Translation of 白虎通 into English.

p.seg: Tiānzǐ 'Son of Heaven'
is the designations of a rank.
Why is this rank called Son of Heaven?
The King
has Heaven as his father, and Earth as his mother;
he is the Son of Heaven1.
Therefore the Yuán shén qì2 says:
"Heaven covers [him], and Earth carries [him]3.
He is called Son of Heaven,
modelling himself above on the pole-star"4.
The Gǒu mìng jué5 says:
"Son of Heaven
is the designation of a rank".
The spiritual power of the Emperors and of the Kings was [with the one] abundant and [with the other] deficient6,
why are they all called Son of Heaven?
Because they are all Kings by the command of Heaven,
to rule within [a territory of] five thousand of li [square]7.
The Shàng shū says:
"The Son of Heaven acts as father and mother of the people,
and in [that capacity] rules as King over all under Heaven"8.
How do we know that the Emperors were also called Son of Heaven?
Because they were the model for all under Heaven9.
The Zhōng hòu says:
"[I,] the Son of Heaven, the servant Fàngxūn (i.e. Emperor Yáo)"10.
The Shū yì piān says:
"He inaugurated the rank of Son of Heaven"11.
p.note: Dadai Liji, 五帝德: 宰我曰：「請問帝堯。」孔子曰：「高辛之子也，曰放勳。

p.seg: Why is it said that the August Ones12 were also called Son of Heaven?
Because it is said of them that Heaven covered [them], and Earth carried [them],
and that they all rulled as Kings over all under Heaven.
Therefore the Yì says:
"When Fúxī ruled as King over all under Heaven...."13.
The ranks are in five grades,
taking the Five Elements as their model;
sometimes they are in three grades,
taking the Three Luminary Bodies14 as their model.
Why do the take as their model now the Three Luminary Bodies,
and now the Five Elements?
The adherents of [the Principle of] Substance base themselves on Heaven,
and therefore model themselves on the Three Luminary Bodies;
the adherents of [the Principle of] Form base themselves on Earth,
and therefore model themselves on the Five Elements15.
The Hán wén jiā16 says:
"The Yīn [Dynasty] had ranks in three grades,
the Zhōu [Dynasty] had ranks in fivē7 grades.
Either [system] was appropriate".
The Wáng zhì says:
"The ranks [, connected with] emoluments [accruing from holdings, which were] instituted by the King,
were in five grades,
namely gōng 'Duke', hóu 'Marquis', bó 'Earl', zǐ 'Viscount', nán 'Baron'"18.
This [saying] is based on19 the institutions of the Zhōu [Dynasty].
The Chūn qīu zhuàn says20:
"The Three Ducal Ministers of the Son of Heaven are called 'Duke'21,
the descendants of the Kings [of the two previous Dynasties] are [also] called 'Duke';
for the rest22 [holders of] large state [-fiefs] are called 'Marquis',
[those of] small state [-fiefs] are called 'Earl', 'Viscount', and 'Baron'".
The Wáng zhì says:
"The 'Duke' and the 'Marquis' hold territories of one hundred li,
the 'Earl' of seventy li,
the 'Viscount' and the 'Baron' of fifity li square"23.
Why are they called gōng 'Duke' and hóu ' Marquis'?
Gōng means expansive tōng,
public-spirited and upright, without selfish intentions24.
Hóú5 means to be on the alert hóu,
on the alert as to [whether his acts will be] against or according to [the King's commands]26.
A Duke and a Marquis both [hold territories which can supply] one thousand war-chariots27;
[the size of these territories] symbolizes the one hundred li within which the sound of thunder [can be heard]28.
Bó 'Earl' means clear báí9.
Zǐ 'Viscount'means diligent zǐ;
[a zǐ] is extremely diligent without end30.
Nán 'Baron' means to be equal to a task rèn31.
A Viscount and a Baron32 both [have territories of] fifty lǐ [square].
There is [thus] variation and gradation [according to] merit and capacity.
Small [states] which are not fully [fifty lǐ] are made sub-fiefs fù-yōng.
Sub-fiefs are added fù
to a large state and presented [to the Son of Heaven] in its namě3.
Why is it that for [a territory of] one hundred lǐ
there are the two ranks of Duke and Marquis,
for [a territory of] seventy lǐ there is [only] one rank,
and for [a territory of] fifity lǐ there are again tow ranks?
[The rank of] Duke
is given as a token of respect to the descedants of the Kings of the two [previous Dynasties;
the rank of] Marquis
is a real rank [connected with a fief] of one hundred lǐ34.
It is proper that for the higher [ranks] there should be gradation;
it is the same for the lower,
so that for the middle [there need] not [be] two [ranks].
The reason for there being two ranks for [a territory of] fifty lǐ,
is to stimulate efforts and to promote men;
it is the same in the smaller states where the lesser dignities
still have a distinction between high and low,
[there,] likewise, [the reason is] is to encourage men.
The Yin [dynasty] had ranks in three grades,
namely gōng, hóu, and bó35.
Why were [the ranks of] zǐ and nán united, and brought together under bó?
When the King, having received the mandate [of Heaven],
abolished [the Principle of] Form and followed [the Principle of] Substance,
he had no right to degrade the men without reason,
and therefore [the ranks of zǐ and nán] were moved upwards, and amalgamated into bó36.
The Shàng shū says:
"[The Lords of] the hóu, diàn, rèn, and wèi [territories] were made bó of [their] states'37;
this was said of the Yin [Dynasty].
The Chūn qiū zhuàn says:
"[The titles of] bó, zǐ, and nán were combined into one"38.
Some say:
"They were combined and brought under zǐ
to honour the middle"39,
[and prove it] from the Chūn qiū, which mentions Hū of Zhèng by his personal name.
Hū was bó of Zhèng.
Here was [a case of a Prince who became] ruler when the year [of the mourning-term for his father] had not yet expired,
and who should have been called zǐ 'Child',
[but] not wishing to change [the titlle of] bó into zǐ,
was mentioned by his personal namè0.
Why is it that the three gradations [in the size] of the states have not been changed,
and only [the gradation of] ranks has been changed?
Land compared with ranks is substantial,
and therefore [its gradation] has not undergone a change.
The King changes the form of an institution,
[but] not its substance.
Why is it that with the House of Yīn43
the gōng were made to occupy [a territory of] one hundred lǐ,
and the hóu [a territory of] seventy lǐ [square]?
The enfeoffing of the worthy was limited to [territories of] one hundred lǐ.
When [the institution was] changed44,
it would not be proper to set back the men in name [only, but it must be accompanied by a decrease in territory].
It [thus] expressed the idea of recompensing the worthy:
there was the wish to reward and honour [the gōng] by placing him above [the hóu]45.
How do we know that with the House of Yin [the territory of] a hóù6 did not exceed seventy lǐ47?
The answer is:
the states48 were in three grades,
[namely] one hundred,
seventy,
and fifty lǐ.
The territories which were half [the size of the large estates] were twice [as many] in number49.
[Therefore,] the institution of land [-tenure], in its organization,
still retained a proportional relation between the size and number [of its territories]50.
What is meant by gōng, qīng, and dà-fū?
They are designations of the interior ranks51.
Why are they called gōng52,qīng, and dà-fū53?
Jué 'rank' means
jìn 'to exhaust'54.
Each [of the three] exhausts his capacities
[in a way] commensurate with his task.
Gōng 'Ducal Minister' means public-spirited, upright, without selfishness.
Qīng 'Minister' means zhāng 'illustrious'55;
[a Minister] makes his abilities illustrious and his principles brilliant56.
Dà-fū 'great officer' means dà-fú 'great aid':
[a great officer] aids in the advancing of [capable] men57.
Therefore the Zhuàn says:
Those who advance the worthy and bring forward the able,
are called dà-fū"58.
Shì 'common officer' means
shì 'to serve'59;
it is the designation of one who is in a position of service60.
Therefore the Zhuàn says:
"He who combines [the knowledge of] antiquity and the present time,
who distinguishes between right and wrong,
is called a shì"61.
How do we know that shì 'common officer' is not a rank62?
The Lǐ says:
"At forty [a man is] in his vigour, and he becomes a shì"63.
It does not speak of obtaining the rank of shì.
When [a man] has reached [the age of] fifty, he receives the rank of great officer64.
How do we know that qīng 'Minister' is a rank?
From [the fact that] dà-fū [is a rank], we know that qīng is a rank likewise.
How do we know that gōng 'Ducal Minister' is a rank?
The Chūn qīu zhuàn says:
"The Feudal lords have four rows of dancers,
the Ducal Ministers have six"65.
[Feudal Lord and Ducal Minister are] mentioned together,
from which we know that gōng 'Ducal Minister' is a rank66.
Why are the interior ranks in three grades?
They, also, are modelled on the Three Luminary Bodies.
Why are they not changed [according to the Principles of] Substance and Form?
The internal [administration] constitutes the basis [of the state's organization],
therefore the interior [ranks] are not changed.
The Feudal Lords have no [dignitaries with the] rank of Ducal Minister,
because their position is beneath that of the Son of Heaven.
Therefore, when the Wáng zhì says:
"Great officers of the higher rank,
great officers of the lower rank;
common officers of the first rank,
common officers of the second rank,
common officers of the third rank;
in all five grades"67,
it refers to the officers of the Feudal Lord68.
Why is it that only with the great officers [is a distinction made between] higher and lower,
whereas with the common officers [a distinction is made between] first, second, and third ranks69?
It indicates that the lower [officers] are more numerous.
All the ranks [are indicated by] one word;
why does dà-fū alone consist of two words?
The Chūn qīu zhuàn says:
"A great officer has no business to act of his own accord"70;
it considers the dà-fū's task to consist in going to the four quarters
and in transmitting to the people
the rules he has received from his Lord.
Therefore he is the only [officer whose rank is] indicated by two words71.
Another opinion says:
Dà-fū
is the lowest rank.
[The great officer is] called dà-fū,
because he receives [his orders] from those above him to transmit them to those below.
In both [explanations the word] dà 'great' is naturally attached [to the title]72.
Why is it that only the common officers of the Son of Heaven are called yuán-shì?
The shì 'common officer' has a lowly [position],
and he cannot have the dignity of being a representative of his Lord.
Therefore [with the common officers of the Son of Heaven the word] yuán is added to distinguish them from the common officers of the Feudal Lords.
When the Lǐ jīng says:
"When a common officer pays a visit to a great officer..."73,
the common officer of the Feudal Lord [is meant].
The Wáng zhì says:
"The King has eighty-one yuán-shì 'common officers'"74.
The title of Son of Heaven is designated by a combination of [the two] words tiān and zǐ;
why is not the title of Feudal Lord [likewese] designated by a combination of [the two] words wáng and hóu?
If75 wáng-hóu were used [the Feudal Lord would have] the same designation as the King76.
And with a weak and feeble [King] he would [thus be tempted to] commit a crime and cherish [thoughts of] usurpation and regicide77.
Another opinion says:
wáng 'King' is a title [conferred] by Heaven,
and the King cannot [give the title of] wáng78 to the Feudal Lords.
Therefore wáng-hóu is not used.
[The title of] Feudal Lord is an affair of men, and is given by [the King] himself.
Therefore [the word wáng is] not attached [to the word hóu]79.
Why is the King's Heir also called shì 'common officer'?
It expresses [the idea] that [everyone] rises from below,
considering that no man is born noble,
and everybody begins with being a common officer.
Thus [though] Shun came in [the course of] time to be called Son of Heaven,
he had first to be tried as a common officer80.
The Lǐ shì guàn jīng says:
"The first son of the Son of Heaven
is a common officer"1.
Why has the wife no rank?
The yin is lowly, and [the woman being yin] has no business outside [her home].
For this reason it is her duty to follow, in three cases, [namely:]
when she is not yet married she follows her father,
when she is married she follows her husband,
and when her husband has died she follows her son2.
So if the husband attains honour at court,
the wife attains glory at home:
she follows in the wake of her husband3.
Therefore the Lǐ jiāo tè shēng says:
"The wife has no rank,
she takes her seat according to the position that belongs to her husband"4.
The Lǐ says:
When one has no rank during one'slife,
one does not receive a title after one's death"85.
[But] the Chūn qīu mentions the spouses fū-rén as all having posthumous titles;
how do we know that fū-rén is not a rank?86
The Lún yǔ says:
"The wife of the Lord of a state
is called 'fū-rén' by the Lord;
the people of the state call her 'the Lord's fū-rén'"87.
If88 [fū-rén] were a rank,
there would be no difference between her designation by the Lord and that by the people of the state.
The common man is called pǐ-fū;
pǐ
means ǒu 'mate';
he is a mate to his wife.
[Thus is expressed] the idea of the mutual completion of the yin and the yang.
One [common] man and one [common] woman [should together] from one household.
It means that the Lord of men
ought not to allow a man and a woman to delay [getting married, and to remain] without a mate.
Therefore the Lún yǔ speaks of
"[the fidelity between] a common man and a common woman"89.
Men have conferred upon them their [administrative] ranks at court,
to express the idea that they are not employed by one man privately,
but [that they are given their charges] with the participation of the multitude.
The Feudal Lords are enfeoffed in the ancestral temple,
to show that [the King] does not act of his own accord.
It means that the laws and ordinances are all institutions of the ancestors,
and that for every act performed announcement must be made to them.
The Wáng-zhì says:
"Ranks are conferred at court,
with the participation of the multitude"90.
The Shī says:
"The King appointed the minister
Nán-zhòng [to be general] before the first ancestor [in the ancestral temple]"91.
The Lǐ jì tǒng says:
"Anciently, when the enlightened ruler conferred ranks upon the virtuous,
it always took place before the first ancestor.
The ruler descended, and stood south of the eastern steps,
with his face to south92,
while those who were to receive their appointments faced north.
The recorder93 was on the right of the ruler, holding the tablets [on which the appointments were written], from which he read"94.
A great officer, who has accomplished meritorious deeds, but dies without having been enfeoffed,
does not posthumously receive a rank,
because he is not yet considered to have sworn allegiance to his ruler95.
The Ch3ūn qīu gǔ liáng zhuàn says:
"To bestow posthumous [distinctions]
is not according to the rites"96.
The Wáng zhì says:
"The funeral [rites] accord with the [rank of the] dead,
the sacrifices accord with the [rank of the] living"97.
Thus
the son practises his filial duty even after the death [of his parent], continuing his care for him.
Why is it that the funeral [rites] accord with [the rank of] the dead?
The son has no right to give a rank to his father.
The Lǐ zhōng yōng jì says:
"If the father is a great officer
and the son a common officer,
the funeral [rites] are those due to a great officer,
while the sacrifices are those due to a common officer.
If the son is a great officer
and the father a common officer,
the sacrifices are those due to a great officer,
while the funeral [rites] are those due to a common officer"98.
Why is it that, when the father is still alive, [the Heir of the Son of Heaven or of a Feudal Lord] is called shì-zǐ 'Generation-[continuing] son'?99
It is to attach him to [his father,] the ruler.
When the father has died, [the son] calls himself 'the Child So-and-so',
because [he is still] in the presence of the corpse in the coffin, [before which] he humbles himself100.
When [the father has been] buried, [the son] calls himself 'Child'101;
he then gradually assumes [his position of] honour.
When the year [in which his father has died] is past, he is called gōng 'Duke' [by his subjects]102,
because in response to the wish of his people there should not be a single day without a ruler103.
According to the principle of succession
there could not be two rulers in one [and the same] year104.
Therefore [only] after the year [of his father's death] has expired should he ascend the throne,
that he may bind the hearts of his people and subjects.
And only after three years105 does he receive [his official] dignity,
because his feelings, as a filial son,
would not [till then] have been able to bear [the thought of] rest and happiness106.
Therefore the Chūn qīu [records]: "Duke Xǐ of Lǔ, in the thirty-third year [of his reign], on [the day] yǐ-sì of the twelfth month,
died in the small chamber"107;
[further:] "in the first year of Duke Wén, in spring, the King's first month,
the Duke ascended the [ducal] throne";
[finally:] "in the fourth month, on [the day] dīng-sì,
we buried our Lord, Duke Xǐ"108.
The Hán shī nèi zhuàn says:
"The Generation-son of a Feudal Lord, after the end of his three years' mourning,
goes [to the King's court] to receive his rank [the emblems of which have been returned at his father's death] and be invested by the Son of Heaven"109.
Why is he called Generation-son?
It expresses the wish that [his line] may not be severed for generations110.
How do we know that the son of the Son of Heaven is also called Generation-son?
The Chūn qīu zhuàn says:
"The Duke [of Lǔ and some other Feudal Lords] had a meeitng with the [King's] Generation-som at Shǒu-zhǐ"111.
Another opinion is:
the son of the Son of Heaven is called tài-zǐ 'Eldest Son'.
The Shàng shū zhuàn says:
"The 'Eldest Son' Fā ascended into the boat"112.
The Zhōng hòu says:
"[King Wén] put aside [his eldest son Bó-yí] Kǎo,
and set up Fā as tài-zǐ 'Eldest Son'".
This shows that in the time of King Wén [the Heir] was called tài-zǐ113.
Why is it that the Generation-son [of a Feudal Lord], after the end of his three years' mourning,
must114 go [to court] to receive [again] his rank and be invested by the Son of Heaven?
It means that [the bestowal of] rank and land115 belongs to [the prerogatives of] the Son of Heaven116,
and that a subject has no right to take a rank upon himself.
When a youth [who is not yet capped] is to receive his father's117 rank and be invested,
[the Son of Heaven] sends a great officer to his state to invest him [therewith].
It means that the King need not observe the rites towards a youth.
The Chūn qiū relates that Duke Chéng of Lǔ in his youth
had a meeting with the Feudal Lords,
[but the Marquis of Chin] did not see him118.
The Classic [, however,] does not regard it as [bringing] shame on Lǔ.
It indicates that towards a youth the rites need not be observed119.
When the Generation-son of a Feudal Lord goes120 [to court] to receive his rank and be invested,
why does he wear the dress of a common officer?
[He does so] out of modesty, not daring [in anticipation] to assume [his rank] by himself.
Thus the Shī says: "Red are his dyed leather kneecovers"121;
this was said of the Generation-son [of a Feudal Lord] setting out on his way [to the King's court].
That, after the Greater Dressing122 of the [deceased] Son of Heaven, [his Heir] is called King,
indicates that his people and subjects123 cannot be without a ruler [even] for one day.
Therefore the Shàng shū says:
"The King was dressed in a hempen cap and a variously adorned skirt"124;
this was after [the event of] the Greater125 Dressing126.
How do we know that it is not [immediately] after the death that [the title of] King is given [to the Heir]?127
Because [the Shàng shū] previously speaks of "meering the Child Zhāo",
and not of "meeting the [new] King"128.
Why is it that as soon as the [deceased] King has been encoffined, [his Heir] assumes the position of continuing the body [politic]129?
Because, in response to the wish of his people and subjects, they should not be without a ruler [even] for one day.
Therefore, no sooner is the former ruler invisible
than the succeeding ruler continues the body [politic].
The Shàng shū says:
"The [new] King twice bowed low, and then arose and replied...;
he thereupon received the [royal] seal"130;
this signifies that he had become the ruler who continued the body [politic].
According to the principle of succession131
there could not be two rulers in one [and the same] year.
Therefore the Shàng shū says:
"The King put off his cap, and resumed his mourning-dress"132.
He had donned his auspicious cap and garments133, he had received the seal,
and he had been called King so that [in that capacity] he could receive the Feudal Lords [in audience].
It means that he had become ruler by [having accepted] the continuance of the body [politic.
Then] he put off his [auspicious] cap [and garments], he had the seal stored away, and resumed the mourning [-dress].
This means that he had not yet been called King to govern [state-] affairs.
It is not proper that there should be no ruler for one whole year134.
And so, when the year [of the ruler's death] has expired, [his successor] ascends the throne, and begins his own chronology gǎi-yuán135.
Yuán is used to name the year [of accession136;
the use of] nián 'year' [implies, that the] affairs [that have taken place] have been chronicled137.
The ruler has by now taken the government of affairs into his hands138,
though he does not yet promulgate orders [himself].
How do we know that after the elapse of the year [in which the King died, his Heir] ascends the throne and begins his own chronologǖ39?
The Chūn qīu zhuàn says:
"[From the fact that] the Feudal Lords ascend the throne after the year [of death] is past,
we know that it is also the case with the Son of Heaven"140.
And the Chūn qīu [repeatedly] speaks of
"in the beginning of the year, spring, the King's first month,
[our] Duke ascends the throne"141,
[which means that the Duke has] attained to the position of beginning his own chronology.
When the King
begins his own chronologǖ42,
he sacrifices to Heaven and Earth;
When a Feudal Lord begins his own chronology,
he sacrifices to the Gods of the Earth and of the Millet143.
The Wáng zbì says:
"During the three years of mourning the sacrifices are stopped,
except those offered to Heaven and Earth, and to the Gods of the Earth and of the Millet.
For the execution [of these sacrifices the mourner even] steps over the cords of the funeral car"144.
When the Chūn qīu zhuàn says:
"The Son of Heaven calls himself King after three years [of mourning]145",
it means that he is called King [in so far as] the government of the affairs [of state]
and the issuing of orders [are concerned].
And when the Shàng shū says:
"Gāo-zōng remained in the mourning-shed for three years"146,
[it also means] this.
The Lún yǔ says:147
"When the lord dies,
all the officials, for the attendance of their several duties, take their orders from the Grand Administrator for three years"148.
Giving away to his feeling s of a filial son
[the new King] for three years
cannot bear to assume [his position of actual ruler]149.
Therefore only after three years does he take off his mourning[-dress],
and does he ascend the throne to administer the affairs [of state]150;
he [then] mounts the eastern steps151 in the capacity of Master [of the house],
and facing south he gives audience to his Ministers and subjects,
calling himself King [, being now in the position] to issue orders [himself].
Thus, only when the Son of Heaven or a Feudal Lord after three years ascends the throne,
[may it be said that] the principle of succession has been completely carried out.
To spend three years in the mourning-shed
means to continue in the way of a filial son to the very end.
Therefore the Lún yǔ says:
"All the men of old behaved likewisē52:
when the Lord died,
all the officials, for the attendnece of their several duties, took their orders from the Grand Administrator for three years"153.
Why do they take their orders from the Grand Administrator for three years?
It is [one of] the tasks of the Grand Administrator to determine the expenditure of the state,
so that it is through him [that the officials receive their orders].
Therefore the Wáng zhì says:
"The Grand Administrator determines the expenditure of the state"154.
Why is the Grand Administrator called zhǒng-zǎi?
Zhǒng means
dà 'great';
zǎi means
zhì 'to regulate'.
He is the great regulator of the affairs [of state].
So the Wáng dù jì155 says:
"The Son of Heaven has one Grand Administrator,
whose rank and emoluments are like those of his great officer".
Another opinion says: the Grand Administrator ranks as a qīng 'Minister'.
This is what the Zhōu guān says156.
What do [the words] dì and wáng signify?
They are appellations hàō57.
An appellation
is the outward sign of an [achieved] merit158.
Therewith the [achievement of the] merit is expressed and the [possession of] spiritual power is manifested,
in order to command the [multitude of] subjects159.
When his spiritual power [harmoniously] combines [that of] Heaven and Earth [the Sovereign] is called dì 'Emperor'160.
When [his spiritual power is the harmonious] combination of consideration for others and sense of the right principles he is called wáng 'King'161.
[Thus] a distinction is made between abundance and scarcity [in the possession of spiritual power].
The Lǐ jì shì fǎ162 says:
"When his spiritual power resembles [that of] Heaven and Earth [the Sovereign] is called dì;
he from whom consideration for others and sense of the right principles proceed is call wáng"163.
Dì
is an appellation [connected with] Heaven;
wáng
is a designation [which is connected with the succession of the spiritual power] of the Five Elements164.
What is the meaning of Huáng?
It is also an appellation165.
Huáng
means jūn 'lord'166,
měi 'beautiful'167,
dà 'great'168.
It was the designation for the combination
of what was beautiful and august in Heaven169.
Owing to the primitivity of the time
[Heaven's beauty and augustness] were generally designated [by this term].
He was called huáng
who shed forth a resplendence huáng-huáng which none could escapē70.
If in his labours for all under Heaven
one great officer were troubled
or one common officer were distressed
[a Sovereign] would not be [called] huáng.
He did not distress the common man nor the common worman,
and thus it was that he was [called] huáng 'the August One'.
Therefore [the August Ones] disregarded the gold that lay hid in the mountains
and suffered the pearls and jade to be lost in the deep171;
they dwelt on mountain-peaks or housed in caves172;
they were clad in hide and fur173;
they drank the freshness of the well
and supped of the radiance of the dew174;
empty and absent, vast and void [was their mind]175;
they were in communication with the spirituality of Heaven and Earth176.
Why is the [Sovereign's] appellation sometimes dì Emperor?
Dì means
tì 'to examine'177.
He symbolizes what may be transmitted [to later generations].
Wáng 'King' means
wǎng 'to go to'.
[A King is he] whom all under Heaven turn to.178.
The Gǒu mìng jué says:
"The Three August Ones walked leisurely,
the Five Emperors walked hurriedly,
the Three Kings ran,
the Five Hegemons galloped"179.
Why is [the Sovereign] sometimes called Son of Heaven,
sometimes Emperor or King?
When, connecting him above [with Heaven], he is called Son of Heaven,
it means that he serves Heaven by [the virtue of] his rank;
when, connecting him below [with Earth], he is called Emperor or King,
it means that his position and appellation, being the most exalted in all under the Heaven,
[entitle him] to command [all his] subjects180.
Therefore the Shàng shū says:
"The Emperor [Yáo] said,
Oh! Chiefs of the Four Mountains"1ī.
[Again it says]: "The King said,
Come, all of you"1í.
Sometimes he calls himself The One Man1ǐ.
The King calls himself The One Man
out of modesty,
wishing to express [thereby] that his ability only stands for that of one man.
Therefore the Lún yǔ says:
"If the people have sinned
let [the blame] be laid upon me,The One Man"185.
Why do the subjects186 speak of him as The One Man?
To honour the King therewith.
Within the wideness of all under Heaven
and within the confines of the Four Seas
there is only one man whom they honour in unison187.
Therefore the Shàng shū says:
"You do not extend [your goodwill] to Our One Man [, The Son of Heaven]"188.
Why does [the King] sometimes call [himself] zhèn?
It also [indicates] the King's modesty.
Zhèn means
wǒ 'We'189.
Sometimes he calls [himself] yú.
Yú also means wǒ 'We'190.
That he does not call himself with honourable [words],
but only [calls] himself [with words meaning] 'We' [testifies to] him modesty in every case.
Why is [the King] sometimes called jūn-zǐ 'Noble Man'?
It is the designation of [one who has obtained] the spiritual power [which proceeds from the possession] of the Way.
Jūn means qún 'to flock'191.
Zǐ
is the common designation of an adult man192.
Therefore the Xiào jīng says:
"The teaching of the Noble Man consists in filial piety,
therewith to induce the fathers in all under Heaven to be reverenced [by their sons]"193.
How do we know194 that 'Noble Man' is a common designation?
Because [the expression is employed] for the Son of Heaven down to the [common] people.
The Shī says:
"A gay and affable Noble Man
is the father and mother of his people"195.
The Lún yǔ says:
"A Noble Man indeed is such a man"196;
this was said [by Confucius] of his disciple,
who
was a man of the people.
Who
were the Three August Ones?
They were said to be Fú-xī, Shén-nóng, and Suì-rén.
Others say [they were]
Fú-xī, Shén-nóng, and Zhù-róng198.
The Lǐ says:
Fú-xi,1 Shén-nóng, and Zhù-róng
were the Three August Ones"199.
Why is Fú-xī so called200?
Anciently
[the rules for] the Three Major and the Six Minor Relationships were not yet [in practise]201.
The people only knew their mothers,
but not their fathers202.
They knew how to cover the front [part of their bodies], but not how to cover the back [part].
They slept snoring
and awoke puffing and screaming203.
When they were hungry they hunted for food,
when satiated they threw away what was left.
They swallowed the hair and feathers [with the flesh of the beast they ate], drank [their] blood,
and clothed themselves in hide and rushes204.
Thereupon Fú-xī appeared and, looking up, contemplated the forms [exhibited] in the sky;
looking down, he surveyed the patterns [shown] on the earth205.
He regulated [the union between] husband and wife,
put right [the order of] the Five Elements,
and gave a beginning of a regulation of human behaviour206.
He drew up the Eight Trigrams
in order to rule all under Heaven207.
When [all under Heaven had been] subjugated208, he civilized them.
Therefore he is called Fú-xī 'the Subjugator Xī'209.
Why is Shén-nóng so called?
The people of antiquity ate the [raw] flesh of birds and quadrupeds.
At the time of Shén-nóng
[the number of] people increased,
and the [quantity of] birds and quadrupeds did not suffice.
Thereupon Shén-nóng, following the seasons of Heaven,
made a [proper] division of the uses of the land210,
instituted ploughing and weeding,
and taught the people husbandry.
He exerted such a spirit-like transformation,
that the people felt constrained to approve [his ordinances] at right211.
Therefore he is called Shén-nóng 'the Sprirtual Husbandman'.
Why is Suì-rén so called?
He drilled [a peice of] wood, [so that] it burned and fire [could be] taken out of it212.
He taught people to cook their food,
he stimulated their instruct for taking advantage [of the circumstances213,
he instructed them] to avoid odours and drive out poison,
and is [therefore] called Suì-rén 'the Fire-drilling Man'214.
Why is Zhù-róng so called?
Zhù means
shǔ 'to connect to'215.
Róng means
xù 'to continue'216.
It means that [Zhù-róng] was able to connect himself to and continue the way of the Three August Ones and put it into practise.
Therefore he is called Zhù-róng 'the Connecter and Continuer'217.
Who
were the Five Emperor?
The Lǐ says:
"Huáng-dì, Zhuān-xū, Dì-kù, Dì-yáo, and Dì-shùn
were the Five Emperors"218.
The Yì says:
"Huáng-dì, Yáo, and Shùn appeared and exercised their influence"219.
The Shū speaks of
Dì-yáo
and Dì-shùn220.
Huáng 'yellow'
is the colour of equilibrium and harmonǘ21.
[Huáng-dì has] the nature of spontaneity,
[his institutions] do not change for ten thousand generations222.
Huáng-dì was the first to instroduce institutions and regulations,
by which he attained the state of equilibrium and harmonǘ23,
to be continually preserved during ten thousand generations.
Therefore he is called Huáng-dì 'the Yellow Emperor'.
Why is Zhuān-xū so called?
Zhuān means
zhuān 'special'224.
Xū means
zhèng 'to correct'225.
He was able [to apply himself] especially to correct the Way of Heaven and man226.
Therefore he is called Zhuān-xū 'the Special Corrector'.
Why is Dì-kù so called?
Kù means
jí 'the utmost'227.
It means that he was able to put into practise and to exhaust to the utmost the spiritual power [emanating from the possession] of the [right] Waǘ28.
Why is Yáo so called?
Yáo means
yáo-yáo 'high and eminent'229.
He had the appearance of extreme height.
[His spiritual power was] pure and subtle, high and far-reaching,
abundant and extensive, vast and overflowing.
He was the chief of the multitudinous Sages,
the first of the Hundred Kings.
Why is Shùn so called?
Shùn means chuǎn-chuǎn 'to match'230.
It means that he was able to pursue and follow the way of Yáo and put it into practisé31.
Who
were the Three Kings?
They were [the Kings of the Dynasties of] Xià, Yīn, and Zhōú32.
So the Lǐ shì guàn jīng says:
"[The cap used by the] Zhōu [was called] biàn, [that used by the] Yīn [was called] xǔ, [that used by the] Xià [was called] shōu.
With all the three Dynasties the cap [worn] was [always] of white deer-skin"233.
Why is it that we have the appellations Xià, Yīn, and Zhōu?
When a King has received the mandate [from Heaven],
he must create a beautiful appellation [expressing his possession] of all under Heaven, in order thereby to express his achievements and make himself illustrious234.
It means that he has changed the clan-namé35 [of the former Dynasty], and [has established new] institutions for his sons and grandsons [to continue].
Xià, Yīn, and Zhōu
were the great appellations of [the Dynasties] all under Heaven.
The Hundred Kings had in common the possession of all under Heaven,
so that there was nothing [with which] to distinguish them from each other.
[So] they changed the institutions and created a great appellation236 [expressing their possession] of all under Heaven
to distinguish themselves [therewith] from the past,
so that their meritorious achievement might be expressed and displayed.
That they considered it necessary to change the appellation
was in order to show that Heaven's decree had already manifested itself,
and that [Heaven] desired that [the new Dynasty] be exalted in the face of all under Heaven.
If [the new Dynasty] should adopt and continue the appellation of the previous King,
it would not be different from [the case of] a Lord who succeeds to the government of the body [politic] and preserves its cultural [institutions].
Not to manifest the lustre [meant by Heaven]
is against Heaven's intention237.
Therefore a King who has received the mandate [from Heaven]
must choose a beautiful appellation [denoting his possession] of all under Heaven,
which expresses his meritorious achievement;
it means that he is [now] in the position to display and exercise [his spiritual influence].
By it he will have prepared his own lustre against the past238.
Why is not the clan-namé39 taken as the appellation?
A clan-name
is a designation by one word
which is shared by high and low240.
The Feudal Lords, as rulers of the Hundred Clans,
are each designated by the name of [their] one state.
The Son of Heaven, as the most exalted,
now assumes an appellaion [expressing] the possession of all under Heaven and the union of the ten thousand states.
Xià means
dà 'great'241.
It means [that the Dynasty was] equal to the task of preserving and holding fast the great principle dà-dào.
Yīn means
zhōng 'equilibrium'242.
It means [that the Dyansty was] equal to [the task of maintaining] the way of equilibrium and harmonǘ43.
Zhōu means
zhì 'to reach',
mì 'perfect'244.
The spiritual power [proceeding from the possession] of the [right] Way [exercised by the Dynasty] was complete and perfect,
and there was nothing which it did not reach.
How do we know that [a King], after having assumed his reign, establishes a [new] appellation?
The Shī says:
"[Heaven] gave the appointment to King Wén,
in Zhōu, in his capital"245;
this refers to the changing of the appellation [of Yīn] into Zhōu,
and to the conversion of its town into the capital.
The Chūn qīu zhuàn says:
"When a King, after receiving the mandate [of Heaven], assumes his kingship,
he must choose a beautiful appellation [expressing hs possession] of all under Heaven, to denominate his own [Dynasty] therewith"246.
Why is it that the Five Emperors and no appellation [denoting their possession] of all under Heaven?
The spiritual power of the Five Emperors was great, and they were able to cede [their thrones in behalf of others]247;
they regarded the people as their children,
and they achieved perfection in all under Heaven
without the need of establishing an appellation.
Another opinion is:
Táng and Yú were appellations [of Yáo and Shùn]248.
Táng means dàng-dàng 'vast and distant'249.
Vast and distant
is the bearing of one whose spiritual power [, proceeding from the possession] of the [right] Way, has reached its apex of greatness.
Yú means
lè 'joys'250.
It means that, when all under Heaven [in the reign of Shun] walked in the right Way,
all the people rejoiced.
Therefore the Lún yǔ speaks of:
"the turn of [the reigns of] Táng and Yú"251.
Dì-kù had an appellation [, expressing his possession] of all under Heaven,
called Gāo-xīn252.
Zhuān-xū had an appellation [, expressing his possession] of all under Heaven,
called Gāo-yáng253.
Huáng-dì had an appellation [, expressing] his possession of all under Heaven,
called Yǒu-xióng254.
Yǒu-xióng means
[that he possessed] a special abundance of spiritual power [proceeding from his keeping] the Waǘ55.
Yáng of Gāo-yáng means
míng 'bright'256.
The spiritual power [emanating from his possession] of the [right] Way was high and bright.
Gāo-xīn means
that the spiritual power [proceeding from his possession] of the [right] Way was great and sinceré57.
Who
were the Five Hegemons?
They were Kūn-wú, Dà-péng, Shǐ-wěi, Duke Huán of Qí, and Duke Wén of Jìn258.
Anciently, when the way of the Three Kings deteriorated,
the Five Hegemons preserved the government;
they led the Feudal Lords in presenting themselves [regularly] at the court of the Son of Heaven;
they kept the development of all under Heaven in the right track;
they revived the Middle State
and repulsed the barbarians;
therefore they were called bà 'Hegemon'.
Formerly Kūn-wú
was Hegemon under the Xià,
Dà-péng and Shǐ-wěi
were Hegemons under the Yīn,
[Duke] Huán of Qí and [Duke] Wén of Jìn
were Hegemons under the Zhōú59.
Another opinion is:
"the Five Hegemons
were Duke Huán of Qí, Duke Wén of Jìn, Duke Mù of Qín, King Zhuāng of Chǔ, and King Hé-lǘ of Wú"260.
Bà means
bó 'chief'261.
[The Hegemons] executed the task of the fāng-bó262,
they assembled the Feudal Lords at the court of the Son of Heaven,
[and caused them] to neglect their duty as subjects.
Therefore the Sage justified them
[and in doing so] condemned [the circumstance] that the laws of the enlightened Kings could not be put into practisé63.
Bà also means può 'to compel',
bǎ 'to take'264.
The Hegemons compelled the Feudal Lords [to do their duties],
and took into their hands the [execution of the royal] government.
The Lún yǔ says:
"Guǎng Zhòng acted as Minister for Duke Huán [of Qí],
and made him Hegemon over the Feudal Lords"265.
The Chūn qīu says:
"The Duke [of Lǔ] paid a court-visit in the place where the King was"266;
by this we know that [Duke] Wén of Qín [at that time] was Hegemon267.
The Shàng shū says:
"The glory and tranquility of the state CHECK TEXT
also have their cause in [my,] the One Man's felicity"268;
[by this] we know that [Duke] Mù of Qín was [at that time] Hegemon.
Chǔ conquered Zhèng, but did not [keep its territory.
When the Earl of Zhèng] announced his submission it forgave him269.
It also ordered its army to return,
and [thus] suffered [the remaining forces] of the brigands of Jìn to escapé70.
[When Chǔ] laid siege to Sòng,
and Sòng yielded, [Chǔ] granted it peace
and led its army awaǘ71.
[By this] we know that Zhuāng of Chǔ was Hegemon272.
The Marquis of Cài without guilt
was seized [and detained] by Chǔ.
[King Hé-lǘ of] Wú [although a barbarian] cherished feelings of concern for the [affairs in the] Middle State;
he raised an army and attacked Chǔ;
none of the Feudal Lords dared not come [at his summons for the expedition273.
By this] we know that [Hé-lǘ of] Wú was Hegemon
Some say:
"The Five Hegemons
were Duke Huán of Qí, Duke Wén of Jìn, Duke Mù of Qín, Duke Xiāng of Sòng, King Zhuāng of Chǔ"274.
When Duke [Xiāng of] Sòng was at war with Chǔ at Hong,
he did not beat the drum [for the attack] before [the army of Chǔ] had been ranged [in battle array]275.
The Chūn qīu zhuan says:
"Even the battle of King Wén did not surpass this [display of generosity"276;
by this we know [that Xiāng of Sòng] was Hegemon.
Since the subjects of Earls, Viscounts, and Barons laudatively call their Lords gōng 'Duke' in their own states,
why is it that only the subjects of the King
are not allowed to call their Sovereign by the laudativé77 title of dì 'Emperor'?
Because the Feudal Lords have the duty of assembling
and the custom of paying visits to each other.
[Now in the Chūn qiū the Feudal Lords are] sometimes called gōng 'Duke' to honour them,
sometimes they are called [by their proper titles Marquis,] Earl, Viscount, or Baron to disparage them278.
[But] on the occasion of a meeting between the Feudal Lords the subjects are not required to observe the [strict ritual rules appertaining to the] status [of their Lords.
These subjects] may wish to exalt their lordly fathers [above the other rulers],
and so in general it is allowed to the subjects to call their own Lords gōng 'Duke'279.
The Emperors and Kings[,however,] lived in [mutually separate and] different times,
so that there was no occasion for them to meet as equals.
Therefore there is none who could be considered as their peer [above whom they should be exalted].
How do we know that the Feudal Lords may be called gōng 'Duke'280?
The Chūn qīu says:
"[We] buried Duke Huán of Qí";
Qí was only a Marquisate.
The Shàng shū says:
"The Duke [of Qín] said, Ah! [my officers]"
Qín was an earldom.
The Shī says:
"The Duke of Tán was her brother-in-law"
Tán
was a viscounty.
The Chūn qīu says:
"[We] buried Duke Mìu of Xǔ"2ì;
Xǔ
was a barony.
The Lǐ dà shè jīng says:
"[If the arrow hits the stay of the target and hangs from it, or ricochets into the target, or rebounds from the target without piercing it, only] in the case of the Duke will it be scored"285.
The Great Archery [Meeting]
belongs to the ritual [meetings to be held] by the Feudal Lords286.
Earls, Viscounts, and Barons are [then] all present287.
Therefore the Lǐ jiāo tè shēng says:
"Anciently those who had no rank during their life
did not receive a posthumous name at death either".
This means that he who had a rank during his life ought
to receive a posthumous name at death.
Why is the posthumous name given after death?
The Shī says:
"All men [are good] at first
but few prove themselves [to be so] at the last";
it means that a man's behaviour is not the same throughout his life,
so that it is only by his end
that his beginning may be known.
The Shì guàn jīng says:
"The conferring of a posthumous name at the death [of a common officer]
is a recent [innovation]".
Why is that posthumous name given just before the funeral?
To avail oneself of the opportunity of there being a gathering [of relatives and friends,
in whose presence one] wishes to elevate [the deceased].
Therefore the Chūn qīu says:
"The coffin of the Duke arrived from Gān-hóu".
Duke Zhāo [of Lǔ] died in the region of Gān-hóu in [the state of] Jìn,
and [his corpse] was returned
in great haste after several months.
It was right that [for this event] his posthumous name was not yet [mentioned].
The Chūn qiū [further] says:
"On [the day] dīng-sì there should have been the interment [of our ruler, Duke Ding; but the rain came down so that it could not carried out];
on [the next day] wù-wǔ, when the sun had begun to decline, it could be done".
[This] means that the posthumous name was given at the sacrifice of departure [, when the coffin had been placed on the hearse].
What
does shì mean?
Shì 'to bestow a posthumous name' means yǐn 'to extend';
to extend and display the vestiges of one's conduct
in order to stimulate the perfection of spiritual power,
and to induce the supersior
to the cultivation of probity.
Why is it that in [the name of] Huáng-dì the word huáng 'yellow' is put first, and [the word] dì 'Emperor' is put last?
In ancient times [emphasis was laid on] simplicity,
and in life as well as after death the denomination was the same,
in either case being formed in accordance with one's conduct.
The beautiful [name of huáng] is placed above.
Huáng-dì was the first to institute laws and measures,
obtaining [therewith] the right course of the Way,
which was not to change in ten thousand generations.
Later ages, though [producing] Sages,
have never been able to equal him.
Even when, their spiritual power being similar to that of Heaven,
[the Sages of] later ages may have been called dì 'Emperor',
they still were not able to create institutions,
so that none of them could be called huáng again.
Why does a posthumous name sometimes consist of one word,
and sometimes of two words?
The [adherents of the Principle of] Form used one word for a posthumous name [, as in the case of King Wén and King Wǔ].
The [adherents of the Principle of] Substance used two words;
thus
after his death Tāng [of the Yīn Dynasty]
was called Chéng-tāng,
[so that] his posthumous name was made up of two words.
Why is it that with the appellations there is no [distinction between] Substance and Form,
whereas this distinction exists with respect to the posthumous names?
The appellation
is the original [denomination];
it is considered the base,
and therefore cannot be changed.
From the Zhōu [Dynasty]
onwards [a futher] ornamentation was added with deliberation,
holding that the orders issued during the life-time should be considered as the base;
if they were good, the King received a good posthumous name.
Therefore, linking [the posthumous name with the appellation wáng 'King'], we speak of Wén-wáng and Wǔ-wáng.
In thus linking [the posthumous name Wén or Wǔ with the appellation wáng] the posthumous name is put first.
[The use of posthumous names] means that distinction is made between good and bad [behaviours],
so that men are stimulated to goodnass
and warned against evil.
Dì 'Emperor'
is the appellation [conferred] by Heaven,
and Yáo is to be regarded as a posthumous name.
But since the oldest times [emphasized] simplicity,
and simply used the 'personal name' míng as an appellation after death,
why has then the posthumous name of Yáo been created?
There are seventy-two articles for the composing of posthumous names.
The Lǐ jì shì fā says:
"He who has attended to the good and transmitted [the Way of] the Sages is posthumously called Yáo;
he whose consideration for others and sageness are abundant and illustrious is posthumously called Shùn;
he who is tender-hearted, liberal and loving towards the people is posthumously called Wén;
he who is strong, vigorous, principled and straightforward is posthumously called Wǔ.
Why is it that at the death of the Son of Heaven
the high dignitaries proceed to [the altar of Heaven in] the southern suburb to give him his posthumous name?
Because
it is the duty of a subject of man
not to fail to eulogize his Lord,
to conceal his faults, and to exalt his virtues.
Therefore [the dignitaires] proceed to the southern suburb,
indicating [therewith] that Heaven should not be deceived.
So the Zēng zǐ wèn [says]:
"Confucius said:
When the Son of Heaven dies
his Ministers proceed to the southern suburb, and, announcing it [to Heaven], give a posthumous name".
Why is it that when a Feudal Lord dies
his Generation-son
goes and announces it to the Son of Heaven,
who sends his great officer to attend the funeral and give a posthumous name?
"The young do not pronounce funeral eulogies on the elder,
neither do the inferior on the superior.
Feudal Lords eulogizing each other at the funeral
would be against the rites".
The subject ought to receive his posthumous name from his ruler.
Why is it that a Minister or a great officer who has retired from old age and dies receives a posthumous name?
The posthumous name
is given to distinguish between the high and the lowly,
and to make illustrious those who have spiritual power.
When a Minister or a great officer retires without having committed a crime
he is continued in his salaried position,
and therefore he will receive a posthumous name.
Why does not the Spouse [of a Feudal Lord] receive a posthumous name?
She has no rank,
and therefore she will have no posthumous name.
Another opinion is:
the Spouse [of a Feudal Lord] receives a posthumous name;
she is the mother of the state,
and takes care [of the affairs] within the women's doors,
so that all the subjects are also affected [by her conduct].
Therefore a posthumous name is accorded to her, to make manifest her good or bad [behaviour].
The Chūn qiū records:
"Funeral of [Duke] Gōng['s Spouse Bo]-jī of Sòng".
The Zhuàn [explaining this entry] says:
"Why is she called by the posthumous name [of her husband]?
Because of her virtuous conduct".
[In another case] the Zhuàn states:
"Who was Āi-jiāng?
She was the Spouse of Duke Zhuāng".
Why does the woman who with the approval of the Son of Heaven
has been taken as the principal wife by a Minister or a great officer
not receive a posthumous title?
[Because of her] lowly [position].
Why do not the Eight Concubines [of a Feudal Lord] receive a posthumous name?
They also [have a] lowly [position],
and cannot assist [in any governmental affair].
Like a common officer they are lowly and petty,
so that they have no right to a posthumous name.
Why does not the Spouse of the Heir [of the Son of Heaven] receive a posthumous name?
In principle the wife follows her husband.
As the Heir does not receive a posthumous name,
his wife also has no right to one.
The Shì guàn jīng says:
"The Heir of the Son of Heaven is like any common officer".
Since a common officer has no posthumous name
we know the Heir [of the Son of Heaven] has none either.
Why is it that [the holders of] a sub-fief receive no posthumous names?
[Because their position is] lowly and petty, and they have no rank.
The Wáng zhì says:
"The institution of ranks
and emoluments in antiquity
[comprised] in all five degrees".
The subfief is not included,
which means that its holder
has no rank.
In which place is the posthumous name given to the Principal Consort of the Son of Heaven?
[It is given] in the Hall of Audience,
which is the place where the affairs of the state are conducted.
The Ministers gather [there], and select a posthumous name, which they announce to the ruler,
who then confers it [upon the deceased].
"A wife regards her husband
as her Heaven".
Therefore it is sufficient to announce [the chosen name] to the ruler [,who is her husband and Heaven].
How do we know that [for the conferring of a posthumous name upon the Principal Consort of the Son of Heaven] they do not proceed to [the altar of Heaven in] the southern suburb?
A wife has in principle no business outside [the women's rooms],
why [should there be any necessity to proceed to] the southern suburb?
The Zēng zǐ wèn says:
"It is 'only' wéi in the case of the Son of Heaven that the term Heaven is used by way of eulogy".
Wéi 'only' means
dú 'exclusively'.
It means that it is exclusively in the case of the Son of Heaven [that his posthumous name is announced to Heaven] in the southern suburb.
What do the appellation and the posthumous name, which make manifest [the deceased's conduct], take as their model?
The appellation models itself on Heaven
and the sun.
Before the sun rises it is already bright.
The posthumous name models itself on Earth
and the moon.
After the moon has set there is still light.
"For this reason one receives a great name, when one's conduct was great;
one receives a small name, when one's conduct was petty.
The conduct originates from oneself,
the name originates from others".
What is meant
by the Five Deities?
They are the outer door, the inner door, the well, the hearth, and the impluvium.
Why are they worshipped?
Because they are the places where men dwell, by which they go in and out,
and where they drink and eat.
Therefore they are worshipped as spirits.
How do we know that the Five Deities are called outer door, inner door, well, hearth and impluvium?
The Yuè lìng says:
"[In spring] they sacrifice to the inner door,
[in summer] to the hearth,
[in the middle of the year] to the impluvium,
[in autumn] to the outer door,
and [in winter] to the well".
Why is it that only [those with the rank of] great officer and higher have the right to sacrifice [to the Five Deities]?
A common officer has a lowly position and a meagre renumeration,
[so] he only sacrifices to his ancestors.
The Lǐ says:
"The Son of Heaven sacrifices to Heaven and Earth,
the Feudal Lords sacrifice to the mountains and rivers,
the Ministers and great officers to the Five Deities,
the common officers sacrifice to their ancestors".
The Qǔ lǐ xià jì says:
"The Son of Heaven sacrifices to Heaven and Earth,
to the Four Cardinal Points,
to the mountains and rivers,
and to the Five Deities,
all in the course of the year.
The Feudal Lords sacrifice to the spirits of their territory, to the mountains and rivers,
and to the Five Deities,
all in the course of the year.
The Ministers and great officers sacrifice to the Five Deities,
the common officers sacrifice to their ancestors.
There should be no presuming
to resume any sacrifice which has been abolished [by proper authority],
nor to abolish any which has been so established.
A sacrifice which it is not proper to offer, and which yet is offered, is called a licentious sacrifice.
A licentious sacrifice brings no blessing".
Why are the Five Deities successively sacrificed to in the course of the year?
They follow [the succession of] the Five Elements.
Therefore in spring a sacrifice is offered to the inner door;
through the inner door men
go in and out,
and it is also in spring that the ten thousand things begin to knock against the inner door [of the earth] to get out.
In summer a sacrifice is offered to the hearth;
the hearth
is the origin of fire,
and it is there that men [prepare their food to] nourish themselves;
in summer also it is fire which governse:
it grows and nourishes the ten thousand things.
In autumn a sacrifice is offered to the outer door;
the outer door, by beeing closed, conceals and keeps man in safety;
it is also in autumn that the ten thousand things develop to maturity
while preparing and guarding themselves within [the earth].
In winter a sacrifice is offered to the well;
the well
is the source of water,
which lies hidden beneath the earth;
in winter also it is water which governs:
in it the ten thousand things lie in concealment.
In the sixth month a sacrifice is offered to the impluvium;
the impluvium
resembles [a heap of] earth in the middle of the house;
in the sixth month also it is earth which governs.
So the Yuè lìng under "Spring" says that a sacrifice is given to the inner door,
while the spleen [of the victim] is offered first;
under "Summer" it says that a sacrifice is given to the hearth,
while the lungs [of the victim] are offered first;
under "Autumn" it says that a sacrifice is given to the outer door,
while the liver [of the victim] is offered first;
under "Winter" it says that a sacrifice is given to the well,
while the kidneys [of the victim] are offered first;
under "Middle [of the year]" it says that a sacrifice is given to the impluvium,
while the heart [of the victim] is offered first.
Why is it that in spring, at the sacrifice to the inner door,
the spleen is especially offered first?
The spleen
belongs to [the element] earth.
In spring wood is 'king', and it 'kills' earth.
Therefore that which is conquered is sacrificed.
Why is it that in winter the kidneys are offered and in the sixth month the heart,
whereas they do not
belong to the [elements which are] conquered?
Earth occupies the centre,
and represents the most honoured [element],
therefore it is offered the heart,
which
is the principal part of the intestines.
Water occupies the lowest [position],
and has nothing to conquer for its sacrifice.
At the sacrifice to the Five Deities
the Son of Heaven and the Feudal Lords use a bull,
the Ministers and great officers use a ram.
The offering of the victims [varies] according to the four seasons.
Another opinion says: a ram is sacrificed to the inner door,
a fowl to the hearth,
a sucking-pig to the impluvium,
a dog to the outer door,
a pig to the well.
Others say that
to the impluvium a bull is sacrificed,
and if a bull is not available, a sucking-pig;
to the well fish is sacrificed.
Why is it that the King has a God of the Earth and of the Millet?
[They are the gods whom he can ask] for prosperity for the benefit of all under Heaven, and whom he can thank for their works.
Without land man would not [be able to] sustain himself,
without grain he would not [be able to] eat.
Land [, however,] is wide and extensive,
and cannot be worshipped everywhere.
The species of grain are too numerous,
and cannot be sacrificed to one by one.
Therefore a tumulus of earth is erected for an altar of the God of the Earth
in order to make manifest the holder of the earth.
Millet
is the most important of the species of grain.
Therefore an altar of the God of the Millet is erected,
to which sacrifices are made.
The use of millet
is most general
because it has absorbed the equi-balanced and harmonious influences of the yin and the yang.
Therefore it is considered the principal [of the species of grain].
Why are there two sacrifices [to the Gods of the Earth and of the Millet] in a year?
In spring [the sacrifice] means a request [for prosperity], in autumn it means a thanksgiving [for the received boon].
Therefore the Yuè lìng says: "In the middle month of spring
[the Son of Heaven] chooses a favourable day,
and orders the people to sacrifice to the God of the Earth.
In the middle month of autumn
he chooses a favourable day,
and orders the people to sacrifice to the God of the Earth".
The Yuán shén qì says:
"In the middle month of spring prayers are presented for the crops, in the middle month of autumn the corn is harvested.
Thanks are rendered to the God of the Earth, and a sarifice is offered to the God of the Millet".
Why is it that at the sacrifice to the Gods of the Earth and of the Millet three victims are used?
To emphasize [the gods'] merits.
The Shàng shū says:
"[The Duke of Zhōu] thereupon sacrificed
a bull,
a ram,
and a pig to the Gods of the Earth and of the Millet in the new city".
The Wáng zhì says:
"To the Gods of the Earth and of the Millet the Son of Heaven offers the 'great sacrifice' tài-láo,
the Feudal Lords offer the 'smaller sacrifice' shào-láo".
Why [is it that the Feudal Lords] offer the great sacrifice [to the ancestors] in the ancestral temple,
and only the smaller sacrifice to teh Gods of the Earth and of the Millet?
In the ancestral temple the great sacrifice is offered
to extend the feelings of filial piety;
to the Gods of the Earth and of the Millet thanks are rendered for their works.
But the things for which a Feudal Lord in his one state renders thanks are not numerous. That is the reason [why only the smaller sacrifice is given].
The Xiào jīng says:
"To preserve the Gods of the Earth and of the Millet and to secure the harmony of their people,
this is the filial piety of the Feudal Lords".
Why is it that the King and the Feudal Lords each have two altars of the God of the Earth?
Both are lords holding land.
Therefore
the Lǐ jì sān zhèng says:
"The King has two altars of the God of the Earth;
he erects one altar fro all under Heave, called the 'Great Altar of the God of the Earth' tài-shè,
and another for himself, called the 'King's Altar of the God of the Earth' wáng-shè.
The Feudal Lords erect for their Hundred Clans one altar, called the 'State's Altar of the God of the Earth' guó-shè,
and another for themselves, called the 'Feudal Lord's Altar of the God of the Earth 'hóu-shè'".
To the Great Altar thanks are offered for its works on behalf of all under Heaven.
To the King's Altar thanks are offered for its works on behalf of the capital.
The Great Altar is more honourable than the King's Altar.
The earth [, constituting all under Heaven,] is extensive,
therefore it is thanked [for its merits] at two [altars].
Why must the King and the Feudal Lords have a Warning God of the Earth?
To remind that there is preservation and loss,
and to indicate that those who do well will succeed
and those who do evil will fail.
Therefore the Chūn qiū gōng yáng zhuàn says:
"Of the God of the Earth of a vanquished state
the upper part is covered,
and round the lower part a pallissade is built".
The Jiāo tè shēng jì says:
"The God of the Earth of a vanquished state is roofed in".
It indicates that it is separated from [the influences of] Heaven and Earth.
[The Warning God is placed] east of the [second outer] gate [of the palace],
to indicate clearly that it has been lowered to a place where it has no [further] function [to perform].
Another opinion is:
it serves as a chear warning,
and should be in the vicinity of the Sovereign;
it is placed south of the enclosure of the ancestral temple.
The Lǐ says:
"The Gods of the Earth and of the Millet of a vanquished state
must be used as a screen for the ancestral temple".
It means that they are treated contemptuously.
Why is the altar of the Gods of the Earth and of the Millet outside the middle
and inside the outer gate [of the palace]?
To honour [the gods] and yet to be near to them.
They are [treated in] the same [way] as the ancestors.
Why [is the altar] not placed inside the middle gate?
To respect it,
and to indicate that one should not be too intimate with it.
The Lùn yǔ says:
"Taking as an illustration a palace with its enclosures:
if one cannot enter through the gates,
one does not see the beauties of the ancestral temple
and the wealth of all the offices".
The Jì yì says:
"To the right there is the altar of the Gods of the Earth and of the Millet,
to the left there is the ancestral temple".
A great officer who has people [to govern]
has an altar of the Gods of the Earth and of the Millet
that he also may thank them for their works [on behalf of his people].
The Lǐ jì fǎ says:
"A great officer, in association with the people who are under him, erects an altar of the Gods of the Earth and of the Millet, which is called the Official God of the Earth".
The Lùn yǔ says:
Jì-lù caused Zǐ-gāo to be appointed governor of Pi,
saying:
He will have people there [to govern],
he will have an altar of the Gods of the Earth and of the Millet there [to sacrifice to]".
Why [is the altar of the God of the Earth] not called tǔ 'Earth'?
A tumulus is made of earth to serve as [the altar of] the God of the Earth.
Therefore the name is [then] changed into shè,
to distinguish it from earth in general.
[After the altar of the God of the Earth is erected] an altar for sacrifices to the millet is made,
which is then called jì.
The expression is not changed,
signifying that there is an insider and an outside.
Another opinion is:
the shè-jì
is not to be [called] jì-shè.
Therefore, the name not being changed,
their functions may be known by themselves.
Why is it that a sacrifice is not offered to the God of the Millet in the first month [of the year]?
The reason for erecting an altar for its spirit
is because the millet is constantly available
[throughout the year] to serve as food for man.
Why is it that the altar of the God of the Earth has no roof?
To keep it in contact with the fluids of Heaven and Earth.
Therefore the Jiāo tè shēng says:
"The Great Altar of the Son of Heaven
must [be open to] receive the hoarfrost, the dew, the wind, and the rain,
so that it can be in contact with the fluids of Heaven and Earth".
Why is there a tree on the altar of the Gods of the Earth and of the Millet?
That it may [thereby] be honoured and recognized.
[Thus]
the people may see it from afar and worship it.
[The tree is] also the expression of [the god's beneficent] capacities.
Therefore the Zhōu guān says:
"The sī-tú builds the altar for the God of the Earth and plants a tree on it.
For each [God of the Earth he uses a tree which] suits the soil".
The Shàng shū yì piān says:
"For the Great Altar of the God of the Earth [the tree] is a pine-tree,
for the altars of the God of the Earth in the east it is a cypress,
for those of the God of the Earth in the south it is a catalpa,
for those of the God of the Earth in the west it is a chestnut,
and for those of the God of the Earth in the north it is an acacia".
Why does the King sacrifice in person to the Gods of the Earth and of the Millet?
The God of the Earth
is the spirit of the earth.
The earth lproduces the ten thousand things,
and is the host of all under Heaven.
Out of reverence for it
[the King] therefore sacrifices in person.
What is the size of the altar?
The Chūn qiū wén yì says:
"The altar of the Gods of the Earth and of the Millet of the Son of Heaven is fifty feet wide [on each side],
that of the Feudal Lords is one half thereof".
What is its colour?
The Chūn qiū zhuàn says:
"The Son of Heaven has a Great Altar;
it is green on the east,
red on the south,
white on the west,
black on the north.
The top is covered with yellow earth.
Thus, when [the Son of Heaven is] going to enfeoff a Feudal Lord [with a territory] in the east,
he takes [a clod of] green earth [from his altar],
wraps it in a white máo [leaf, and gives it to him].
For each [Feudal Lord receiving a fief the Son of Heaven] takes [earth] from the [corresponding] side [of his altar],
with which [the Feudal Lord] constructs the mound for his [own altar of the] God of the Earth.
It signifies that [that clod of] earth is to be revered for its purity."
Is music used at the sacrifice to the Gods of the Earth and of the Millet?
The Yuè jì says:
"Music [the instruments of which are] executed in metal and stone,
finding its expression in tunes and notes,
and used in the ancestral temple and at the altar of the Gods of the Earth and of the Millet".
The Zēng zǐ wèn says:
"If a Feudal Lord is sacrificing to the Gods of the Earth and of the Millet,
for which the stands and vessels have already been arranged,
and news arrives of the death of the Son of Heaven,
what is to be done?
Confucius says:
"[The sacrifice should be] discontinued".
When a subject is afflicted with sorrow
he dares not continue the rites [of sacrifice] to the end.
What do [the words] lǐ and yuè
mean?
Lǐ 'rites' means lǚ 'to tread';
to go [the way] which may be trodden.
Yuè 'music' means
lè 'to joy';
"the Noble Man rejoices when he has attained the [right] Way,
the small man rejoices when he has reached what he desired".
Why does the King perfect his rites and music?
To manifest his joy and anger in a regulated and cultivated way.
Music takes its image from Heaven,
rites model themselves on Earth.
All men contain in themselves the essence of Heaven and Earth,
and harbour the instinct for the Five Constant [Virtues].
Therefore music is that wherewith to incite [man]
to turn back from evil,
rites are that wherewith to curb licentiousness
and check prodigality.
Therefore the Xiào jīng says:
"For securing the repose of superiors and the good order of the people
there is nothing better than rites;
for changing their manners and altering their customs
there is nothing better than music".
The Master said:
"When in the ancestral temple
the ruler and his Ministers, the high and the lowly, listen together to the music,
there is none who is not in harmony and reverence;
when at the [gathering of the] heads of the kindred, and at the district- and village [-meetings],
old and young listen together to it,
there is none who is not in harmony and obedient accord;
when within the gate of the family
fathers and sons, elder brothers and younger brothers, listen together to it,
there is none who is not in harmony and affection.
Therefore in music emphasis
is laid upon harmony and obedient accord.
The [eight musical] instruments should be attuned to each other to embellish the divisions [of the melody],
while their rhythms are harmonezed to complete the elegance.
So
fathers and sons, rulers and Ministers, are united in harmony,
and the people of the myriad states are associated in love.
Such was the purpose of the Ancient Kings when they framed their music.
In listening to melodies of the yǎ and the sòng
the aims and thoughts receive an expansion.
When, holding the shield and war-axe,
one practises the looking-up and the looking-down, the bending and the strentching [of the body],
one's carriage receives composure.
When, in going to the places indicated at the pantomime,
one follows the rhythm [of the music]
the rows and arrays are formed correctly,
and the advancing and retreating get their proper order.
So music
is [the lesson] ordered by Heaven and Earth,
the director of harmony,
and that which the nature of man cannot dispense with.
And thus music was that
wherewith the Ancient Kings adorned their joy,
[just as] the army's host and the battle-axes
were the things wherewith [the Ancient Kings] adorned their anger.
Therefore the joy and the anger of the Ancient Kings
had both their accompaniments.
When they were joyful, all under Heaven were joyful with them;
when they were angry, the oppressive and disorderly feared them.
In the ways of the Ancient Kings
rites and music may be said to have attained perfection indeed".
There is none who, hearing the note jué,
does not feel compassion and act accordingly;
there is none who, hearing the note zhǐ,
does not rejoice in nourishing [the needy], and does not love bestowing [goodness];
there is none who, hearing the note shāng,
does not become strong and decided, and embark on enterprises;
there is none who, hearing the note yǔ,
does not deeply reflect and take precautionary measures against far-off [eventualities];
there is none who, hearing the note gōng,
does not become mild and liberal, and act beneficently and harmoniously.
Why do humbling oneself and yielding precedence to others belong to the rites?
To honour others and to efface oneself.
Humbling oneself and yielding precedence to others prevent strife.
The Lùn yǔ says:
"[A Noble Man] bows and gives precedence to the others when he ascends
and when he descends [the hall at the archery-competition] to join the drinking-bout.
In his contest he is still a Noble Man".
Thus "the Lord employs his subjects according to the [rules of] rites,
and the subjects serve their Lord with faithfulness".
"The Noble Man who adds humility to humility
may with profit cross the great stream".
"While noble, he humbles himself to the mean,
and grandly gains the people".
Humbling himself and honouring others
are the nature of the Noble Man.
Therefore Confucius says:
"Rites performed without reverence,
how should I regard such a thing?"
Rites
are the meeting-corner of the yin and the yang,
[the link] connecting all the affairs [of men],
that wherewith Heaven and Earth are revered,
the spirits are treated,
the order among the high and the lowly is maintained,
and the Way of man is kept straight.
Why must music [always be accompanied by] singing?
Singing
expresses through the mouth [the sentiments of man].
When he is gay in his heart he feels impelled to express it
through his mouth by singing,
through his hands by waving,
through his feet by dancing.
Therefore the Shàng shū says:
"In the front they sing, in the rear they dance;
[the sound] reaches [Heaven] above and [Earth] below".
Why is it that in rites value is given to equilibrium?
[The practise of] rites is to
fill out where there is an insufficiency,
and to moderate where there is a surplus,
so that in rich years there may be no extravagance,
in bad years no stint,
and wealth and poverty should not provide a constrast.
Why is it that in music the yǎ[-melody] is highly esteemed?
Yǎ2
anciently meant zhèng 'correct'.
[The yǎ-melody] therefore differs widely from the music of Zhèng.
Confucius says: "Why is the music of Zhèng licentious?
In the state of Zhèng the peasants live in the mountains,
and when they draw water in the valleys
men and women mix freely
and perform the music of Zhèng
to amuse one another.
Therefore the music of the depraved and mean
is always music of licentiousness and lust.
Why is it that only when general peace [has been restored after the establishement of a new Dynasty new] rites may be fashioned and [new] music be created?
Rites and music
are to curb prodigality and licentiousness.
When the people in all under Heaven are [still] suffering from hunger and cold,
how could there be [occasion for] enjoyment?
"[But] when the efforts [of the new Dynasty] have attained a successful end [new] music is created,
and when its government has been established [new] rites are fashioned".
Why is it that music is said to be created,
and rites are said to be fashioned?
Music
belongs to the yang;
in it the movements begin [from non-movement], and singing starts [from silence].
Therefore it is said to be created.
Rites
belong to the yin,
which is subordinately fashioned by the yang,
therefore they are said to be fashioned.
Music takes its image from the yang,
rites model themselves on the yin.
When a King has just assumed his Kingship
what does he apply to keep the people straight?
He temporarily uses the rites and music of the former Dynasty.
When in all under Heaven general peace [has been restored]
he fashions [the rites] and creates [music] anew.
The Shū says:
"[Let the King] at first employ the rites [of the Kings] of Yīn,
and sacrifice in the new city".
This means that only after general peace [had been fully restored] the rites of Yīn were abolished..
The Chūn qiū zhuàn says:
"Why is it [that sometimes the rites and music do] not conform to [those of] the nearest [previous Dynasty] but to [those of] the distant [Dynasty]?
Because [the distant Dynasty was an adherent of] the same [Principle of Form or Substance] as one's own,
[and its rites and music] can be followed as a precedent [in confirming] the general peace [in all under Heaven]".
It is necessary [for a new Dynasty] to fashion [and create] anew [the rites and music of its predecessor],
in order to indicate that it has not inherited [from it].
Besides, [the newly created music expresses] what all under Heaven rejouce in;
the music [expressing what they rejouce in],
being that by which form is given to the spiritual power [of a new Dynasty] and its achievement is manifested, differs [each time] by its name [from the music of previous Dynasties].
The Lǐ jì says:
"The music of Huáng-dì was called Xián-chí,
that of Zhuān-xū Lìu-heng,
that of Dì-kù Wǔ-yīng,
that of Yáo Dà-zhāng,
that of Shùn Xiāo-sháo,
that of Yǔ Dà-xià,
that of Tāng Dà-hù,
that of King Wǔ of Zhōu Xiàng,
that of the Duke of Zhōu Zhuó,
when united together the music of Zhōu was called Dà-wǔ".
The music of Huáng-dì was called Xián-chí,
meaning that [during his reign] the Way was greatly 'applied' shī to all under Heaven, and put into practise.
'Everything' shēng that was created by Heaven
and was borne by Earth
received the beneficent application of spiritual power.
The music of Zhuān-xū was called Lìu-heng,
meaning that in it the [six musical pitch-pipes] lǜ were in consonant use with the [other six pitch-pipes] lǚ, [thus] harmonizing the yin and the yang.
Heng 'stem'
is that by which the ten thousand things are made visible.
The music of Dì-kù was called Wǔ-yīng,
meaning that he was able to bring the Five Notes into harmony
in order to nourish the ten thousand things,
and harmonize their blossoming.
The music of Yáo was called Dà-zhāng,
meaning that he had greatly made illustrious the Way of Heaven, Earth, and Man.
The music of Shùn was called Xiāo-sháo,
meaning that he was able to continue the Way of Yáo.
The music of Yǔ was called Dà-xià,
meaning that Yǔ was able to follow and put into practise the Way of the two Sages [Yáo and Shùn].
Therefore it was called Dà-xià.
The music of Tāng was called Dà-hù,
meaning that when he received [the continuation of] the decaying [Empire]
he was able to meet the people's needs.
The music of the Duke of Zhōu was called Zhuó,
meaning that when the Duke of Zhōu assisted King Chéng
he was able to deliberate upon the Ways of [King] Wén
and [King] Wǔ, and bring them to completion.
The music of King Wǔ was called Xiàng,
meaning that it was made 'to represent' xiàng [the achievement of] general peace.
It was an expression of [the fact that] general peace was already [prevailing again].
When united together [the music of Zhōu was] called Dà-wǔ,
meaning that all under Heaven at last rejoiced when [the House of Zhōu] took up arms for the expedition [against the House of Yīn].
Therefore the poets
celebrated it in the song:
"King [Wén] rose majestic in his wrath,
and marshalled his troops".
At this time
all under Heaven rejoiced at the anger of King Wén [, who was going] to pacify all under Heaven.
Therefore they put his military [prowess] into music.
Why is it that the House of Zhōu composed the Xiàng music of all musics?
[King] Zhòu of Yīn had already long been indulging in his evil [deeds];
his wickedness was extreme,
he cut off [the feet of] persons walking [in the snow in the morning], he ripped open the wombs [of pregnant women],
he acted as a brigand through all under Heaven.
King Wǔ took up arms [against him,
and the soldiers were so rejoiced that they were] singing in the front and dancing in the rear [of his army].
After the Yīn [Dynasty] had been overcome
the people greatly rejoiced.
For that very reason [the Xiàng music was] composed to regulate their over-abundance of joy.
The Son of Heaven has eight rows of dancers,
the Feudal Lords have four,
so as to distinguish between the high and the lowly.
Music
belongs to the yang,
therefore it uses the [even] yin-number,
and models itself on the Eight Winds,
the Six Musical Pitch-pipes,
or the Four Seasons.
The Eight Winds
and the Six Pitch-pipes
[represent] the breath of Heaven,
they assist Heaven and Earth in bringing the ten thousand things to maturing.
Likewise music is that by which, in conformity with Heaven's breath,
the myriads of people are transformed and their lives perfected.
Therefore the Chūn qiū gōng yáng zhuàn says:
"The Son of Heaven has eight rows of dancers,
the Dukes [and Ducal Ministers] have six,
the Feudal Lords four".
The Shī1 zhuàn says:
"A great officer and a common officer have the qín and the sè [lutes] to play upon".
What is meant by
bā-yì 'eight rows of dancers'?
Yì
means liè 'row'.
Eight men form a row.
Eight [row of] eight [dancers] make sixty-four men.
The Dukes have six rows of six,
the Feudal Lords have four rows of four.
