By the Dukes are meant the Three Ducal Ministers and the descendants of the two Kings [of the previous two Dynasties].
Great officers and common officers are subjects who face north,
they have no right to employ people of their own accord;
therefore they have only [the right to use] the qín and the sè [lutes].
The King performs the Six Musics [of the previous Dynasties]
to honour their achievements and to extol their spiritual power.
To continue the performance of the music of the former Kings
at his sacrifices
means that there is a modal,
and that the orgins should not be forgotten;
the performance of the music which he has himself created
is to show his own accomplishment.
Why [does the King] perform the music of the Four Barbarian Tribes?
That his spiritual power may be extended to them.
The Yì says:
"The Ancient Kings [, in imitation of the thunder issuing from the earth as this is depicted in the Yu hexagram,] composed their music and did honour to its spiritual power,
presenting it most grandly to the Lord on High,
when they associated with Him [at the service] their first ancestor [Hou-zhi] and their father [King Wén]".
The Shī says:
"The drums and resound harmonious and loud,
to delight our meritorious ansestor [Tāng]".
The Yuè yuán yǔ says:
"When [the King has] received the mandate [of Heaven he performs] the six musical dances;
the performance of the music of the Ancient Kings
indicates that there is a modal [to follow];
the performance of that which he has himself created
indicates that he has his [own] fashion;
the performance of the music of the Four Barbarian Tribes
means that his spiritual power has been extended to them".
Thus the music of the eastern barbarians is called zhāo-lí,
that of the southern barbarians is called nán,
that of the western barbarians is called wèi （味）,
and that of the borthern barbarians is called jìn/
When enjoying together music and dancing in the hall [of the ancestral temple]
the musicians of the Four Barbarian Tribes are seated at the right [outside the gate].
That wherewith the King has acquired [his kingship is, in the performance of his music,] put first in order to conform with the mandate [he holds], and to emphasize the beginning [of his rise].
That the King's music has a first and a later [part] is because in either [part] its [characteristic] spiritual power isbrought forward.
This means that if [a King] has attained [his kingship] by civil [means] the civil [part of the performance] is executed first,
that is a dance with feathers and plumes held [in the hands];
if he has attained [his kingship] by military prowess the martial [part of the performance] is executed first,
that is a dance with shields and lances held [in the hands].
The Yuè yuán yǔ says:
"With the music of the eastern barbarians there is a dance with spears held [in the hands]
to aid the seasonal growth.
With the music of the southern barbarians there is a dance with feathers held [in the hands]
to aid the seasonal nurture.
With the music of the western barbarians there is a dance with halberds held [in the hands]
to aid the seasonal decay.
With the music of the northern barbarians there is a dance with shields held [in the hands]
to aid the seasonal rest".
Who instituted the music of the barbarians?
The Ancient Sage-kings.
When the Ancient Kings had promoted and exercised the spiritual power [proceeding from their possession] of the Way,
when they had harmonized the yin and the yang,
and overwhelmed the barbarians [with their beneficence],
these barbarians peacefully and joyfully
paid their court-visits to the Middle State,
and on this [occasion] the music was made to amuse them.
Nán [, the music of the southern barbarians,] means rèn 'to be in charge of';
to be in charge of nourishing the ten thoudand things.
Wèi [, the music of the western barbarians,] means mèi 'obscure';
mèi
expresses the decaying and ageing of the ten thoudand things;
it takes its meaning from [the idea of] 'obscurity' huì-mèi.
Jìn [, the music of the northern barbarians,]
means that the ten thoudand things have 'retired and hidden themselves' jìn-cáng.
Zhāo-lí [, the music of the eastern barbarians,]
means that the ten thousand things, [though still] tiny, 'leave' lí the [covering] earth to begin to grow.
Another opinion is:
For the eastern region [there is a dance with] spears held [in the hands],
for the southern region a song is sung,
for the western region [there is a dance with] lances held [in the hands],
for the northern region a gong is beaten.
The barbarians were primitive
and did not attain the [height of] culture of the Middle State.
They only called [their music] after the names of the instruments,
therefore [these names were] not changed throughout the Dynasties.
Why is it that the King fashions music for the barbarians,
but not fashion their rites?
Because rites
are performed with [the accompaniment of certain] movements of the body,
which the barbarians
will not be able to execute,
[whereas] their music
has been created by the Sages for the sole purpose of amusing them.
Therefore there is the music of the barbarians.
who are to execute the dances?
Men of the Middle State are employed [for it].
Why is it said so?
It is feared that the barbarians, being ignorant in [the matter of] rites,
will commit mistakes [in the performance].
Why [is the music of the barbarians] performed outside the gate [of the ancestral temple]?
The barbarians are seated outside [the temple],
therefore [their music is] brought near to them.
The barbarians have no [knowledge of] ritual behaviour,
and are not permitted within.
The MI2ng táng jì says:
"The [chiefs of the] states of the Nine Barbarian Tribes
are outside the eastern gate".
Thus we know that they are not inside the gate.
[Again] the Míng táng jì says:
"They introduce the music of the eastern and southern barbarians into the ancestral temple".
The use of the word 'introduce'
indicates that there are [special cases when the barbarians are allowed] insider.
It is asked: what does [the expression] 'Music of the Four Barbarian Tribes'
mean?
[The reply is:] the Four Barbarian tribes comprise those outside regions which are without knowledge of ritual rules.
The enumeration of these barbarian tribes begins with the east,
therefore the beginning is taken as their generic name.
When the expression yí-dí is used,
the beginning and the end [of the enumeration] are emphasized.
The expression mán
is used to emphasize their 'distancy' yuǎn;
the expression mò
is used to emphasize their 'cruelty' è.
When they have to be distinguished
[the barbarians of] the eastern region are called the Nine yí,
[those of] the southern region are called the Eight mán,
[those of] the western region are called the Six róng,
[those of] the northern region are called the Five dí.
Therefore the Zēng zǐ wèn says:
"The Nine yí,
the Eight mán,
the Six róng,
and the Five dí
are the greatest sore to the Hundred Clans [of the Middle State]".
How do we know that the yí[-barbarians] lived in the east?
The Wáng zhì says:
"The [barbarians of the] eastern region are called yí,
they wear their hair loose, and tattoo their bodies".
It further says:
"The [barbarians of the] southern region are called mán,
they tattoo their foreheads, and sleep with crossed legs.
[Those of] the western region are called róng,
they wear their hair loose, and are clad in skins.
[Those of] the northern region are called dí,
they are clad in feathers and fur,
and dwell in caves".
Why has the east
nine [barbarian tribes]?
Because [the number of] those who have come and crossed [the frontiers] amounts to nine.
Jǐu 'nine' means jīu 'profound';
the [King's] spiritual power is ubiquitous and profound;
therefore, responding to this power, [the eastern barbarians] also come in [the profound number of] nine.
It is not a course of affairs brought about on purpose,
but it has naturally [so developed that nine tribes have come].
Why [are the barbarians] named yí, mán [, and so on]?
Since the Sage-kings in princple do not regulate the outer regions
they do not devise names for them.
When they speak of them they only follow the [existing] names of their countries.
Another opinion is:
They devise a name for them according to what [each of the barbarian tribes] falls short of.
[So] yí means
zūn-yí 'to squat'; [squatting indicates] a lack of propriety.
[Or,] the east
is the region where the yang is tender, so that it is 'easy' yí to reform;
the name [of yí] is therefore taken [from it].
Mán means
'to be bent on wickedness and evil'.
Róng means
'to be oppressive and cruel'.
Dí means
'easy-going';
[the dí-barbarians are] depraved, easy-going and promiscuous;
in the north the elder yin
[causes] meanness and frugality;
therefore [the opportunities are] few and [the region is] difficult to reform.
Why are the singers seated on the platform in the hall
while the dancing [takes place] below it?
The song gives form to the spiritual power [of the King],
the dance gives form tois prowess.
A Noble Man puts his spiritual power first and his prowess afterwards.
The Jiāo tè shēng says:
"The singers are above [on the platform]".
The Lùn yǔ says:
"The Jì family had eight rows of dancers dancing in the space below the raised platform in the hall".
The Shū says:
"Below there are the flutes, hand-drums.
drums, calabash organs, and bells, all filling up the intervals".
Why is the music for inviting down the spirits [of the deceased forefathers] placed upon [the platform]?
To elevate it on behalf of the spirits.
Therefore the Shū says:
"When [the chu was] struck to start [the orchestra] or [the yu] to stop it, when the jade chiming-stone [was sounded],
and the bó-fǔ and the qín and sè [lutes were played to] accompany the singing,
[the spirits of] the first ancestor and the father arrived".
Why are the chiming-stone, the bó-fǔ [, and the lutes] used?
The spirits, being pure and invisible,
like calm
and dislike twanging.
Therefore the Shàng shū dà zhuàn says:
"The bó-fǔ is a drum
filled with bran,
the qín and sè [lutes have] purely boiled red silk strings,
the chiming [-stone is used]
out of esteem for the sound of the jade [-stone]".
Why is it that when the King takes his meals music is played?
He is pleased [at being able] to enjoy general peace in all under Heaven
and at the abundance of accumulated wealth.
It means that the Son of Heaven, being most exalted,
does not take food when he has not accomplished [his task],
neither does he eat to repletion when his spiritual power has not [manifested itself to the full].
Therefore the Zhuàn says:
"The Son of Heaven has music performed
at the times of his meals".
Why does the King take four [complete] meal daily?
It indicates that he has [at his disposal] the produce of the four quarters
and the yields of the four seasons.
If the four quarters are not in peace,
and the four seasons are out of order,
then he applies the rule of 'clearing away the aliments',
by which is meant that the Most Exalted
has proclaimed the prescribed fast.
Quietly the King sits in the centre
and manages the four quarters.
At dawn he takes his meal:
it is the inception of the younger yang.
In the afternoon he takes his meal:
it is the inception of the elder yang.
In the afternoon he takes his meal:
it is the inception of the younger yin.
In the evening he takes his meal:
it is the inception of the elder yin.
The Lùn yǔ says:
"Gān, [the band-master] at the second meal, went to Chǔ;
Liáo, [the band-master] at the third meal, went to Cài;
Quē, [the band-master] at the fourth meal, went to Qín".
The Feudal Lords take three [complete] meals [a day],
the Ministers and great officers two,
so as to distinguish between the high and the lowly.
The Dì zǐ zhí says:
"It is the common officer,
who again applies the rites [observed at the morning-meal] to the evening-meal".
"[The common man] who earns his living by his labour is not limited in the number [of his meals]".
The task of the common man is to plough or to gather mulberry-leaves,
exhausting his strength and exerting himself laboriously.
When he is hungry he eats,
when he has had enough he works again;
therefore there is no limit to the number [of his meals].
What
do shēng and yīn mean?
Shēng 'note' means
míng 'to sound';
hearing the note we know what has produced it.
Yīn means
yǐn 'to swallow';
it means that the hard and the soft, the sharps and the flats
are harmonized and have swallowed each other.
The Shàng shū says:
"I wish to hear the Six Pitch-pipes, the Five Notes, and the Eight Kinds of Instrumental Music".
What
are the Five Notes?
[They are:] gōng, shāng, jué, zhǐ, and yǔ.
Earth may be said [to corresponds to the note] gōng,
metal to shāng,
wood to jué,
fire to zhǐ,
water to yǔ.
The Yuè lìng says:
"Its perfect spiritual power is in wood,
its note is jué".
It futher says:
"Its perfect spiritual power is in fire,
its note is zhǐ;
its perfect spiritual power is in metal,
its note is shāng;
its perfect spiritual power is in water,
its note is yǔ".
Why [is the note] called jué?
Jué means
yuè 'to leap';
the yang-fluid stirs and leaps.
Zhǐ means
zhǐ 'to stop';
the yang-fluid has stopped.
Shāng means
zhāng 'to expand';
the yin-fluid begins to expand
[while] the yang-fluid begins to contract.
Yǔ means
yū 'to twist';
the yin-fluid is above,
the yang-fluid is below.
Gōng means
róng 'to contain';
hán 'to hold';
it contains and holds the four seasons.
What
are the Eight Kinds of Instrumental Music?
The Yuè jì says:
"[The music produced by the instrument made of] clay is called xūn 'occarina',
[that produced by the instrument made of] bamboo is called guǎn 'flute',
[that produced by the instrument made of] hide is called gǔ 'drum',
[that produced by the instrument made of] the gourd is called shēng 'pan-pipes',
[that produced by the instrument made of] silk is called xián 'harp',
[that produced by the instrument made of] stone is called qìng 'chiming-stone',
[that produced by the instrument made of] metal is called zhōng 'bell',
[that produced by the instrument made of] wood is called zhù and yǔ".
They are called the Eight Kinds of Instrumental Music
[because] they model themselves on the Eight Trigrams of the Yì,
and [follow] the number of the ten thousand things;
the Eight Kinds of Instrumental Music
[represent] the sounds of the ten thousand things.
Why [does the Son of Heaven] use the Eight Kinds of Instrumental Music?
The Son of Heaven, in aiding the ten thousand things to multiply,
ought to know their number,
and knowing their number
ought to know their sounds;
after which he reflects on their shapes.
When, in this way,
[even to] the flying of the insects and the wriggling of the worms there is no sound which he does not enjoy,
his spiritual power has reached its perfection.
The Son of Heaven finds his joy in them,
therefore in his music he uses the Eight Kings of Instrumental Music.
The Yuè jì says:
"The occarina
[produces] music [which corresponds with the trigram] kǎn;
the flute music
[corresponding with the trigram] kěn;
the drum music
[corresponding with the trigram] zhèn;
the harp music
[corresponding with the trigram] lí;
the bell music
[corresponding with the trigram] duì;
the zhù and the yǔ music
[corresponding with the trigram] qián".
The xūn 'occarina' [is an instrument which it is proper to use] in the eleventh month.
Xūn means xūn 'to rise as steam';
the yang-fluid under the yellow sources rises as steam to germinate.
Páo 'gourd' means shī 'to extend',
yá 'to sprout out';
in the twelfth month
the ten thousand things begin to extend and sprout out.
The shēng 'pan-pipes'
produces air of the [pitch-pipe] tài-cù,
it represents the 'growing' shēng of the ten thousand things.
and is therefore called shēng.
It has [seven] regulating [pipes corresponding with] the Seven Regulating Celestial Bodies,
and [six] harmonizing [pipes corresponding with] the Six Points of the Compass;
all under Heaven rejoice in it,
therefore it is called shēng.
The gǔ 'drum'
[produces] a rolling sound of thunder
[following upon] an atmosphere of distress.
When the ten thousand things are in dire plight they are shaken into motion,
the thunder moves them,
the heat gives them warmth,
the wind disperse them,
and the rain moistens them.
[The drum] rouses [a sound announcing] the greatest bliss,
it moves to an air of harmony and tranquillity.
The same sounds reverberate upon each other,
the same airs solicit each other.
Spirits and enlightened beings respond to them,
Heaven and Earth come to aid them,
does not then their origin lie at the inception of the ten thousand things?
Therefore [the drum is] called gǔ 'stimulator'.
The tao 'handdrum'
[also belongs to] the sphere of [the trigram] zhèn.
Above it corresponds with the 'Pleiades' mǎo-xīng,
so as to be in communication with the 'Kingly Way' wáng-dào;
therefore it is called tao.
The xiāo 'bamboo-flute'
[produces] the air of the [pitch-pipe] zhōng-lǚ.
The ten thousand things originate from the soundless,
and become visible out of the formless.
[Xiāo means] liu 'to unite',
sù 'reverential';
therefore [the bamboo-flute is] called xiāo.
The xiāo
has its base in [the idea of] 'prosperity' lù,
meaning that it aids Heaven in the multiplication of things, [thus] providing the people with a base.
When human power is added to the natural processes of the Earth,
there is a transformation,
after which the ten thousand things unite [all their strength].
Therefore [the bamboo-flute is] called xiāo.
Sè 'multi-stringed lute' means
sè 'to moderate',
xián 'to bar out'.
With it anger is restrained, passions are curbed,
man's spiritual power is kept straight.
Therefore there is the saying:
"The sè [lute secures] the moderation of the Lord and father,
and the rules for the subject and son".
If Lord and father observe moderation,
and subject and son know their duties,
the four seasons will be in harmony;
if the four seasons are in harmony the ten thousand things will have their growth [unimpeded].
Therefore [the multi-stringed lute is] called sè.
Qín 'five-stringed lute' means
jìn 'to stop'.
With it depravity and licentiousness are stopped
and man's heart is kept straight.
The qìng 'chiming-stone'
[produces] the air of the [pitch-pipe] yí-zé;
it represents the maturing of the ten thousand things.
This air is 'distinct' qìng,
therefore it is called qìng.
There are the high and the lowly,
the nearly related and the distantly related,
the old and the young;
[according to] the rites at the court-audience
the high do not give precedence to the lowly,
so as to distinguish between the honourable and the humble;
[according to] the rites in the village society
the old do not give precedence to the young,
so as to make clear that there is [distinction in] years;
[according to] the rites in the ancestral temple
the nearly related do not give precedence to the distantly related,
so as to make clear that there is [distinction in] affinity.
If these three [principles] are observed
the Kingly Way will be achieved.
If the Kingly Way is achieved
the ten thousand things will attain their maturity.
All under Heaven rejoice in it,
therefore in music the 'distinct chiming-stone' qìng is used.
Zhōng 'bell' means dòng 'to move'.
When the yin-fluid holds sway
the ten thousand things are moved to maturing.
The bell uses for its air
the sound of metal.
The bó 'large bell'
[produces] a sound [which represents] the air of the seasons,
by which rules and patterns come into being.
If [in the relation] between Lord and subject there are rules the ten thousand things will bloom,
if there are no rules the ten thousand things will decay.
Bloom and decay are 'close upon one another's heels' pò,
therefore [the large bell is] called bó.
The zhù and the yǔ
[produce the] sounds [which represent] the end and the beginning,
that by which the ten thousand things come into being.
The yin and the yang succeed and follow upon each other.
Therefore there is the saying: "The zhù
assists and conforms to Heaven and Earth
that the ten thousand things may be welcomed in orderly [succession]".
All under Heaven rejoice in it,
therefore in [the King's] music the zhù is used.
The zhù
[marks] the beginning [of the orchestra],
the yǔ
the end.
Another opinion says:
[With respect to the order of the regional correspondences of] the shēng, the zhù, the gǔ, the xiāo, the qín, the xūn, the zhōng, and the qìng
the shēng corresponds with the north,
the zhù with the north-east,
the gǔ with the east,
the xiāo with the south-east,
the qín with the south,
the xūn with the south-west,
the zhōng with the west,
the qìng with the north-west.
Why is it that there are five notes,
but eight kinds of instrumental music?
The 'notes' shēng form the basis
and originate from the Five Elements.
The [eight kinds of] 'instrumental music' yīn form the end
and represent the Eight Winds.
So the Yuè jì says:
"When notes are combined so as to form a harmonious whole [we have] what is called instrumental music".
[Thus] we know that when we rejoice in [executing together these eight kinds of] instrumental music [we have] what is called 'music'.
It is asked:
When different opinions are indiscriminately put into practice
may not pupils be thereby brought into confusion?
Confucius had a saying:
"I have heard that to pick out what is good and follow it,
to see much and take due note of it,
is the lower [of the two kinds of] knowledge".
"The Way of [the Kings] Wén and Wǔ
has never yet utterly fallen to the ground".
"If Heaven had really intended that such culture as this should disappear [a latter day mortal would never have been able to link himself to it as I have done]".
"Without looking for it I find happiness to boot".
The Way of the Sage
is to use refinement and simplicity
with which to give significance to his words.
Transmitting what one has heard [of the Sage's words]
one should also, for each case, only hand down what one has received.
Why does the King appoint three Ducal Ministers and nine Ministers?
Heaven, however divine,
must depend on the light of sun and moon;
Earth, however potent,
must have the erosive influence of mountains and rivers;
a Sage, though possessing the spiritual power of ten thousand men,
needs the aid of able and worthy men,
[namely] the three Ducal Ministers,
the nine Ministers,
the twenty-seven great officers,
and the eighty-one common officers,
with whom, in conformity with Heaven, [he can] make his way complete.
The sī-mǎ supervises the army,
the sī-tú supervises the people,
the sī-kōng supervises the earth.
When a King has received the mandate [of Heaven] he has the task of [regulating the affairs which pertain to] Heaven, Earth, and Man.
Therefore he divides his task by appointing three Ducal Ministers,
each supervising one [part of it],
so as to make his work efficient.
One Ducal Minister appoints three Ministers,
so that there are nine Ministers.
The Way of Heaven everywhere perfects itself in [the number of] three.
Heaven has the Three Luminary Bodies:
the sun, the moon, and the stars;
Earth has the Three Configurations:
high, low, and level;
man has the Three Elevated Positions:
Lord, father, and teacher.
Therefore one Ducal Minister
has three Ministers to assist him;
one Minister
has three great officers to assist him;
one great officer
has three common officers to assist him.
[In the same way as] Heaven only with the help of the Three Luminary Bodies
can everywhere shed its illumination,
[so] the model of three applies to each [of them].
Things reach their completion after three [stages]:
they have a beginning,
a middle,
and an end,
meaning that [therewith] the Way of Heaven has reached its termination.
The three Ducal Ministers,
the nine Ministers,
the twenty-seven great officers,
and the eighty-one common officers
form together one hundred and twenty officers,
corresponding, below, with the Twelve Earthly Stems.
The Bié míng jì says:
"The sī-tú has control over the people,
the sī-kōng supervises Earth,
the sī-mǎ conforms himself to Heaven".
Heaven is the dispenser of life,
why is it that the sī-mǎ has the command over the army?
The army is [for cases] where plans are made to clear away disturbances,
so that the life [of the people] may be preserved
and their living may be safeguarded.
Therefore the army is said [to reside under] Heaven;
it has as its task the abolishment of disturbances,
[of which] bandits, rebels, as well as ferocious beasts [, may be regarded as examples].
The Lún yǔ says:
"When in all under Heaven the Way plrevails,
then rites, music, and punitive expeditions proceed from the Son of Heaven".
Though the sī-mǎ is the head of the army the word bīng 'arms'
is not used [in the term], but the word mǎ 'horse',
the horse
is a creature belonging to the yang,
that by which the male principle is motivated.
Though, indeed, arms are used,
[words bearing the connotation of] hurting and wounding are not used in the term,
and mǎ is therefore employed.
The sī-tú supervises the people.
That the word rén 'people' is not used [in the term], but tú,
is because tú means
zhòng 'multitude',
and importance is attached to the multitudes of people.
Though the sī-kōng has supervision over the 'earth' tǔ
the word tǔ is not used [in the term], but kōng,
because kōng 'the empty' still [being considered as] supervising,
how much more [would it be the case] with the full [earth;
it is a case of] bringing out the importance [of the whole] by means of a minute detail.
Since the appointment by the King of three Ducal Ministers,
nine Ministers,
and twenty-seven great officers
is sufficient to teach the Way and to illumine the dark and hidden,
why is it then still necessary to enfeoff Lords?
It is [a sign of] the utmost regard for the people.
When good and evil are compared it is easy to know [the difference].
Thus [the King] selects the worthy and gives them fiefs,
that in governing the people
they may display their spiritual power
and use their abilities to the utmost.
Above they pay homage to the Son of Heaven
and see to the safeguarding of the frontiers.
Below they nourish the Hundred Clans as their children,
practising right principles
and opening the road for the worthy.
They observe humility and shun self-righteous deeds.
Therefore [the King] divides the land to enfeoff his worthy,
and, by so doing, he sets them up as models [to be imitated];
to set the worthy up as models [to be imitated means] paying attention to the people.
Whatdoes zhōu-bó mean?
Bó means zhǎng 'chief'.
[The King] selects [from among] the worthy and capable [Lords] one
to act as Chief over one 'province' zhōu;
he is then called bó.
The Wáng zhì says:
"[For the government of the territory] outside the thousand lǐ [comprising the domain of the Son of Heaven two] 'Regional Chiefs' fāng-bó are appointed.
Five principalities form a shǔ,
governed by a zhǎng;
ten principalities form a lián,
governed by a shuài;
thirty principalities form a zú,
governed by a zhèng;
two hundred and ten principalities form together a 'province' zhōu
governed by a bó".
Why [was this Chief] under [Yáo of] Táng
and [Shùn of] Yǘ called mù 'Shepherd'?
[Yáo and Shùn] honoured [the Principle of] Substance;
they sent their great officers to go and 'shepherd' the Feudal Lords.
Therefore they were called Shepherds.
For [each of the four] quarters three men were appointed [as Shepherds],
so that there were in all twelve.
The Shàng shū says:
"[Shùn] consulted with the Twelve Shepherds".
How do we know that in the time of Yáo [the country was divided into] twelve provinces?
Because the Yǔ gòng speaks of the Nine Provinces.
The King appoints two [Regional] Chiefs because,
in delegating the government to them,
he wishes to attain the greatest efficiency by dividing their task.
The Wáng zhì says:
"The eight [Procincial] Chiefs, with those under them, were all under the two Ancients of the Son of Heaven,,
who divided all under Heaven between them, [one having charge of the regions] on the left, and [the other of those] on the right
and were called the two Regional Chiefs".
The Shī says:
"Young and tender is this sweet pear-tree;
do not lop it or knock it,
for [the Chief of the West,] the Lord of Shào took shelter under it".
The Chūn qiū gōng yáng zhuàn says:
"For the regions east of Shǎn
the Duke of Zhōu was the Chief,
for those west of Shǎn
the Lord of Shào was the Chief".
Why [was the country] not divided into north and south?
The eastern regions had only recently undergone the influence of the Sages,
while the western regions had already long been subjected to that influence.
So a division was made into east and west,
and the sage [Duke of Zhōu] appointed to supervise the difficult [regions],
while the worthy [Duke of Shào] was appointed to supervise the easy [regions].
In this way both brought peace [to their territories].
Besides, it was desired that [the two regions] should have the same share in the rhythm of the yin and the yang, and of cold and heat,
and together partake in [the same] laws and measures.
The partition-line in Shǎn
divided the country into two halves,
Speaking of its surface
[each half contained] eight hundred and forty principalities.
The reason for the Feudal Lords having three Ministers
is the division of three [governmental] tasks;
[the reason for their having only] five great officers is [the desire] to keep below [the number of those of] the Son of Heaven.
The Wáng zhì says:
"A large [Feudal] State has three Ministers,
all appointed by the Son of Heaven;
there are [further] five great officers of the second rank
and twenty-seven common officers of the first rank.
The next largest [Feudal] State has three Ministers,
of whom two are appointed by the son of Heaven
and one by his [own] ruler.
A small principality has two Ministers,
both appointed by their [own] ruler.
As to the great officers [and the common officers, their number is] the same".
The Lǐ Wáng dù jì says:
"Viscounts and Barons have three Ministers,
of whom one is appointed by the Son of Heaven".
The fief of a Feudal Lord does not exceed [a territory of] one hundred lǐ [square],
to symbolize the hundred lǐ within which the sound of thunder can be heard.
Thunder
is the yang within the yin,
and the Feudal Lord takes his image from it.
The Feudal Lord, in comparision with the King, is the yin.
[But, as he is himself a ruler who] faces south and bestows rewards and punishments, he is [also] the yang.
So he models himself on the thunder.
The [fiefs of] seventy lǐ
and [of] fifty lǐ [square]
indicate the difference in spiritual power and merit [of the holders].
Therefore the Wáng zhì says:
"Of the nine provinces within the four seas
[each] province is one thousand lǐ square,
and there are established in it thirty states of one hundred lǐ,
sixty of seventy lǐ,
one hundred and twenty of fifty lǐ.
The famous hills and great swamps are not included in the investitures;
the rest [of the land] forms sub-fiefs and unoccupied country".
The Son of Heaven occupies [a territory of] one thousand lǐ square.
[The whole country consists of] three thousand [lǐ square] of level country,
and together with the numerous cities, habitations,
mountains, and rivers [the area] comprises five thousand lǐ [square].
The famous hills and great swamps are not given as fiefs
because they are shared with the Hundred Clans [as common property],
and no state is allowed to have exclusive rights to them.
Of the abundance of the mountain-trees
and the advantages of the water-sources
one thousand lǐ is for public use,
so as to level out [the inequalities between] those who have and those who have not,
and to assist those who have not enough.
Why is the ground parcelled out in three grades?
In imitation of the soil having [the three divisions in] first, second, and third class [qualities].
The first thing the King does after his accession to the throne
is to give fiefs to the worthy
because he is anxious about the pressing needs of the people.
Therefore the division of the land into principalities is not for the sake of the Feudal Lords,
neither is the institution of administrative offices and bureaux for the sake of the Ministers and great officers.
It is all for the benefit of the people.
The Yì says:
"[There will be advantage in] appointing Feudal Lords".
This means that they are appointed [with the purpose of] following what gives advantage [to the people].
The Yuè jì says:
"After King Wǔ had overcome the Yīn he returned to [the capital of] Shāng,
and, descending his chariot, he gave to the descendants of the Xià Dynasty to the fief of Qǐ,
while he moved the descendants of the Yīn Dynasty to Sòng.
He erected a tumulus on the grave of the [Yīn] King's son Bǐ-gān,
and released the Viscount of Qí from his imprisonment".
[When the King,] after general peace has been established in all under Heaven,
gives fiefs to his relatives,
it is a sign of his unselfishness.
Since he is unselfish, why does he enfeoff them?
"Under the wide heaven
there is no land which is not the King's;
of all the guests on the earth there is none who is not the King's subject".
After the multitudes within the seas have completely come under his command
he cannot bear to leave his relatives without foothold.
To enfeoff them at the same time [as the worthy]
is [the expression of] the principle of loving one's relatives.
According to the Shàng shū Kāng-shū was enfeoffed
after [he ahd helped to restore] peace [in the empire].
After the King has begun his reign
he gives fiefs to his paternal uncles and his brothers,
which means that, as it is his duty to share his wealth with them,
he ought also to share the land with them.
Another opinion is:
the paternal uncles are not enfeoffed.
[A man is] enfeodded as a Hereditary Lord of a state to reward him for his merits,
and that his worthiness may be held up as an example [to his descendants] for the benefit of the people.
The sons and grandsons of [such] a worthy are mostly classed as worthies [themselves].
Likewise a Minister has no hereditary position
because he is not [required] to love the Hundred Clans as his children.
In each case he is rewarded for his merits,
that he may enjoy happiness during his life.
The reason why [the King,] after receiving his mandate, does not enfeoff his son
is because father and son are like hands and feet, which cannot be separated, so that there should be no division of property.
Brothers [, however,] represent a branching off from the main body,
therefore [they may be] enfeoffed.
So Shùn gave to his younger brother Xiàng the territory of Yǒu-bǐ as a fief.
Why does the enfeoffing of the Feudal Lords take place in summer?
The yang-fluid has [then] reached its fullness of nourishing power;
therefore the enfeoffment of the Feudal Lord
[means] the promotion of the worthy to its fullness.
By enfeoffing and establishing Lords of men
the fullness of the yang-spiritual power [of the King] is reached.
The Yuè lìng says:
"In the first month of summer
[the Son of Heaven] distributes rewards
and gives fiefs to the Feudal Lords.
Congratulations and presents are dealt out,
and there is none who is not pleased and happy".
Why is it said that Feudal Lords are appointed in a hereditary position?
Because they are appointed in order that [their descendants] may imitate their worthiness.
Why do not the great officers have a hereditary position?
Because they are servants [forming] the legs and arms [of their master], and are [only] employed in service.
To give them autonomous power and independent authority [by making their positions hereditary]
would upset the state's household.
It is also said:
[they have] the duty of yielding [their positions to the more capable];
it is a precautionary measure [against the event that] those who are unfit to assist in the task of the government
should block the [way for the really] worthy.
Therefore the position [of a great officer] is not hereditary.
So the Chūn qiū gōng yáng zhuàn says:
"[The Chūn qiū] condemns a Minister
having a hereditary position
because it is against the rites".
According to what rule
do the Feudal Lords hold hereditary positions,
whereas the great officers do not?
It is because the Feudal Lord is a ruler, facing south;
he practises the yang, which he embodies;
the Way of the yang is unbroken.
The great officer is a servant of man, facing north;
he practises the yin, which he embodies;
the Way of the yin is broken.
When a son is born he is turned [towards the] inside [of the house]
because it is his duty to remain in the family;
when a daughter is born she is turned [towards the] outside
because it is her duty to follow her husband.
This is in imitation of the yang being unbroken
and the yin being broken.
The reason why the Heir is appointed during the [life of the ruler of a] state
is to prevent usurpation and murder,
and to debar Ministers and sons from insurrection.
The Chūn qiū considers
the murder of the Heir
a similar crime to the murder of the ruler.
The Chūn qiū says:
"[Li K'o, an officer of Jìn?,] mudered Xī-qí, the son of the ruler",
meaning [that the murder is regarded as]
similar to the murder of the ruler.
When a ruler dies,
and his Principal Spouse has no sons
but is pregnant,
why must the appointment [of the Heir] wait until she is delivered of child?
To honour the principal wife and to emphasize the correct [succession].
The Zēng zǐ wèn says:
"Why is the appointment of an Heir from [among the sons of] the plrincipal wife determined by seniority in age, and not by worthiness?
It means that whether a man will prove to be worthy or unworthy cannot be known".
The Shàng shū says:
"Even for Emperor [Yáo]
it was difficult [to know men]".
The appointment of an Heir [from among the other sons] is determined by rank and not by seniority,
in order to prevent [strife arising from] love and jealousy.
The Chūn qiū zhuàn says:
"The appointment of an Heir from [among the sons of] the principal wife is determined by seniority and not by worthiness,
that from among the other sons by rank and not by seniority".
Why is it that when a Feudal Lord who has been enfeoffed for the first time dies without sons
it is not allowed to pass [the fief] over to his brothers?
Because of old [the idea of enfeoffment is that the son may] imitate the worthy [father],
and a brother does not directly descend from the worthy.
The Chūn qiū zhuàn says:
"[The duty of] treating the good with goodness is extended to the sons and grandsons".
It is not said that it is extended to the brothers
because brothers have the same honourable [status],
and are not in duty bound to support and maintain each other.
Brothers do not succeed one another.
But when a Feudal Lord who has succeeded to the fief
has no sons,
[the succession] may be extended to his [other] relatives
because they are all regarded as the descendants of [the same] worthy [ancestor].
It is to honour the merits of the first ancestor,
therefore [the succession] may be extended to them.
When such a Feudal Lord has no sons
and no younger brothers
but only paternal uncles and elder brothers born of a secondary wife,
to whom should [the succession] be given?
To an elder brother born of a secondary wife,
being the next of kin.
So Duke Xī had the right to succeed Duke Mǐn [of Lǔ].
The Lǐ fú zhuàn says:
"Since [the succession of] a Major Lineage may not be discontinued,
why is it allowed to take a person from the same lineage [as the Major] to be adopted as the continuer [of this Major Lineage]?
It means that a Minor Lineage may be discontinued
but not a Major Lineage.
Therefore the continuation of one's own [lineage]
is discarded to continue the Major Lineage,
so as to honour the first ancestor and to emphasize [the importance of the principle of] not discontinuing the Major Lineage".
The Chūn qiū zhuàn says:
"One who is adopted as the continuer [of a Major Lineage] is made son".
When a King, having received his mandate, assumes [his kingship],
why does he revive the states that have been extinguished,
and restore Houses whose line of succession has been broken?
Because [all this had been caused by] the former Dynasty,
which did not observe the right Way and wilfully slew the innocent.
As to the Heir, who was young and weak,
he had been a prey to powerful Ministers,
and his sons and grandsons as a consequence of it had all been innocently cut off [from the succession].
To honour the merit of their first ancestor
they are therefore reinstated.
The Lún yǔ says:
"[The rulers of the Zhōu Dynasty] revived the states that had been extinguished,
and restored the families whose line of succession had been broken".
The reason why the son of an executed Lord is not installed [as his Heir]
is because of the principle that [in such a case his line] should not be continued:
Feudal Lords have a hereditary position
that they may imitate a worthy [father].
Now that his father has been executed [the succession is] cut off.
The Chūn qiū zhuàn says:
"The son of an executed Lord is not appointed [as his successor]".
Why is it that when a ruler has been murdered
his son may be appointed [as his successor]?
To honour the ruler,
and prevent usurpation and murder.
The Chūn qiū jīng says:
"Wú-zhī of Qí slew his Lord [Chu-erh]";
[whereupon] the son of the [ruler's] favourite concubine, Gōng-zǐ jīu, had to be set up [as his successor].
When a great officer who has achieved merits
dies before his enfeoffing[-ceremony]
his son is entitled to receive the fief
because [the duty of] treating the good with goodness is extended to the sons and grandsons.
The Chūn qiū zhuàn says:
"The sons and grand-sons of a worthy [officer] should be enfeoffed with land [if the latter dies without having enjoyed it]".
Why did the Duke of Zhōu not go to Lǔ [, his fief]?
Because he had to continue the work [left by the death] of King Wǔ.
The Chūn qiū zhuàn says:
"Why did the Duke of Zhōu not go to Lǔ?
He wanted to unify all under Heaven in Zhōu".
The Shī says:
"[Then] King Chéng said [to the Duke of Zhōu]: My uncle,
I will set up the eldest son,
and make him Lord of Lǔ".
When the Duke of Zhōu died
Heaven showed extraordinary signs;
[therefore] King Chéng buried him with the rites pertaining to the Son of Heaven,
and ordered that a sacrifice be offered to him in the suburb of Lǔ,
to show that this [expression of] utmost filial piety
had been instigated by Heaven.
Why must the King, for his capital, select [a place in] the centre of the country?
It is in order that he may maintain an equipoise of [the effects of his spiritual] teaching,
and equalize the distance to and from [the capital];
that he may easily be informed of the good
and the evil that is committed.
It indicates that he should always be careful and diligent
in the observation of [the people's] good and evil [deeds].
The Shàng shū says"
"May the King come [in the new capital] to continue [the work] of the Lord on High,
and undertake himself [the duties of government] in the centre of the land".
The Sage makes institutions in continuation of [the work of] Heaven.
[Again] the Shàng shū says:
"Thou [, my Uncle, Duke of Zhōu,] hast not dared but acknowledge reverently the favour of Heaven,
and hast surveyed the locality [to find where our Zhōu may respond to that favour]".
Where was the first fief of the House of Zhōu?
Hòu-jì was enfeoffed in Tái,
Duke Líu left Tái and moved to Bīn.
The Shī says:
"Thus [Hòu-jì] made house and home in Tái".
Again it says:
"Stalwart was Duke Líu,
he made his lodging in Bīn".
Though the House of Zhōu moved [its capital] five times,
the [underlying] idea [in each case] was the same;
each time [the motive was] the wish to bring its Way to consummation.
Why [must a Feudal Lord, to move his capital,] first announce [his intention] to the King?
A Feudal Lord is not allowed to move [his capital],
and only after his request has been approved [by the King] may he carry it out.
What
does Jīng-shī mean?
It is the denomination of the city [within the King's domain] of one thousand lǐ [square].
Jīng means
dà 'great';
shī means
zhòng 'multitudinous'.
[Jīng-shī is the place where] the Son of Heaven has his residence;
therefore [it is indicated by] the words great and multitudinous,
meaning that [the King's territory] is ten times [as large as that of] a Feudal Lord.
It models itself on the sun and the moon, both having a diameter of one thousand lǐ.
The Chūn qiū zhuàn says:
"The jīng-shī
is the abode of the Son of Heaven".
The Wáng zhì says:
"The territory of the Son of Heaven amounts to one thousand lǐ square".
Another opinion is:
[The capital] under the Xià was called Xià-yì;
under the Shāng it was called Shāng-yì,
and under the Zhōu it was called jīng-shī.
The Shàng shū says:
[The King of Xià] does nothing but execise oppression in Xià-yì".
This was said of Jié [, the last Sovereign of Xià].
Again it says: King Zhōu's crimes accumulated in Shāng-yì.
This was said of [the last Sovereign of] Yīn.
Lù 'revenue accuring from a governmental position' means
lù 'a registered agreement'.
[It is that by which] the superior agrees to attach the inferior to him with consideration,
and each inferior agrees to serve the superior with diligence.
The Wáng zhì says:
"The territory [assigned to each of] the three Ducal Ministers of the Son of Heaven is equal to that of a Duke or Marquis;
that of the Ministers is equal to that of an Earl;
that of the great officers to that of a Viscount or Baron;
and that of a common officer to that of sub-fief.

[According to that regulations, the fields of the husbandmen are in portions of a hundred acres. According to the different qualities of those acres,] when they are of the highest quality, a farmer supports nine individuals;
where they are of the next, eight;
and so on, seven,
six, and five.
[The pay of] the common people who are employed in government offices is regulated in harmony with these distinctions [among the husbandmen].
The officers of the lowest grade in the Feudal states have a revenue equal to that of the husbandmen whose fields are of the highest quality,
equal to what they would make by tilling the fields.
Those of the middle grade have double that of the lowest grade,
and those of the highest grade double that of the middle.
A great officer of the lowest grade has double that of an officer of the highest.
A Minister has four times that of a great officer,
and the ruler has ten times that of a Minister.
In a state of the second class
the revenue of a Minister is three times that of a great officer,
and that of the ruler ten times that of a Minister.
In small states a Minister
has twice as much as a great officer,
and the ruler ten times as much as a Minister.
Within the domain of the Son of Heaven
there are nine states of one hundred lǐ [square],
twenty-one of seventy lǐ,
and sixty-three of fifty lǐ:
in all ninety-three states.
The famous hills and great swamps are not assigned.
The rest [of the land] serves to endow the officers,
and to form unoccupied country".
When a Feudal Lord enters [the service of the Son of Heaven] as a Ducal Minister, a Minister, or a great officer,
does he receive the emoluments of an apanage for two generations?
It is said that
he who has ability
will receive a position,
and he whose spiritual power affects others
will enjoy his emoluments;
thus the worthy is honoured
and the possessor of spiritual power is esteemed
When [a Fuedal Lord] now with his abundant spiritual power enters [the royal service] to assist in the administration
he is entitled to enjoy [the enoluments of an apanage] for two [generations].
Therefore the Wáng zhì says:
"Within the domain of the Son of Heaven the Feudal Lords [who serve in the administration] enjoy emoluments [from apanages],
outside it they have hereditary [fiefs]".
The eldest son of the Son of Heaven enjoys the right to an apanage
because he is the Heir Apparent
and the [future] successor of the Sovereign.
He must have land that he may be honoured [for his position].
The Heir has an apanage of one hundred lǐ [square],
which is the same as the fief of a Feudal Lord [of the highest rank].
Therefore the Lǐ says:
"[Though] a common officer [the Heir is] the son of the Son of Heaven".
Though [the Heir has] no rank [his dignity is] above [that of] a great officer;
so we know [that his apanage is] one hundred lǐ [square].
The Ducal Ministers, the Ministers, and the great officers all take emoluments from apanages,
meaning that they should share their people's wealth and poverty.
What is meant
by the 'Five Elements' wǔ-xíng?
Metal, wood, water, fire, and earth.
The word xíng
is used to bring out the meaning that [in accordance] with Heaven the fluids have been 'put into motion' xíng.
Earth aids Heaven
as the wife serves her husband,
and the Minister serves his Lord.
Their position is lowly,
and those who are in a lowly position personally attend to their duties,
Therefore they naturally are the same with respect to [their] one motion, [which is] to pay reverence to [what represents] Heaven [to them].
The Shàng shū says:
"The first [element] is called water,
the second fire,
the third wood,
the fourth metal,
the fifth earth".
Water has its position in the northern quarter.
The north is [the place] where the yin-fluid
lies beneath the Yellow Sources,
having as its task the nourishment of the ten thousand things.
'Water' shuǐ means zhǔn 'level'.
It nourishes the things equally,
possessing the propensity of always being level.
Wood [has its position] in the eastern quarter.
The east is [the place]
where the yang-fluid begins to move,
and the ten thousand things begin their life.
'Wood' mù means chù 'to knock';
the yang-fluid moves and jumps, knocking against the earth to break out.
Fire [has its position] in the southern quarter.
The south is [the place]
where the yang is superior,
and the ten thousand things hang down their [luxuriant] branches.
'Fire' huǒ means wěi-súi 'to follow as a result';
it means that the ten thousand things have fully unfurled themselves.
Hǒu also means huà 'to change';
the yang-fluid holding away,
the ten thousand things transform themselves and change.
Metal [has its position] in the western quarter.
The west is [the place]
where the yin begins to rise,
and [the development of] the ten thousand things is called to a stop.
'Metal' jīn means jìn 'to stop'.
Earth [has its position] in the centre.
The centre is [occupied by] the earth.
The earth has as its task to bring forth the ten thousand things.
'Earth' tǔ means tǔ 'to bring forth'.
How do we know that the eastern region [represents] growth?
The Yuè jì says:
"In spring they grow, in summer they ripen,
in autumn they are harvested, in winter they are hoarded".
That earth is not [attached to] the name of a season
is because it is [only] another name for 'the Earth' dì-tǔ,
and [occupies] the highest position in the sequence of the Five Elements;
therefore it does not by itself occupy a special department.
The Yuán mìng bāo says:
"Though earth has no [defined] position its effects are [everywhere] present;
therefore [just as] the Tài-yī does not participate in [the process of] transformation
[so] the Lord of men is not in charge of a special department".
Why is it that [according to] the nature of the Five Elements
some [occupy a] high, and others a low [position]?
Fire
is yang;
[it represents the] superior,
therefore [it occupies a] high [position].
Water
is yin;
[it represents the] inferior,
therefore [it occupies a] low [position].
Wood is the younger yang;
metal is the younger yin,
it has the nature of equilibrium and harmony,
and can therefore be bent and straightened, it can obey and change.
Earth is the greatest,
containing the [ten thousand] things, which, growing, leave it,
and, returning, enter into it [again];
it neither rejects the pure nor the impure, it is the mother of the ten thousand things.
The Shàng shū says:
"Of water it is said that it soaks and descends,
of fire that it blazes and ascends,
of wood that it is crooked or straight,
of metal that it obeys and changes,
while [the nature of] earth is [seen in] seed-sowing and in gathering".
Why is it that among the Five Elements two [, wood and fire,] are yang, and three are yin?
Earth is the superior [among them],
and [being] the superior is associated with Heaven.
In metal, wood, water, and fire
the yin and the yang range themselves in couples.
Why is the taste of water salty?
This is its nature.
The northern quarter is the place
where the ten thousand things are strong;
the salty [taste of water] is to make them strong, as the Five Tastes are made strong by salt.
Why is the taste of wood
sour?
The eastern quarter is [the place]
where the ten thousand things come to life;
the sour [taste of wood] stimulates their life,
as the Five Tastes are stimulated by acidity.
Why is the taste of fire bitter?
The southern quarter supervises the growth and nourishment [of the ten thousand things];
the bitter [taste of fire]
makes them grow and gives them nourishment,
as the Five Tastes need bitterness to be nourishing.
Why is the taste of metal acrid?
The western quarter is [the place] where the matured things die and decay;
the acrid [taste of metal]
makes them die and decay,
as the Five Tastes are made insipid by acridity.
Why is the taste of earth sweet?
The centre is
[the place of] equilibrium and harmony;
therefore [the taste of earth, being in the centre, is] sweet,
as in the Five Tastes sweetness is the most important.
The Shàng shū says:
"That which soaks and descends becomes salt,
that which blazes and ascends becomes bitter,
that which is crooked and straight becomes sour,
that which obey and changes becomes acrid,
and from seed-sowing and gathering comes sweetness".
Why is the smell of the northern quarter that of decay?
The northern quarter [represents] water,
in which the ten thousand things lie concealed.
Water, now, receives [all the] dirt and impurities,
therefore its smell is that of rotting decay.
The eastern quarter
[represents] wood,
[it is the place where] the ten thousand things have freshly come out of the earth,
therefore its smell is rank.
The southern quarter [represents] fire,
[it is the place where] the abundant yang assists the movement [of the ten thousand things],
therefore its smell is that of burning.
The western quarter [represents] metal,
[it is the place where] the ten thousand things, having reached their ripeness, begin again to wither,
therefore its smell is frowsy.
The centre
[represents] earth,
which supervises the nourishment of the ten thousand things,
therefore its smell is fragrant.
The Yuè lìng says:
"The smell of the eastern quarter is rank,
of the southern quarter that of burning,
of the centre fragrant,
of the western quarter frowsy,
of the northern quarter that of decay".
[The east is] called dōng-fāng
because it is 'the quarter of movement' dòng-fāng,
where the ten thousand things begin their movement and life.
[The south is called] nán-fāng
because it is the quarter which is 'charged with' rèn the nourishment [of the ten thousand things];
these [again] contain in themselves their [several] tasks.
[The west is called] xī-fāng
because it is 'the quarter of displacement' qiān-fāng,
where the ten thousand things are displaced and dropped.
[The north is called] běi-fāng
because it is 'the quarter for lying low' fú-fāng,
where the ten thousand things lie low and hidden.
The younger yang is visible in [the zodiacal sign] yǐn;
Yǐn means
yǎn 'to extend';
its musical pitch-pipe lǜ is exactly tài-cù;
lǜ means shuài 'to conduct';
with it the fluid [of the younger yang] is conducted to [its task of] stimulating life.
[The younger yang] reaches its ascendency in [the zodiacal sign] mǎo;
mǎo means
mào 'to flourish';
its musical pitch-pipe is exactly xié-zhōng.
[The younger yang] declines in [the zodiacal sign] chén;
chén means
zhèn 'thunderclap';
its musical pitch-pipe is exactly gū-xǐ.
The days [of the younger yang are in the signs] jiǎ or yǐ;
jiǎ means
that the ten thousand things [are about to emerge out of their] 'scales' fú-jiǎ;
yǐ means
that the things which have been lying protected and bent, having served their term, wish to come out.
The season [of the younger yang] is 'spring' chūn;
chūn means chǔn,
which means
dòng 'to move'.
Its position is in the eastern quarter,
its colour is green,
its musical tone is jué;
jué means
that the fluid is moving and jumping.
Its Emperor is Tài-hào;
tài-hào means
'general rise'; the ten thousand things are stirring.
Its genius is Gōu-máng;
gōu-máng means
that the things begin their life.
Its essential spirit is the Green Dragon,
Máng means méng 'to sprout out'.
It is caused by the yang [appearing] in the middle of the yin.
The elder yang is visible in [the zodiacal sign] sì;
sì means
that the [ten thousand] things have ended their [phase of] rising;
its musical pitch-pipe is exactly zhòng-lǚ.
Its strength is fullest in [the zodiacal sign] wǔ;
wǔ [means that]
the [ten thousand] things are full and mature;
its musical pitch-pipe is exactly sheng-bīn.
It declines in [the zodiacal sign] wèi;
wèi means
wèi 'to taste';
its musical pitch-pipe is exactly lín-zhōng.
The days [of the elder yang are in the signs] bǐng or dīng;
bǐng means
that the things are 'luminous and clear' bǐng-míng;
dīng means
qiáng 'strong'.
The season [of the elder yang] is 'summer' xià;
xià means dà 'great'.
Its position is in the southern quarter,
its colour is red;
its musical tone is zhǐ;
zhǐ means
'to stop';
the measure of the yang has reached its exptremity.
Its Emperor is Yán-dì;
yán-dì means
'elder yang'.
Its genius is Zhù-róng;
zhù-róng means
shǔ-xù 'to connect and continue'.
Its essential spirit is the Vermillion Bird.
It is caused by its becoming a luán[-bird] after leaving [its burning nest].
The younger yin is visible in [the zodiaca] shēn;
shēn means
shēn 'body';
its musical pitch-pipe is exactly yi zé.
It reaches its strength in [the zodiacal sign] yǒu;
yǒu means
lǎo 'old';
the things are gathered and harvested;
its musical pitch-pipe is exactly nán-lǚ.
It declines in [the zodiacal sign] xū;
xū means
miè 'to extinguish';
its musical pitch-pipe is exactly wú-i;
wú-i means
wú-yàn 'unscathed'.
The days [of the younger kyin are in the signs] gēng or xīn;
gēng means
that the things 'change' gēng;
xīn means
that the yin begins its completion.
The season [of the younger yin] is 'autumn' qiū;
qiū means chóu 'afflicted by grief';
Its position is in the western quarter,
its colour is white,
its musical tone is shāng;
shāng means
qiáng 'strong'.
Its Emperor is Shào-hào;
shào-hào means
shào-liǎn 'minor harvest'.
Its genius is Rù?-shōu;
rù?-shōu means
suō 'to shrink'.
Its essential spirit is the White Tiger;
'tiger' hǔ means 'to catch and chastise'.
The elder yin is visible in [the zodiacal sign] hài;
hài means
kái 'kernel';
its musical pitch-pipe is exactly ying-zhōng.
It reaches its strength in [the zodiacal sign] zǐ;
zǐ means
zǐ 'to engender';
its musical pitch-pipe is exactly huáng-zhōng.
It declines in [the zodiacal sign] chǒu;
chǒu means
nǐu 'to knot';
its musical pitch-pipe is exactly dà-lǚ.
The days [of the elder yin are in the signs] rén or kuí;
rén means that
the yin is employed [by the yang] and 'serves' rèn it;
kuí means
kuí-dù
'to measure'.
The season [of the elder yin] is 'winter' dōng;
dōng means zhōng 'to end'.
Its position is in the northern quarter,
its musical tone is yǔ;
yǔ means shū 'repose';
the ten thousand things begin to produce.
Its Emperor is Zhuān-xū;
zhuān-xū means
that the cold is shrinking.
Its genius is Xuán-míng;
xuán-míng means that
'great darkness'.
Its essential spirit is the Black Tortoise,
which rises from and quits [its hiding];???
its body resembles that of a sanke.
The earth represents the middle palace.
Its days are [in the signs] wù or jǐ;
wù means
mào 'to flourish';
jǐ means
to rise after having been pressed and bent down.
Its musical tone is gōng;
gōng means
zhōng 'the middle'.
Its Emperor is Huáng-dì;
its genius is Hòu-tǔ.
Why is it that in the Yuè lìng
the musical pitch-pipe for the eleventh month is called Huáng-zhōng?
Huáng 'yellow'
is the colour of equilibrium and harmony;
zhōng means
dòng 'to move';
it means that the yang-fluid moves under the Yellow Sources,
and nourishes the ten thousand things.
Why is the musical pitch-pipe for the twelfth month called dà-lǚ?
Dà means
'great';
lǚ means
jù 'to oppose';
it means that the yang-fluid wishes to break out,
but is repulsed by the yin.
Lǚ means 'to oppose',
that is: the host [of yin-forces] oppose and obstruct [the yang].
Why is the musical pitch-pipe for the first month called tài-cù?
Tài also means dà 'great';
cù means
còu 'to collect';
it means that the ten thousand things have begun greatly
to collect [their forces against] the earth to break through.
Why is the musical pitch-pipe for the second month called jia-zhōng?
Jia means
fú-jiǎ;
it means that the ten thousand things [are about to emerge out of their] 'scales' fú-jiǎ,
dividing themselves according to their species.
Why is[the musical pitch-pipe for] the third month called gū-xǐ?
Gū means
gù 'old';
xǐ means
xiān 'fresh';
it means that the ten thousand things all leave their old [dwelling] and turn to their new [one],
none of them failing to wear a fresh appearance.
Why is [the musical pitch-pipe for] the fourth month called zhòng-lǚ?
It means that the yang-fluid is about to reach its extremity, and is in its very fullness and greatness;
therefore, taking advantage of this middle [position], it obstructs [the rising yin].
Why is [the musical pitch-pipe for] the fifth month called shēng-bīn?
Shēng means
xià 'inferior';
bīn means
jìng 'to respect';
it means that the yang-fluid is at its top and extremity
while the yin-fluid begins to rise;
therefore [the yin] pays [the yang] its respect as a guest.
Why is [the musical pitch-pipe for] the sixth month called lín-zhōng?
Lín means
zhòng 'multitude';
the ten thousand things have fully developed their ripenesss,
and their species abound in numbers.
Why is [the musical pitch-pipe for] the seventh month called yí-zé?
Yí means
shāng 'to afflict';
zé means
fǎ 'law';
it means that the ten thousand things begin to be afflicted
and to undergo the law of penalty.
Why is [the musical pitch-pipe for] the eighth month called nán-lǚ?
Nán means
rèn 'to charge';
it means that the yang-fluid still has its charge [to fulfil],
producing greens and wheat.
Therefore the yin opposes it.
Why is [the musical pitch-pipe for] the ninth month called wú-i?
I means
zhōng 'termination';
it means that the ten thousand things, following the yang, have reached their termination,
and have to follow the yin in order to rise again;
none [of them] has been [completely] exterminated.
Why is [the musical pitch-pipe for] the tenth month called yīng-zhōng?
Yīng means
yìng 'to respond';
zhōng means
dòng 'to move';
it means that the ten thousand things, responding to the yang, move and lie low.
Why is it that the Five Elements alternate their 'kingship'?
Because they engender each other in succession,
so that [each of them has] an end and a beginning.
Wood engenders fire,
fire engenders earth,
earth engenders metal,
metal engenders water,
water engenders wood.
Therefore, when wood is 'king',
fire assists,
earth is dead,
metal is imprisoned,
and water takes its rest.
That which is conquered by the 'king' is dead,
[that which is to conquer the 'king' is] imprisoned,
[that which the 'king' is to engender assists], and so it is that the engenderer takes its rest.
When wood is 'king', fire assists; how do we know [who is to be its] subject?
That earth is dead is because
the son [wood engendered by water] revenges his father [water, which has been conquered by earth].
In [the succession of] the Five Elements the son has [feelings of] concern [, which is the principle of] the things returning to their mother.
When wood is 'king',
fire assists;
when metal has accomplished [its conquering capacities],
fire smelts it.
[But] metal engenders water,
which extinguishes fire,
and so fulfils its compensating function.
Fire engenders earth,
which again obstructs water,
so that it is rendered helpless.
The Five Elements destroying each other
is the nature of Heaven and Earth.
The mass conquers the stray,
so water conquers fire.
The fine conquers the solid,
so fire conquers metal.
The hard conquers the soft,
so metal conquers wood.
The compact conquers the loose,
so wood conquers earth.
The full conquers the empty,
so earth conquers water.
Fireis yang,
and represents the Lord.
Water is yin,
and [represents] the position of the subject.
Why does the subject conquer the Lord?
This refers to the Lord who does not follow the Way.
Therefore he [, being the yang,] is overcome by the host of yin [-forces],
as was the case with King Zhòu [of the Yīn Dynasty].
And so it is that if water is in a position to go its [natural] course,
it will take metal as its cover,
and adapt itself to [the damming by] earth;
it is warm when one wishes it to be warm,
and cold when one wishes it to be cold.
How then could it ever be in a position [really] to destroy fire?
It is said that
each of the Five Elements by its nature is either the yin or the yang.
Since wood engenders fire,
why is it that [fire] repays is by consuming its mother?
The reply is:
metal conquers wood,
and fire on behalf of wood wishes to destroy metal;
[but] metal is hard and strong, difficult to smelt,
therefore [wood,] the mother, sacrificing its own body, comes to the aid of fire to burn metal.
This is the meaning of the wish to develop the child [by destroying] itself.
Moreover, the way of the yang is not to separate from each other;
therefore for the sake of both [wood and fire] fire is made consummate,
by the death [of wood, the mother,]
the child [, fire,] continues it.
Why is it that wood is 'king' for seventy-two days?
Earth is 'king' during the four last months of the seasons, each time for eighteen days;
together [with each of the other four elements it governs] for ninety days, which make one season.
[Each of the four elements together with earth is] 'king' for ninety days.
Why is earth 'king' during the four last months [of the seasons]?
Wood without earth does not grow,
fire without earth does not blaze,
metal without earth does not take its shape,
water without earth does not attain its height.
Earth supports the tender and aids the weak,
that they may accomplish the passing through their course.
Therefore the Five Elements, alternating their 'kingship',
are always in need of earth,
which is 'king' in the four last months [of the seasons],
occupies the centre,
but is not named after a season.
How do we know that the Five Elements, arising at the same time, engender each other according to their positions?
The Zhuàn says:
"The Five Elements arise together,
but each is distinguished by its name".
The yang gives life, the yin kills;
why is it that in fire there can be no living being,
whereas it is possible in water?
Life comes from within,
and fire has the yin within,
therefore there can be no life [there].
Since water and fire [each represent] only one specimen,
why is it that metal and wood [comprise] so many specimens?
Because the south and the north [corresponding with fire and water] are the extremities of the yang and the yin,
and [fire and water] having reached their extremities
are single.
The east and the west do not represent extremities,
therefore [wood and metal corresponding with east and west are] not limited to one [specimen].
Why can water and wood be consumed,
but not metal, fire, and earth?
Wood is yang,
which is the dispenser of life;
therefore it can be consumed.
Fire has the yin within,
in metal the yin is scanty [but present],
therefore they cannot be consumed.
Why do fire and water kill man?
Water is fluid at its fullest,
therefore if man enters it he is killed;
fire has the yin within,
therefore it kills man, [in a] more violent [way] than [does] water.
Metal and wood, having only a weak fluid,
cannot, therefore, kill man of their own [force].
Fire cannot be penetrated into
because it has the yin within,
which will kill man if he enters [into the fire].
Water and earth have the yang within,
therefore it is possible to enter into them.
Metal and wood, [though] having a weak fluid,
are close and compact, and it is impossible to enter into them.
Why is it that water and fire cannot be of use by applying man's skill to them,
whereas to metal and wood man's skill can be applied?
Fire is the consummation of the yang,
water is the consummation of the yin.
When the fluid is at its fullest it cannot be changed,
therefore it cannot be made to serve the use of man by applying his skill to them.
Metal and wood cannot accomplish themselves,
therefore they require the application of man's skill to be of use to him.
According to the nature of the Five Elements
fire is hot and water is cold;
why is there hot water
but not cold fire?
It means that a subject may be a Lord,
but a Lord cannot be changed into a subject.
The Five Elements having a constant existence,
why does fire suddenly disappear?
Eater is the elder yin;
[it represents] punishment, therefore it is constantly existent.
Metal is the younger yin,
wood the younger yang;
their fluid is weak and admit of no change;
therefore they are also constantly existent.
Fire is the elder yang, infinitesimal and fine,
a representation of the Lord of men,
representing him as honoured and constantly hidden,
as the Son of Heaven abides in the confines of the nine double [walls],
guarded by his subjects.
[As fire is] concealed in wood,
[so the Lord of men] reposes in consideration for others.
Wood grows of its own nature,
metal requires [the force of] man to be taken out and shaped
because the yin,being lowly, cannot of itself take shape.
Why is it that wood floats
and metal sinks?
It expresses the idea of the son being begotten of the mother.
Why is it that the liver [corresponding to wood] sinks,
and the lungs [corresponding to metal] float?
He who knows honours his mother.
Another opinion is:
The jiǎ[-part of] wood stands in fear of metal;
with its yǐ[-part] it is wedded to the gēng[-part of metal],
and receives the transformations by [this] gēng[-part].
Wood follows its original [nature of]
being soft and [easy to] bend,
it is directly [attached to] its jiǎ[-part],
and therefore floats.
The liver [, however,] follows [the fact of] its being transformed [by the gēng-part of metal],
it is directly [attached to] the yǐ[-part of wood],
and therefore sinks.
[The gēng-part of] metal stands in fear of fire;
with its xīn[-part] it is wedded to the bǐng[-[part of fire],
and receives the transformation of [this] bǐng[-part].
Metal follows its original [nature],
it is directly [attached to] its gē1ng[-part], and therefore sinks.
The lungs follow [the fact of] their being transformed [by the bǐng-part of fire],
they are directly [attached to their xīn-part], and therefore float.
[The rest of] all the Five Elements can be like wise explained.
Why is it that Heaven is light within and dark without,
whereas man is light without and dark within?
It means that Heaven and man exercise their influence by their desire to supplement each other.
Why are there five elements,
whereas there are four seasons?
The Four Seasons make up the seasons,
the Five Elements make up the joints.
So, when wood is 'king' [the corresponding season is] called spring;
when metal is 'king' [the corresponding season is] called autumn.
Earth, being the most revered, has no [defined] task,
as the Lord does not occupy a [defined] department.
Therefore the seasons are four.
According to what pattern
is the child not willing to yield?
It patterns itself after the four seasons: fire does not cause earth to flourish, but metal.
According to what pattern
does the son succeed after the death of his father?
He patterns himself after wood, which, terminating [its rule, is succeeded by] fire [taking up] 'kingship'.
According to what pattern
does the younger brother continue after the death of his elder brother?
He patterns himself after summer, which follows upon spring.
According to what pattern
is [the duty of] treating of capable with goodness extended to the sons and grandsons?
It patterns itself after [the fact that] what has come to life in spring acquires its development in summer.
According to what pattern
is [the principle of] treating the bad with badness limited to the [bad] person himself?
It patterns itself after [the fact that] autumn destroys without waiting for the winter.
According to what pattern
does the Minister assist in the government when the ruler is young?
He patterns himself after earth, which exercises authority in the period
between the last [month of summer] and the first [month of autumn].
According to what pattern
does the son revenge [his father]?
He patterns himself after earth, which conquers water,
and water, which conquers fire.
According to what pattern
does the son obey his father,
the Minister obey his Lord,
and the wife obey her husband?
They pattern themslves after Earth, which obey Heaven.
According to what pattern
does the son not leave his parents?
He patterns himself after fire, which does not leave wood.
According to what pattern
does the daughter leave her parents?
She patterns herself after water, which streams away from metal.
According to what pattern
does a man meet in person the woman whom he takes in marriage?
He patterns himself after [the fact that] when the sun sets
the yang descends upon the yin.
According to what pattern
does the Lord yield to his Minister?
He patterns himself after the [moon-]month, which after thirty days
is given a name [according to] its merits.
According to what pattern
are the good ascribed to the Lord
and the faults to oneself?
They pattern themselves after [the fact that, while] the yin and the yang together kill and together beget,
it is the yang which has the name of giving life,
and it is the yin which has the name of killing.
According to what pattern
does the Ministser ascribe his merits
to his Lord?
He patterns himself after [the fact that all] light is to be ascribed to the sun.
According to what pattern
does the Minister admonish his Lord?
He patterns himself after metal, which straightens wood.
According to what pattern
does the son admonish his father?
He patterns himself after fire, which makes wood pliable and straight.
According to what pattern
does the Minister leave his Lord when his admonitions have not been listened to?
He patterns himself after water, which, [though] soaking and descending, penetrates upwards.
According to what pattern
does the Noble Man withdraw from his son but approach his grandson?
He patterns himself after wood, which withdraw from fire but approaches earth.
According to what pattern
do relatives who act as Ministers not leave [their Lord when their admonitions have not been listened to]?
They pattern themselves on wood, of which the branches and the leaves do not separate.
According to what pattern
does the father screen his son?
He patterns himself on wood, which conceals fire.
According to what pattern
does the son screen his father?
He patterns himself on water, which detaches itself from metal [and engulfs it].
According to what pattern
has the Lord his multitudes of people?
He patterns himself on Heaven, which has its multitudes of stars.
According to what pattern
does the King bestow his favours
first on his relatives and close associates,
and afterwards on the distant?
He patterns himself on the rain from Heaven, from which the highest [parts of the earth] first receive [the benefit].
According to what pattern [is there distinction between] old and young?
It patterns itself on the Four Seasons, which [each] are divided into the first,
the middle,
and the last [months].
According to what pattern [is the relation between] friends?
It patterns itself after the waters, which assist each other by their flowing together.
According to what pattern
do the parents give life to their child and nourish it?
They pattern themselves on water, which gives life to wood and rears it.
According to what pattern
does the son nourish his parents?
He patterns himself on summer, which nourishes the trees;
that is: fire nourishing its mother [wood].
According to what pattern
does the son not neglect his grandfather's command
on behalf of that of his father?
He patterns himself after metal, which does not stand in awe of earth, but of fire.
According to what pattern
does the yang go leisurely, whereas the yin goes hurriedly?
They pattern themselves after the sun, which goes slowly,
and the moon, which goes quickly.
According to what pattern
is there a division of land
but not a division of people?
It patterns itself after the Four Seasons, which each have their division [of tasks]
while that which produces [the things in them] is [the same] 'connecting' [force] tōng;
it is as if we speak of dōng 'east',
the eastern quarter [being the place where]
everything in all under Heaven is given life.
According to what pattern
does the Lord take nine women as his wife?
He patterns himself after the nine provinces,
and resembles Heaven, which bestows [its engendering powers].
According to what pattern
does [a man] not marry [a woman of] the same clan-name?
He patterns himself on the Five Elements, which, being of different species, engender each other.
According to what pattern
does the son wear mourning for his parents?
He patterns himself on wood, which withers in the absence of water.
According to what pattern
does the mourning last three years?
It patterns itself after [the fact that there is] one intercalary month in three years,
by which the Way of Heaven is terminated.
According to what pattern
does the father wear mourning for his son,
and the husband for his wife?
They pattern themselves after [the fact that] in one seasonal year the things have their end and beginning,
and Heaven's humour changes upon their behalf.
According to what pattern
does [a man] at sixty close his door [to his wife]?
He patterns himself after the yang-force, which declines after six months.
According to what pattern
does man possess the Five Reservoirs and the Six storehouses?
He patterns himself after the Five Elements and the Six Cardinal Points.
According to what pattern is the eye of man?
It patterns itself after the light of sun and moon.
The sun shines at day,
the moon shines at night;
according to what pattern
does the eye of man alternate its light?
It patterns itself after the sun, which also alternates its activity.
According to what pattern
does the King oversee the descendants of the two [previous] Dynasties?
He patterns himself after wood, which needs metal to be straightened,
and water to be moistened.
According to what pattern
does the enlightened King first give out rewards and afterwards punishments?
He patterns himself after the Four Seasons, which first give life and afterwards kill.
Why has a [Feudal] State [an army of] three hosts?
It is in order to guard against extraordinary [events],
to punish those who do not follow the Way,
to honour the ancestral temple,
to hold the Gods of the Earth and of the Millet in reverence,
and in [times of] peace not to forget that there is [always] danger.
Why is it said that there is [an army of] three hosts?
The Lún yǔ says:
"[Zǐ-lù asked Confucius:] If you had the command of [an army of] three hosts, who would you have [to act] with you?"
The Shī says:
"The King of Zhōu marched on,
followed by his [army of] six hosts".
What do the three hosts
model themselves on?
They model themselves on Heaven, Earth, and Man.
[A unit of] five men is called a wǔ;
five wǔ form a liǎng;
four liǎng form a zú;
five zú form a lǔ;
five lǔ form a shī;
five shī form a jūn.
Two thousand five hundred men constitute a shī,
twelve thousand five hundred men constitute a jūn,
and [an army of] three jūn consists of thirty-seven thousand five hundred men.
The Zhuàn says:
"If one man decides [to fight to the] death
ten men cannot oppose him;
if one hundred men decide [to fight to the] death
one thousand men cannot oppose them;
