therefore the Kings applied them according to their sequence.
Why is it said that the Three Instructions were applied together
and not separately?
Because neither loyalty nor reverence nor culture can be spared.
Why are there three Instructions?
They model themselves on Heaven, Earth, and Man.
Inwardly loyal,
outwardly reverent,
embellished by culture,
[by these] three [things] perfection [its reached].
Modelling themselves on Heaven, Earth, and Man, how does each [Instruction] manifest itself?
Loyalty models itself on Man,
reverence on Earth,
culture on Heaven.
The way of Man has loyalty as its lead.
Man, to make his way perfect, instructs man
by utmost loyalty,
therefore loyalty is Man's Instruction.
The way of Earth is modest and lowly.
What Heaven begets
is reverently nourished by Earth,
therefore reverence is Earth's Instruction.
What
does jiào 'Instruction' mean?
Jiào means
xiào 'to imitate';
what the superior does
the inferior imitates.
The people [represent] crude material which,
left uninstructed, will not become accomplished.
Loyalty shows itself in severe straightforwardness, therefore it [can] degenerate into vulgarity.
Reverance shows itself in sacrificial worship, therefore it [can] degenerate into superstitition.
Culture shows itself in graceful deportment, therefore it [can] degenerate into profligacy.
[At the sacrifice for the dead] the Xià people used the Spiritual Vessels,
the Yīn people the Sacrificial Vessels,
and the Zhōu people combined both uses.
Why is this?
It is said:
The Xià instructed by loyalty,
therefore they preferred the Spiritual Vessels,
so as to ensure the heart of the filial son.
The Yīn instructed by reverence,
therefore they preferred the Sacrificial Vessels,
so as to expree the utmost of reverence.
The Zhōu instructed by culture,
therefore they combined both uses,
so as to express their idea of the climax of culture.
Confucius said:
"To approach the dead and treat them as dead
is against consideration for others, and should not be done.
To approach the dead and treat them as living
is a want of wisdom, and should not be done".
Therefore there should be the way of the dead
in order to ensure the heart of the filial son,
and there should [at the same time] be the way of the living
in order that men be not ungrateful.
Therefore [at the sacrifice] the vessels of bamboo are not fit for actual use,
the vessels of wood are not well carved,
the vessels of earthenware cannot be used to wash in,
the qín and the sè [lutes] are strung but not evenly,
the pan-pipes are complete but out of tune,
the bells and chiming-stones are there but they have no stands.
It means that the things are [all] complete but not for [ordinary] use.
Confucius said:
"The invention of Spiritual Vessels is good,
but the invention of human figures [to accompany the dead] is against consideration for others.
The carriages of clay and the figures of straw,
they have been since antiquity".
It means that they obtain for the present as well as for antiquity.
What
are the Three Major Relationshs?
They are [the relation between] Lord and subject,
[the relation between] father and son,
and [the relation between] husband and wife.
The Six Minor Relationships
are [the relation with] father's brothers,
[with] elder and younger brothers,
[with] one's kinsmen,
[with] mother's brothers,
[with] teachers and elders,
and [with] frends.
Therefore the Hán wén jiā says:
"The [relation the] Lord has with the subject [belongs to] the Major Relationships,
so do [the relation] the father has with his son,
and [the relation] the husband has with his wife".
It also says:
"Pay reverence to thy father's elder brothers,
and when the way of the Six Minor Relationships has been put into practise
mother's brothers will observe [the rules attached to] their [different] status,
kinsmen will observe [the rules of] precedence,
elder and younger brothers will observe [the rules of] affection,
teachers and elders will enjoy [their right to] reverence,
and friends will enjoy [the benefit of] intimacy".
What do gāng 'Major Relationship' and jì 'Minor Relationship' mean?
Gāng means
zhāng 'to spread out';
jì means
lǐ 'to regulate'.
The greater [relationships] form the gāng,
the lesser the jì;
thereby [the positions of] superior and inferior are spread out and regulated,
and the way of man is adjusted and ordered.
All men harbour the instinct for the Five Constant [Virtues],
and possess the disposition to love;
they are developed by [the rules for] the Major and the Minor Relationships,
as a net which has small and large net-rops spreads out its ten thousand meshes.
The Shī says:
"Very zealous was King Wén,
[he promulgated the rules for] the Major and the Minor Relationships to the four quarters".
Why is it that, though Lord and subject,
father and son,
husband and wife,
make six people,
we speak of the Three Major Relationships?
"The alternation of the yin and the yang is called the Way";
the yang completes itself by the yin,
the yin adapts itself to the yang,
the hard and the soft supplement each other.
Therefore the six people make up the Three Major Relationships.
The Three Major Relationships model themselves on Heaven, Earth, and Man.
The Six Minor Relationships model themselves on the Six Cardinal Points.
[The relation between] Lord and subject models itself on Heaven,
and represents the coming and going of the sun and the moon,
due to the workings of Heaven.
[The relation between] father and son models itself on Earth,
and represents the Five Elements begetting one another.
[The relation between] husband and wife models itselfs on Man,
and represents the unison of the yin and the yang in man,
by which he possesses the faculty of propagation.
The Six Minor Relationships
represent the minor counterparts of the Three Major Relationships.
[The relation with] the teacher and the elder
is the minor counterpart of [the relation between] Lord and subject.
They both serve to perfect one's own person.
[The relation with] father's brothers
and elder and younger brothers
is the minor counterpart of [the relation between] father and son.
They are connected with [bonds of] love and affection.
[The relation with] mother's brothers
and friends
is the minor counterpart of [the relation between] husband and wife.
They all have the same intentions as to the helping of one's [kindred].
What
do fù 'father' and zǐ 'son' mean?
Fù means
jǔ 'a square';
the father teaches his son the rules and measures.
Zǐ means
zǐ 'to engender';
to engender without end.
Therefore the Xiào jīng says:
"If a father has a son who dares to admonish him
he will not be endangered into performing unprincipled deeds".
What
do fū 'husband' and fù 'wife' mean?
Fū means
fú 'support';
[the husband] provides the support by means of the Way.
Fù 'wife' means
fú 'to submit'.
[The wife] humbly submits according to the rites.
The Hūn lǐ says:
"The [new] husband with his own hands removes his wife's tassel".
The Zhuàn says:
"Husband and wife, [though] divided, form one [body]".
What
does péng-yǒu 'friends' mean?
Péng means
dǎng 'associate';
yǒu means
yǒu 'to have'.
The Lǐ jì says:
"One of the same school is called a péng;
one of the same intention is called a yǒu".
The association of friends
[implies that] in each other's company they correct each other's words,
and when they are separated they abstain from criticizing one another.
When the one behaves well
the other rejoices with him,
when he behaves ill
he grieves for him.
Their property they share without reckoning.
They share each other's distress and sorrow, mutually giving assistance.
In life they do not hang on one another,
at their death they do not burden one another.
Therefore the Lún yǔ says:
"Zǐ-lù said:
I should like carriage and horses,
and light fur dresses to wear them out with my friends".
It also says:
"If a friend has no [relations] to fall back on
I shall provide for his home when he is alive,
and for his burial when he dies".
The way of friendship [is this]:
When the parents are alive two things may not be done:
one must not allow his friend to sacrifice his life [for one];
one must not accept the favour of sharing one's [friend's] riches without [his parents'] consent.
If his friend suffers from hunger
he must inform his father and elder brother;
if the latter are willing [to listen]
he must relate [the story];
if they are not he stops.
Therefore there is the saying:
"If thy friend hungers ration thy food for his sake;
if he shivers do not wear double fur for his sake".
And therefore the Lún yǔ says:
"If there are still father and elder brother,
why shouldst thou act [of thy own accord] after hearing [about thy friend's condition]?"
Why is it that with respect to males we speak of xiōng-dì 'brothers',
and with respect to females of zǐ-mèi 'sisters'?
[These] males and females will have different surnames,
therefore their denominations should be differentiated.
Why is it [thus] stated?
The Lǐ qīn shǔ jì says:
"The first-born male is called xiōng,
the later-born is called dì;
the first-born female is called zǐ,
the later-born is called mèi".
Why is it that the father's brothers
are not all [generiaclly] called shì-fù,
whereas the father's sisters
are all [generically] called gū?
Because the father's brothers are said [to belong to] the inner affinal relatives,
and therefore should have different denominations,
whereas the sisters [belong to the category of those who] detach themselves by marrying out,
so that there is one generic name for them.
Why is it that sisters, though [belonging to those who] marry out,
are distinguished by [the words] zǐ and mèi?
The rites for serving the father's sisters are alike,
while their marrying out is the same,
therefore their denomination is a generic one.
As to sisters[, however], though it were desirable to denominate them generically,
[the position of] the edler sister is superior to [that of] the younger,
and they observe different rites.
The Shī says:
"I will ask my father's sisters
and also my edler sister".
Why [are parents-in-law] called jìu-gū?
Jìu 'husband's father' means
jìu 'old';
gū 'husband's mother' means
gù 'aged';
jìu-gù
is the term for elderly people.
Why [are sisters] called zǐ-mèi?
Zǐ 'elder sister' means
zī 'to consult';
mèi 'younger sister' means
mò 'accessory'.
Why [are brothers] called xiōng-dì?
Xiōng 'elder brother' means
kuàng 'to increase';
to increase the father's laws.
Dì 'younger brother' means
tì 'fraternal love';
[the younger brother is] obedient in his heart and reverent in his conduct.
Why are the husband's parents called jìu-gū?
[A man is called] jìu who,
though not being the father, is revered as a father.
[A woman is called] gū who,
though not being the mother, is loved as a mother.
Therefore the husband's parents are called jìu-gū.
What
do [the words] qíng and xìng mean?
Xìng 'instinct'
is the dispensation of the yang;
qíng 'emotion'
is the working of the yin.
Man is born through the reception of the yin- and the yang-fluids,
therefore he harbours the Five Instincts and the Six Emotions.
Qíng [also] means
jìng 'quiescence';
xìng [also] means
shēng 'life';
it is through the reception of these six fluids that man gets his life.
Therefore the Gōu mìng jué says:
"Emotion arises from the yin,
it is desire [based] on momentary reflection;
instinct arises from the yang,
it is [always] attached to reason.
The yang-fluid [stands for] consideration for others,
the yin-fluid [stands for] selfishess.
Therefore emotions have desire of gain [as their origin],
instinct has consideration for others [as its base]".
What are the Five Instincts?
They are 'consideration for others' rén, 'sense of the correct principles' yì, 'ceremonial behaviour' lǐ, 'wisdom' zhì, 'trustworthiness' xìn.
Rén 'consideration for others' means
bù-rěn 'unable to endure';
[he who has consideration for others] dispenses life and loves men.
Yì 'sense of the correct principles' means
yí 'proper';
[he who has sense of the correct principles] in his decisions achieves justness.
Lǐ 'ceremonial behaviour' means
lǚ 'to tread';
[he who observes ceremonial behaviour] treads the way which leads to accomplished refinement.
Zhì 'wisdom' means
zhī 'to know';
[he who has wisdom] sees for himself and learns before-hand,
he is not deceived by events,
he sees what is [still] minute, and knows what will arise out of it.
Xìn 'trustworthiness' means
chéng 'sincerity';
[he who is trustworthy] devotes himself unswervingly to one end.
Therefore man lives in conformity with the bodily [parts] of the Eight Trigrams;
he obtains the five fluids to form the [Five] Constant [Virtues],
which are: consideration for others, sense of the correct principles, ceremonial behaviour, wisdom, and trustworthiness.
What are the Six Emotions?
They are:
'joy' xǐ, 'anger' nù, 'grief' āi, 'happiness' lè, 'love' ài,and 'hate' wù.
They are called the Six Emotions to serve as a complement for the Five Instincts.
Why are there five Instincts
and six Emotions?
Man by nature lives by containing the fluids of the Six Pitch-pipes and the Five Elements.
Therefore he has in [his body] the Five Reservoirs and the Six Storehouses,
through which the Instincts and Emotions go in and out.
The Yuè dòng shēng yí says:
"A government's office has six storehouses,
man has five reservoirs".
What
are the Five Reservoirs?
They are the liver, the heart, the lungs, the kidneys, and the spleen.
Gān 'liver' means gàn 'to attend to'; deliberations and preparations proceed therefrom.
Fèi 'lungs' means fèi 'to spend';
the emotions move and attain their sequence.
Xīn 'heart' means rèn 'to consider';
it has reflection as its task.
Shèn 'kidneys' means xiè 'to drain';
to drain through orifices.
Pǐ 'spleen' means bìng 'to unite';
it accumulates the germs and provides the fuid.
Of the Five Reservoirs
the liver [represents] consideration for others,
the lungs [represent] sense of the correct principles,
the heart [represents] ceremonial behaviour,
the kidneys [represent] wisdom,
the spleen [represents] trustworthiness.
Why [does] the liver [represent] consideration for others?
The liver
is the essence of wood;
consideration for others [expresses] love for the living.
The east
[represents] the yang,
[there] the ten thousand things begin their lives.
Therefore the liver resembles a tree,
green-coloured, with branches and leaves.
Why are the eyes its watch?
The eyes can shed tears,
but admit no objects.
Likewise the tree shoots out branches and leaves,
but nothing can enter it.
Why [do] the lungs [represent] sense of the correct principles?
The lungs
are the essence of metal.
[Out of a] sense of the correct principles decisions are taken.
The west also [represents] metal,
[there] the ten thousand things die in maturity.
Therefore the lungs resemble metal
and are white-coloured.
Why is the nose their watch?
The nose exhales and inhalses air,
it is high and has openings.
The mountains contain metals and minerals in layers
as well as holes and crevices;
they produce clouds and spread out rains
which moisten all under Heaven.
When it rains the clouds disperse,
[it is like] the nose blowing out the inner breath.
Why [does] the heart [represent] ceremonial behaviour?
The heart
is the essence of fire.
In the south the superior yang is ascendant
while the inferior yin lies prone.
Ceremonial behaviour [observes the difference between] superior and inferior;
therefore the heart resembles fire,
is red-coloured and pointed.
Man, being in the possession of the Way, reveres Heaven,
whose position is by nature high.
Therefore the heart is pointed downwards.
Why are the ears its watch?
The ears can discern between inside and outside,
and distinguish sound from speech.
The glow of fire resembles ceremonial behaviour
in that above and below are clearly divided by it.
Why [do] the kidneys [represent] wisdom?
The kidneys
are the essence of water.
Wisdom advances without stopping;
it neither hesitates nor doubts,
[it is like] water, which also advances without uncertainty.
The north [represents] water;
therefore the kidneys are black-coloured.
Water [belongs to] the yin,
therefore the kidneys form a pair.
Why are the [secret] orifices their watch?
The [secret] orifices can drain off,
as water also can drain off.
Why [does] the spleen [represent] trustworthiness?
The spleen
is the essence of earth.
Earth has as its highest charge the nourishment of the ten thousand things;
it is for them the symbol of the begetter of things,
requiring nothing for itself,
[the embodiment of] the utmost trustworthiness.
Therefore the spleen resembles earth
and is yellow-coloured.
Why is the mouth its watch?
The mouth can swallow,
its tongue can taste,
it can also produce sounds
and emit saliva.
Therefore the Yuán mìng bāo says:
"The eye
is the envoy of the liver;
the liver
is the essence of wood,
the seat of the Green Dragon.
The nose
is the envoy of the lungs;
the lungs
are the essence of metal,
cleaving and cutting
The ears
are the watch of the heart;
the heart
is the essence of fire,
above it corresponds with [the constellations] zhāng and xīng.
The genitals
are the drainage for the kidneys;
the kidneys
are the essence of water,
above they correspond with [the constellations] xū and wēi.
The mouth
is the gate of the spleen;
the spleen
is the essence of earth,
above it corresponds with [the constellation] Ursa Major;
it directs the transformations".
One opinion is:
The mouth
is the watch of the heart,
the ears
are the watch of the kidneys.
Another opinion is:
The liver is connected with the eyes,
the lungs with the nose,
the heart with the mouth,
the spleen with the tongue,
the kidneys with ears.
What
are the Six Storehouses?
They are: the large intestines, the small intestines, the stomach, the bladder, the gullet, and the gall.
The Storehouses
serve as the depositories of the Five Reservoirs.
Therefore the LI3 yùn jì says:
"The Six Emotions
serve as a complement for the Five Instincts".
The stomach
is the storehouse of the spleen;
the spleen directs the spending of the fluid;
the stomach
is the accumulation-place for the food,
therefore the spleen provides it with fluid.
The bladder
is the storehouse of the kidneys;
the kidneys direct the drainage;
as the bladder can always develop heat
it forestalls difficulty.
The gullet
is a storehouse which is wrapped up,
it is the canal for food and drink,
[the place] where the breath stops and begins;
therefore the upper part is like an orifice,
the middle part is twisted,
and the lower part is like a drain.
The gall
is the storehouse of the liver;
the liver
is the essence of wood,
it directs [the feeling of] consideration for others;
consideration for others means to be unable to endure,
therefore it decides by 'courage';
for this reason consideration for others requires the possession of bravery.
How do we know that though the liver and the gall have different tendencies
the one is the storehouse of the other?
The liver
is the essence of wood;
'wood' mù means mù 'to shepherd';
when a man becomes angry he always assumes a green colour while his eyes dilate;
this is the working [of the liver].
The small intestines and the large intestines
are the storehouses of the heart and the lungs,
and direct the sense of ceremonial behaviour;
sense of ceremonial behaviour
has discrimination as its principle;
likewise the large and the small intestines receive from each other;
the intestines are the directors of the heart and the lungs;
the heart is the director of its dependencies,
therefore there are two storehouses.
The eyes see for the heart,
the mouth talks for it,
the ears hear for it,
the nose smells for it:
such is its direction of its dependencies.
Why is it that joy resides in the west,
anger in the east,
love in the north,
hate in the south,
grief in the lower,
and happiness in the upper [regions]?
In the west the ten thousand things mature,
therefore there is joy;
in the east they are born,
therefore there is anger,
in the north the yang-fluid begins to work,
therefore there is love;
in the south the yin-fluid begins to rise,
therefore there is hate;
in the upper [regions] there is much happiness
as there is much grief in the lower.
What
do [the words] hún and pò mean?
Hún expresses the idea of soaring away,
of going without rest;
it is the fluid of the younger yang,
therefore it moves without stopping;
with respect to man it is external
and directs the instincts.
Pò
expresses the idea of a pressing urge on man;
it is the fluid of the younger yin;
it resembles [precious] metal and stone, which urge man without distraction
and directs the emotions.
Hún means
yún 'to weed';
with the instincts the ill-weed is removed.
Pò means
bái 'to clear up';
with the emotions the inner movements are governed.
What
do the words jīng and shén mean?
Jīng 'receptive power' means jìng 'repose';
it is the fluid of the dispensing and transforming [power] of the elder yin;
it resembles the transforming [power] of water,
which must wait for its task of giving life.
Shén 'vital force' means huǎng-hū 'flux';
it is the fluid of the elder yang,
which is in motion without interruption.
In general it may be said [that vital force is] the origin of [the process of] branching off [into various organs], and of the ten thousand transformations.
What
does mìng 'destiny' mean?
[It means] man's old age,
what Heaven has destined to constitute his span of life.
There are three kings of destinies, indicating [man's] vicissitudes.
There is the 'Old-age Destiny' shòu-mìng, [to denote] those who observe the rules;
there is the 'Accident Destiny' zāo-mìng, [to denote] those who meet a violent [death];
there is the 'Merit Destiny' suí-mìng, [to denote] those who receive according to their deserts.
The 'Old-age Destiny'
is the best.
It applies for instance to "King Wén, who received his mandate in the middle of his life
and enjoyed the state['s throne] for fifty years".
The 'Merit Destiny'
is the destiny as a consequence of one's behaviour.
It applies for instance to [the prince of Hu,] "who idly abandoned the Three Rectifications,
so that on that account Heaven cut off his life".
For [Heaven] desires that the people apply themselves to consideration for others and abide by the sense of the correct principles,
not despising Heaven;
when [there is one who] despises Heaven, then the Overseer of Destinies will expose his guilt,
that is, he will use it as a reason to destroy him.
The 'Accident Destiny'
[applies to] those who encounter the depravities of his time,
as when above [there happens to be] an unruly Lord,
so that below there will be calamities and extraordinary events.
Disasters occur
and the life of men is cut short.
Such was the case when the town of Shā-lù fell crushingly from the river-bank
[or] when Rán Bó-níu, [Confucius' disciple and a man of] bold speech and upright conduct,
was visited by a loathesome disease.
Confucius said [of him]:
"It is destiny!
That such a man should have this disease!"
The Master, when passing through Zhèng,
found himself separated from his disciples,
and alone took his stand outside the gate of the city-wall.
Someone told Zǐ-gòng:
"At the eastern gate there is a man,
whose head resembles that of Yáo;
his neck resembles that of Gāo-yáo,
and his shoulders resembles those of Zǐ-chǎn;
only from his waist down
he lacks [the height of] Shùn by three inches.
He looks wearied like a homeless dog".
Zǐ-gòng related it to Confucius,
who with a sigh and a smile replied:
"[The description of my] appearance is inadequate,
but as to the homeless dog,
how true it is,
how true it is".
What
does zōng mean?
Zōng means
zūn 'to honour'.
He who officiates as host to the ancestors
is honoured by the members of his lineage.
The Lǐ says:
"When the Head of the Major Lineage has some business to do
all his kindred wait on him".
Why is it that
from of old there must always be lineages with [their heads]?
To promote harmonious relations.
The [Head of the] Major Linage can lead the Minor Lineages;
[the Heads of] the Minor Lineages can lead the groups of younger brothers;
they share their wealth
so as to keep [the affairs of] the kindred in order.
All descendants who 'honour' the first ancestor constitute the Major Lineage;
this is [the ancestor who is] honoured for a hundred generations.
All descendants who 'honour' the great-great-grandfather
are those who are shifted after five generations.
Therefore it is said: "The ancestors are shifted upwards,
the lineages are changed downwards".
All descendants who 'honour' the great-grandfather constitute the Great-grandfather Lineage;
those who 'honour' the grandfather constitute the Grandfather Lineage;
those who 'honour' the father consititute the Father Lineage.
[The lineages] from Father Lineage to Great-great-grandfather Lineage
together consititute the Minor Lineages.
It is by their shifting
that they are distinguished from the Major Lineage.
The son who is set aside [to become the founder of a new line]
naturally becomes the first ancestor of his sons and grandsons.
His collateral descendants in each [following] generation
naturally form [Minor] Lineages.
What is meant by: there are four Minor Lineages
and one Major Lineage,
in all five lineages,
is that thus man's kinship is completely defined.
Since it is proper that [a man who is set up as] a Feudal Lord is withdrawn from his [original] lineage,
meaning that he is [to be the first ancestor] to be 'honoured',
why is it not allowed for a great officer to be withdrawn from his lineage?
The answer is:
a Feudal Lord transmits his hereditary [position] to his sons and grandsons,
therefore he is withdrawn from his [original] lineage.
A great officer does not transmit [his position] to his sons and grandsons,
therefore he is not withdrawn from his lineage.
The Sàng fú jīng says:
"A great officer [wears the three months' mourning] for the Head of the Major Lineage".
It is never stated that a Feudal Lord [wears mourning] for the Head of the Major Lineage.
What
does zú mean?
Zú 'kindred' means
còu 'to collect',
jù 'to assemble'.
It means that love and affection flow together and collect.
Above, [the kinship] includes the great-great-grandfather in the collection,
below, it reaches to the great-great-grandson.
If one house enjoys good luck
a hundred houses assemble it;
it unites and makes them love each other.
When alive they have affection for one another,
in the case of death they grieve for one another.
They follow the way of assembling in a body,
therefore they are said [to form] a zú 'kindred'.
The Shàng shū says:
"[Yáo was able] to love the Nine [Groups of] Kindred".
Why are there nine [groups of] kindred?
Jǐu 'nine' means jīu 'profound'.
The affection of the nearer and remoter relatives is profound,
[therefore] we speak of jǐu-zú 'the [Profound] Nine [Groups of] Kindred'.
[These Nine Groups consist of] four [groups of] kindred through the father,
three the mother,
to through the wife.
The four [groups of] kindred through the father are [the following]:
those bearing the father's surname form the first [group of] kindred;
the father's married sisters with their children form the second [group];
ego's married sisters with their children form the third [group];
ego's married daughters withtheir children form the fourth [group].
The three [groups of] kindred through the mother are [the following]:
the mother's parents form the first [group of] kindred;
the mother's brothers form the second [group];
the mother's sisters form the third [group].
The mother's brothers as well as the mother's sisters
belong to the 'outside relatives',
therefore they are mentioned together.
The two [groups of] kindred through the wife are [the following]:
the wife's father forms the first [group of] kindred,
the wife's mother forms the second [group].
As [the relationship with] the wife's parents is loose
her father and her mother each are considered as one [group of] kindred.
The Lǐ says:
"Among the Three [Divisions of] Kindred there is no occasion for mourning".
The Shàng shū says:
"[Yáo was able] to love the Nine [Groups of] Kindred".
The meaning [of the two expressions] is the same.
One opinion [says]:
The reason for speaking of the Nine [Groups of] Kindred combined [as in the Shàng shū] is to express the idea that in the time of Yáo [the three divisions] each had three [groups].
Why[, however,] is it that according to the [later] rites only the [groups of] kindred through the father have become four?
The meaning is this: When the Zhōu succeeded to the two degenerated [Dynasties Xià and Yīn]
all the people [had begun to] emphasize the [importance of knowing their] offspring.
Therefore they raised the rites for the mother's kindred [above those for] the wife's kinsfolk,
and lowered the rites for the mother's kindred [below those for] the father's kindred.
Thus the [number of groups of] kindred through the wife was diminished [by one], which was added to the [number of groups of] kindred through the father.
Some [say]: When we speak of the Nine [Groups of Kindred]
it refers to the affection between those who are related to each other,
as [in the case of Chuang-chiang, who was] the sister-in-law of the Marquis of Xíng,
and had the Duke of Tán as her brother-in-law.
When we speak of four [groups of kindred]
it refers only to those who wear mourning [for each other].
The difference is [that the latter are expected] never to harm one another.
Why has a man a clan-name?
To emphasize [the feelings of] affection,
to enhance the love between his kindred,
to differ from the beasts,
and to distinguish the marriage[-groups].
Therefore, when in ordering the generations and distinguishing
the species men are induced to love each other during their life
and to mourn for each other in case of death,
and they are forbidden to marry persons of the same clan-name,
it is all to accentuate [the improtance of] the human relationships.
Xìng 'clan-name' means
shēng 'to live'.
Man receives life by the grace of Heaven's fluid.
The Shī says:
"Heaven gave birth to the multitudes of people".
The Shàng shū says:
[Yáo] appeased and made illustrious the Hundred Clans".
Why are there one hundred clan-names?
Anciently the Sages by blowing the musical pitch-pipes fixed the clan-names,
and thereby registered the [different kinds of] kindred.
Man is born with the Five Constant [Virtues] in him.
There are five principal tones:
gōng, shāng, jué, zhǐ, and yǔ,
which, combining together five by five,
make twenty-five [tones],
and further give birth to the four seasons.
With the [four] different climates
and the [twenty-five] various tones the completion is obtained.
Therefore there are one hundred clan-names.
What are the surnames for?
To honour efficacious spiritual power
and discourage cunning force.
Sometimes one's official position is taken as a surname,
sometimes one's profession.
Hearing the surname one's spiritual power can be known.
Thereby man is encouraged to practise what is good.
Why is sometimes the 'style' of the grandfather taken as a surname?
To distinguish between the descendants of the Feudal Lords,
to revive an extinguished state,
or to continue a cut-off generation.
The son of the King is called 'King's son' wáng-zǐ,
the grand-son of a King is called 'King's grandson' wáng-sūn.
The son of a Feudal Lord is called 'Duke's son' gōng-zǐ,
the son of a Duke's son is called 'Duke's grandson' gōng-sūn.
The sons of a Duke's grandson
each take the style of their grandfather as their surname.
Therefore we have in the Chūn qīu Wáng-zǐ Xiá,
in the Lún yǔ we have Wáng-sūn Jiǎ,
Wèi Gōng-zǐ Jīng, and [Wèi] Gōng-zǐ Cháo.
In Lǔ we have [the surnames] Zhòng-sūn, Shū-sūn, and Jì-sūn.
In Chǔ we have [the surnames] Zhāo, Qū, and Jǐng;
In Qí we have Gāo, Guó, and Cuī.
Thus we know that they were descendants [bearing the style of their grandfathers as surnames].
The descendants of the Kings [of the previous Dynasties]
are also called 'King's son'
because all of them, elder and younger brothers, are established as fief-holders.
Another opinion says:
the descendants of the Kings [of the previous Dynasties]
are also called 'King's grandson'.
The Xíng dé fàng says:
"When Yáo knew his end was coming
he distinguished Jì and Xiè
by conferrring upon them the clan-names of Zǐ and Jī,
[but] Gāo Yáo, who had regulated the punishments,
was not distinguished by a clan-name".
This means that Heaven employs spiritual power, and avoid punishments.
The clan-name of Yǔ was Sì;
[it was based on the fact that his] ancestor Chāng-yì was born through [the mediation of] the yì-yǐ [plant].
The clan-name of the Yīn was Zǐ;
[it was based on the fact that their] ancestor [Xiè] was born through [the mediation of] a black bird.
The clan-name of the Zhōu was Jī;
[it was based on the fact that their] ancestor [Hóu-jī] was born through [his mother] having trodden on the footprint of a giant.
Why must a man have a [personal] name?
To reveal his emotions,
and in the reverential service of others to present himself.
The Lún yǔ says:
"If the names are not correct the words will not conform [with the facts]".
Why [is it that a child is] given its name three months [after its birth]?
The Way of Heaven is that in a season [of three months]
the things have their transformation,
while three months after his birth
a child acquires its eyesight, is also able to smile,
and to come into communication with the people [of the outer world].
So, with the beginning of its consciousness, it is given a name.
Therefore the Lǐ fú zhuàn says:
"Three months after its birth
a child receives from the father its name before the shrine of the first ancestor".
[It takes place] before the shrine of the first ancestor,
that is the ancestral temple of the child's parents;
it means [that the name given] should be [announced to all] the shrines in the ancestral temple.
Another opinion is: the name is given in the Small Apartment.
The personal name
is [only] an appellation of a young and unimportant [child],
it is unpolished and indefinite,
therefore [it is given] in the Small Apartment.
The Lǐ nèi zé says:
"When a child [of a Feudal Lord] has been born[, and a name is to be given to it],
the Lord washes his face and body, and puts on his court-robes;
his Consort does the same.
They take their stand to the south-west of the eastern steps;
one of the secondary wives, with the child in her arms, ascends by the western steps;
[then] the Lord gives the name".
If it is a child by the principal wife its right hand is taken;
if it is a child by the secondary wife it is caressed on the head.
The Lord says:
Be careful in thy lead;
his Consort says:
Remember to become perfect.
[Afterwards they] announce [the name] to the four frontiers.
The announcement to the four frontiers
is in order to nip in the bud
and to prevent from the beginning [all possible disasters].
The Zēn zǐ wèn says:
"Three months after his birth the Generation-son
is given his name, which [the child's father] announces to the shrines of his [first] ancestor and of his father".
The Nèi zé jì says:
"When the name is to be announced to the hills and rivers, to the Gods of the Earth and of the Millet, and to the four frontiers,
in the case of the Heir of the Son of Heaven
a common officer is ordered to carry the child to the southern suburb".
Why is it that [at the birth of a son]
six arrows of [the wood of] the wild rubus are launched from a bow of [the wood of] the mulberry-tree?
This is [a reference to] the duties of a male.
Therefore first his duties are indicated
that he may later enjoy his official position.
Why must it be [the wood of] the mulberry and of the rubus?
The mulberry and the rubus
express the idea of a mutual contact.
The Bǎo fù says:
"When an Heir is born
he is treated with [the required] ceremonial;
a common officer is ordered to carry him;
the officer in charge, who has observed a stringent fast and is wearing his black ceremonial dress and bonnet,
proceeds to the suburb
to show [the child] to Heaven".
The Hán shī nèi zhuàn says:
"When an Heir is born
six arrows of [the wood of] the wild rubus from a bow of [the wood of] the mulberry-tree
are shot upwards, downwards, and to the four quarters".
It means that [the child] will have to serve Heaven, Earth, and the four quarters.
Why is it that the Yīn [Sovereign] used the day of birth to name the child?
The House of Yīn belonged to [the adherents of the principle of] Substance,
therefore they simply took the day of birth to name the child.
Thus the Shàng shū relates of Tài-jiǎ, Dì-yǐ, and Wǔ-dīng, who were Sovereigns of the House of Yīn.
Were the subjects among the people allowed to name the child after the days of birth [and use the signs of the celestial cycle] jiǎ, yǐ[, etc.]?
They were not urged to, but neither were they prevented.
So the Shàng shū mentions among the Ministers of the Yīn one Wū-wù
and one Zǔ-yǐ.
How do we know that the Feudal Lords [did] not [wish to be] similar to the King by taking the day of birth to name their children?
From [the fact that] Tài-wáng had as his personal name Tán-fǔ,
and Wáng-jì has as his personal name Lì;
they were Feudal Lords under the Yīn.
Where in the Yì mention is made of Dì-yǐ,
Chéng-tāng is meant;
where in the Shū mention is made of Dì-yǐ,
his descendant of the sixth generation is meant.
As Tāng lived in the time of the Xià,
why did he use as his personal name [one of the signs of the cycle] jiǎ, yǐ[, etc.]?
The reply is:
The descendant-kings of Tāng have changed his personal name,
and it was only [a case of] the rule of these sons and grandsons [being applied afterwards].
The original personal name [of Tāng] was Lǚ.
The Lún yǔ says: "I, the Little Child Lǚ".
Lǚ
was Tāng's personal name.
Why is it that [the signs in the terrestrial cycle] zǐ, chǒu[, etc.] were not used as personal names?
The reply is:
[The celestial cycle] jiǎ, yǐ[, etc.]
represents the trunk;
[the terrestrial cycle] zǐ, chǒu[, etc.]
represents the branches.
The trunk is the base;
the base being the substantial,
[the cycle] jiǎ, yǐ[, etc. is] used for personal names.
Why is it that sometimes the personal names are double, sometimes single?
To indicate that they do not express the same [idea].
Sometimes the name is fixed with the help of the musical pitch-pipe
after hearing the cry [of the child],
sometimes [it is given] according to the circumstances [of the birth]
or according to the appearance [of the chile].
Therefore the personal names are either double or single.
A case of a name given according to the circumstances
is that of Hòu-jì.
He was abandoned [at this birth],
and was accordingly named Qì.
[A case of a name given] according to appearance is that of Confucius,
whose head resembled the shape of the Ní-qīu mountain in the state of Lǔ,
and therefore was named Qīu.
Sometimes the personal name is extended to make a style,
so that hearing the personal name one knows the style,
and hearing the style one knows the personal name.
So for the personal name Cì there is the style Zǐ-gòng 'Child-bestowal';
for the personal name Lǐ 'Carp' there is the style Bó-yú 'Chief-fish'.
Why does the Chūn qīu condemn [the use of] two personal names?
[To avoid] the difficulty of tabooing them.
Others say: it is condemned because it[s use] is [a sign of] inconstancy,
as when [the son of the last Sovereign of Yīn] suddenly adopted the personal name
of Lù-fǔ, whereas he was originally called Wǔ-gēng.
A personal name
is not made after the sun, the moon, mountains, and rivers,
because a personal name is a belittling and self-depreciatory appellation.
A subject ought to taboo [the names of his superiors,
which would be difficult if they were formed after] things of general use;
so they are avoided.
The Qǔ lǐ says:
"It is not necessary to taboo both [names in a double] personal name.
He who has reached [the age to be able] to serve his parents taboos [the names of] his grand-parents;
he who has not yet reached [the age to be able] serve his parents does not taboo [the names of] his grand-parents.
In the presence of the Lord [the names of the parents are] not avoided,
neither in reciting the Shī and the Shū
nor in writing an [official] composition
nor [at the sacrifice] in the suburb or in the ancestral temple".
Futher it says:
"In the presence of the Lord the subject calls himself by his personal name,
in the presence of the father the son calls himself by his personal name".
That is to say that [likewise] a great officer calls himself by his personal name in the presence of the Minister,
and the younger brother does so in the presence of his elder brother.
It means that one dares not taboo [one's name] in the presence of one's superior.
Why is it that in the earliest antiquity there was no [rule of] tabooing [names]?
They esteemed simplicity,
so that the subject and son were allowed to pronounce the names of the Lord and father.
Therefore the Lǐ jì says:
"In former days simplicity was esteemed, and there was no tabooing [of names]; the name [which had been announced to] Heaven was properly used".
Why is man born ten months [after the conception]?
Man
is begotten of Heaven,
and passes through the numbers of Heaven and Earth, [each being] five.
Therefore in ten months [the embryo is] complete
and becomes a human being.
Why does a child cry when it is born?
It detaches itself from [the mother with whom] originally [it formed] one trunk.
When it gets air and breathes separately
it cries,
which means that the separation from the mother is a crucial event.
The Shàng shū says:
"Qǐ was wailing and weeping".
Why does one in saluting mention one's personal name?
To define one's appellation and to indicate oneself.
Why is it that according to the rites
one subordinates oneself in the salutation
and does not mention one's personal name [first]?
To conform oneself to [the relation of] the yin and the yang.
Why do people salute each other?
To manifest their emotions, to show their intentions,
to humble themselves, and to incline their bodies
in order reverently to be at the disposal of other.
Bài 'to salute' means fú 'to submit to'.
Why is it necessary to salute twice?
To model oneself on the yin and the yang.
The Shàng shū says: "[The Feudal Lords] saluted twice and inclined their heads [till they touched the ground]".
Why is it necessary to touch the ground with the head?
It is an expression of the highest reverence.
Why must the crown touch the ground?
Shǒu 'head' is said,
[by which] the crown is meant.
The Lǐ says: "If on the head there is an ulcer then it is washed".
Why is it that first the salutation with the hands is made,
and then the inclining of the head?
[The order of] each follows the Principles of Form and Substance.
The Shàng shū says:
"The Duke of Zhōu [adhering to the Principle of Form] saluted with his hands and inclined his head [to the ground]".
Why must a man have a style?
To crown his spiritual power, to show his merits,
and to honour the [new] adult.
Therefore the Lǐ shì guàn jīng says:
"The guest, facing north,
gives the style, saying: Eldest son So-and-so fǔ".
It further says:
"The giving of the style after the capping
is to maintain the honour of the personal name [which the young man has received from his parents]".
It is only when a man has reached his fiftieth year that he is called bó 'elder uncle' or zhòng 'younder uncle',
because at fifty he knows Heaven's destiny,
and his thoughts are careful and firm;
he knows how to adapt himself to the orderly succession of the four seasons and of the old and the young;
therefore he received the appellation bó and zhòng.
The Tán gōng says:
"In his youth he has his personal name, at the capping he receives his style,
when he is fifty he is called bó and zhòng".
The Lún yǔ says:
"At fifty I knew the destiny of Heaven".
Why is it that there are four [distinguishing] appellations?
model themselves on the positional domination of [each of] the four season, which symbolize [the order of] the first and the later,
the senior and the junior, the elder and the younger.
Therefore, in conformity with the older and younger of the seasons the appellations are bó, zhòng, shū, and jì.
Bó means
Zhǎng 'senior'.
A bó
is the son who is the senior [in years]
and approaches [the age of] the father.
Zhòng means
zhōng 'the middle'.
Shū means
shào 'young'.
Jì means
yòu 'junior'.
The eldest son of the principle wife is called bó;
Bó-qín is an example.
The eldest son of a secondary wife is called mèng;
the great officer Mèng of Lǔ is an example.
"Sons and daughters are distinguished by their ages,"
[that is,] each natually have [the distinguishing names of] bó, zhòng[, etc.],
and model themselves on the yin and the yang, both of which naturally have their beginning and end.
The Chūn qīu zhuàn says:
"Who was Bó-jī?
It is the denomination of a girl of the same clan-name as the King".
Why is a woman [already] called bó or zhòng when she is fifteen?
A woman's stuff is such that she quickly [reaches her age of] transformation:
the way of the yin soon attains completion.
At fifteen [a woman is] versed in the arts of weaving,
while her thoughts are careful and firm.
Therefore, when she is promised in marriage,
she receives a hairpin and her style.
So the Lǐ jīng says:
"At fifteen a girl is promised in marriage;
she receives a hairpin,
is given presents, and is called by her style".
Why is the clan-name of a woman a correlate of her style?
To make it clear that one does not take a wife of the same clan-name.
Therefore the Chūn qīu says:
"Bó-jī was married to Sòng".
Jī
was her clan-name.
Why is it that with the adherents of the Principle of Substance [the younger sons are all] gathered together in [the appellation] zhòng?
[The Principle of] Substance is to love the relatives,
therefore [the younger sons are] gathered together in zhòng.
The adherents of the Principle of Form honour the honourable,
therefore [the younger sons are] gathered together in [the appellation] shū.
If that be so,
why is it that the Lún yǔ says:
"Zhōu had eight officers:
Bó-dá,
Bó-kuò4,
Zhòng-tū,
Zhòng-hū,
Shū-yè,
Shū-xià,
Jì-suí,
and Jì-kua",
[thus] not gathering together [the younger brothers] in [the appellation] shū?
Because [the brothers were] born two by two.
[Usually, however, the sons are] never gathered together in [either the appellation] bó or jì,
meaning that there are never two [eldest or youngest sons].
King Wén had ten sons.
The Shī zhuàn says [they were]:
"Bó Yì-Kǎo,
Wǔ-wáng Fā,
Zhōu-gōng Dàn,
Guǎn Shū-xiǎn,
Cài Shū-dù,
Cáo Shū-Zhèn-duó,
Chéng Shū-chù,
Huò Shū-wǔ,
Kāng Shū-fēng,
Nán Jì-zài".
Why is it that with some of them shū and jì are preceded [by another name]?
Guǎn, Cài, Cáo, Huò, Chéng, Kāng, and Nán were all [names of] fiefs,
and were therefore put before shū and jì.
Why is it only in the case of Bó Yì-Kǎo that there is no [preceding name]?
He was [made] a great officer, [and his case is] not connected with a fief.
What does tiān 'Heaven' mean?
Tiān means zhèn 'to govern'.
Resting on high, [Heaven] regulates [all that is] below it,
governing on behalf of man.
Earth
is created out of the primeval fluid,
and is the ancestor of the ten thousand things.
Dì 'Earth' means
shī 'to spend', dì 'to examine'.
Responding [to Heaven] it spends [its nourishing power]
and brings about transformations;
it investigates and examines unerringly; reverencing the beginning it honours the end; therefore it is called dì.
The ten thousand things contain the capacity of mutation and change.
In the very beginning there was first the Great Origin,
then came the Great Beginning;
when the assuming of form was completed
it was called the Great Simplicity.
It was [still] chaotic, undivided,
invisible,
inaudible.
Then it divided, and after the clear and the muddy
were separated
the infinitesimal and sparkling [elements] emerged and dispersed,
and the multitudes of things were endowed with life.
The infinitesimal [elements] became the Three Luminary Bodies
and the Five Elements.
The Five Elements produced the emotions and instincts;
the emotions and instincts produced harmony and equilibrium;
harmony and equilibrium produced intelligence and understanding;
intelligence and understanding produced the spiritual power [proceeding from the possession] of the Way;
this again produced cultural refinement.
Therefore the Qián zuò dù says:
"The Great Origin
is the beginning of the [primeval] fluid;
the Great Beginning
is the beginning of the forms;
the Great Simplicity
is the beginning of matter.
The yang leads, the yin conforms;
the man goes [ahead], the woman follows".
Why is it that Heaven's way is a revolution to the left,
whereas that of Earth is a revolution to the right?
Because Heaven and Earth, though moving, do not separate,
and in going [their courses] do not leave each other.
Therefore the revolutions to the left
and right
are like the oppositeness
of Lord and subject, of the yin and the yang.
The generic name for a man and a woman being 'man',
why have Heaven and Earth no generic name?
The answer is:
Heaven is round, Earth is square; they are not of the same species,
and have therefore no generic name.
Since the Lord should be at ease while the Minister hurries
because the inferior's duty is to toil,
why, on the contrary, does Heaven work constantly?
Because if the yang did not move its discipline would not be practised,
and if the yin were not quiescent it would not bring about its transformations.
Though all the day active
[the yang] never leaves its palce.
Therefore the Yì says: "All the day active,
treading the Way over and over again".
Why is it that Heaven revolves to the left,
while sun, moon, and the five planets so to the right?
Sun, moon, and the five planets are, with respect to Heaven, the yin.
Therefore they go to the right.
Going to the right
is like [the position which is taken by] the subject in opposition to the Lord.
The Hán wén jiā says:
"Calculating the rightward courses of the sun and the moon".
The Xíng dé fàng says:
"The sun and the moon go eastwards".
Why is it that the sun goes slowly,
and the moon goes quickly?
The Lord takes his ease, the Minister toils.
The sun daily covers [a distance of] one degree,
the moon [of] 13 7/19 degrees.
The Gǎn jīng fú says:
"[According to] the principle of the Three Major Relationships
the sun is the Lord,
the moon is the Minister".
Why are the sun and the moon suspended [in the sky] day and night?
To assist Heaven in its work of tranformation,
and to illuminate Earth beneath.
Therefore the Yì says:
"[Of things] suspended [in the sky with their figures displayed] clear and bright,
there are none greater than the sun and the moon".
Rì 'sun' means shí 'solid';
[the sun is] always full and regular.
Yuè 'moon' means quē 'defective';
[the moon is] now ful now defective.
Why is it sometimes defective?
It is [then] turning its task over to the sun.
After three days [the moon] develops into a 'digit' pò;
after eight days it develops into brightness.
After two X eight = sixteen says it turns its task over [to the sun].
Between the end of its 'last phase' huì and the beginning of its 'new phase' shuò
it receives again its task and resumes its course.
Therefore the Yuán shén qì says:
"After three days the moon develops into a 'digit'; three moons make a season".
Why [are the planets] called xīng?
Xīng means
jīng 'essence'.
They are spoken of [as essences of the sun] according to [their having] the sun's regularity.
In one day and one night
[Heaven] moves one degree in succession,
leaving in one day-and-night a remainder of one day['s sun-course],
and dividing Heaven again in [spheres of] thirty-six degrees.
The revolving Heaven covers 365 1/4 degrees.
The sun and the moon have each a diameter of one thoudand lǐ.
Why must there be day and night?
To bring [the alternation of] the yin and the yang to full development.
When the sun shines there is day,
when the moon shines there is night..
Why is it that the days are long and short?
It is the yin and the yang alternating in their activities.
Therefore in summer the days are long,
in winter the nights are long.
In summer the sun has its mansion in the 'Easter Well' dōng-jǐng;
it rises [in the sign] yǐn, and sets [in the sign] xū.
In winter the sun has its mansion in the 'Tethered Ox' qiān-níu;
it rises in [the sign] chén, and sets in [the sign] shēn.
Why is the moon[-month] now short now long?
Heaven revolves to the left,
the sun and moon go to the right;
the sun daily moves one degree,
the moon daily moves thirteen degrees.
When the moon reaches the sun [again] it is one month.
[But] twenty-nine days
do not cover [the distance of Heaven] by [about] seven degrees,
whereas thirty days
exceed it by [about] seven degrees.
The day cannot be divided,
therefore the month is sometimes long sometimes short,
meaning that there is [the interaction of] the yin and the yang.
Therefore the Chūn qīu says:
"In the ninth month, [on the day] gēng-xū[, which was] the first day of the moon,
there was a sun-eclipse;
in the tenth month, [on the day] gēng-chén[, which was] the first day of the moon,
there was a sun-eclipse";
this was [a month of] thirty days.
Further it says;
"In the seventh month [on the day] jǐa-zǐ[, which was] the first day of the moon,
there was a sun-eclipse;
on the eight month, [on the day] kuí-sì[, which was] the first day of the moon,
there was a sun-eclipse";
this was [a month of] twenty-nine days.
Why is there a remainder of 'intercalary months' rùn?
The revolving Heaven covers 365 1/4 degrees.
One seasonal year consists of twelve months.
[The moon] daily exceeds [the sun's round] by twelve degrees.
Therefore in three years there is one intercalary month,
and in five years two.
It means that the yin does not suffice,
but the yang has a superabundance.
Therefore the Chèn says:
"An intercalary month is the superabundance of the yang".
Why [is the seasonal year] named suì?
Suì means
suí 'to follow'.
In three hundred and sixty-six days Heaven makes one revolution,
and the ten thousand things terminate and complete [their round];
therefore [this period] makes one seasonal year.
The Shàng shū says:
"A round year consists of three hundred sisty-six days;
by means of an intercalary month the four seasons are fixed, and the year is completed".
What are the seasons of the year?
Spring, summer, autumn, and winter.
Shí 'season' means
qī 'period',
the period of rest and activity for the yin and the yang.
Why is it that in [each of] the four seasons Heaven is named differently?
Heaven is exalted,
and in each [of the seasons] it is named after what it shows in abundance.
In spring and autumn the change of things is abundant,
in winter and summer the change of climates is abundant.
In Ěr yǎ says: "In spring we speak of 'Green Heaven',
in summer of 'Grand Heaven',
in autumn of 'Compassionate Heaven',
in winter of 'High Heaven'".
Another opinion says: "In spring we speak of 'Grand Heaven', in summer of 'Green Heaven'".
Why is it that the four seasons do not follow the change of the first month of the year?
Because the seasons are named according to [the changes of] the [ten thousand] things.
Spring is the time for birth,
winter is the time for termination;
in each case the season begins with the first [seasonal month].
Why do we sometimes speak of suì,
sometimes of zǎi,
and sometime of nián?
The suì 'seasonal year' is to mark the changes of things and climates;
the Emperors and Kings, contributing [to its work],
made [a division in] seasonal years on the basis of [the activities of] the sun.
Nián 'calendrical year' means
réng 'as before'.
The calendrical year marks events,
and it is on the basis of [the events in] the months that we speak of nián.
The Chūn qīu [repeatedly] speaks of
the first calendrical year, first month;
[or] twelfth month, the 'first day of the moon' shuò; [or ninth month, the 'last day of the moon' huì.
The words] shuò and huì are mentioned,
by which we know that the calendrical year is formed by lunar divisions.
Zǎi 'full year' means chéng 'to complete';
it is said with respect
to the completion of the beginning and end
of the ten thousand things.
The two Emperors used the word zǎi,
the Three Dynasties used the word nián;
in both cases there is a deficiency.
Therefore the Shàng shū says:
"[After the death of Yáo] for three 'full years' zǎi
the eight [kinds of] musical instruments were stopped and hushed within the four seas".
This refers to the two Emperors [Yá and Shùn].
It is further said:
"[Kao-tsung of the Yīn] spent three 'calendrical years' nián in the mourning shed".
This refers to [a King of one of] the Three Dynasties.
The Chūn qīu zhuàn says:
"The mourning term of three 'calendrical years' nián
is in reality twenty-five months";
we know [by this that the actual period of mourning] fell short [of the expressed term of three years].
Why is it that [with respect to] the sun we speak of yè 'night',
but [with respect to] the moon of huì 'last day of the moon';
[again with respect to] the moon of shuò 'first day of the moon',
[but with respect to] the sun of zhāo 'morning'?
Shuò means sū 'to revive';
it expresses the idea [that the moon has] waned, [but has] returned to life again; therefore we speak of shuò.
The sun is visible by day and is hidden by night;
there is a morning and there is an evening,
therefore we speak of zhāo.
Why did the Sages institute [the wearing of] robes?
In order that by the cloth the [bodily] forms should be covered,
and the spiritual power [of the wearer] be displayed; it is to encourage the capable,
and to distinguish between the high and the lowly.
Why [are robes] called yī-shang?
Yī means
yǐn 'to conceal';
shang means
zhàng 'to screen'.
With [the robes] the [bodily] forms are concealed, and one screens and shuts oneself off [from shame].
The Yì says:
Huáng-dì, Yáo, and Shùn [sat] with robes hanging down, and all under Heaven was well-governed".
How do we know that the upper [garments] are called yī,
and the lower shang?
Because the first [part of the] expression is yī.
The Shī says:
"I will lift my lower garments, and wade the [river] Zhēn".
With [the upper garments they are] connected to form the lower [garments].
The Dì zǐ zhí[, however,] says: "They gathered their 'garments' yī, and descended";
why are they named yī [here, whereas the lower garments were meant]?
The [mentioning of the] upper includes the lower.
The fur
is the additional [dress to the common ones] made by the handwork of women, in order to increase the warmth.
Anciently, with black upper-garments the fur of a lamb [was worn],
and with yellow upper-garments the fur of a fox.
Since there are so many [species of] animals,
why [did they] only [use the fur of] a fox and a lamb?
To profit by its being light and warm.
[Besides, the fox's fur was used] because a dying fox turns its head towards the hill [where it was born];
meaning that a Noble Man never forgets his origin.
[So the fur of] a lamb was used
because it kneels down when it sucks[, which indicates] respect and obedience.
Therefore, when the Son of Heaven [wears] white fox[-fur],
the Fuedal Lord yellow,
the great officer dark,
and the common officer lamb's fur,
it is also for the sake of the distinction between the high and the lowly.
The reason why a sash must [be worn]
is because it expresses [an attitude of] respect and self-constraint.
The silk [girdle] is tied on the front [with slips] hanging down[,
and it is divided into] three parts,
halfway down the body
the sash forming two [slips].
The reason why a man
wears a leather girdle
is to indicate that he is concerned with [the use of weapons of] metal and leather.
The reason why pendants must be used
is to make manifest one's spititual power and to show one's abilities.
Therefore: he who follows the Way without end wears the pendant huán,
he who can base himself on the spiritual power [proceeding from his possession] of the Way wears the pendant kūn,
he who can decide [in affairs that are] perplexing and ambiguous wears the pendant jué.
This is the reason why, seeing what a man wears as his pendant,
one can know his capacities.
The Lún yǔ says:
"After the period of mourning he wears all his pendants [again]".
The Son of Heaven has pendants of white jade,
the Feudal Lords of dark jade,
the great officer of water-green jade,
the common officer of the juan-min stone.
Thus the pendants represent one's occupation:
the farmer wears as pendants his plough and hoe,
the carpenter his hatchet and axe,
the woman her needles and thread,
[though] she also wears jade pendants.
How do we know that the woman also wears pendants of jade?
The Shī says:
"We will roam, we will ramble,
her girdle-gems tinkle,
that beautiful Eldest Lade Jiāng,
her reputation will never be forgotten".
Why is it that the Sage in governing all under Heaven
must have [a system of] punishments?
To assist his spiritual power, to aid [him in his task of] government,
and to conform to the measures [instituted] by Heaven.
Therefore he proffers ranks and rewards,
showing that there are things to strive for;
and he establishes [a system of] punishments,
to make it clear that there are things to be afraid of.
The Zhuàn says:
"The Three August Ones had no written code;
the Five Emperors employed 'punishment by effigy';
the Three Kings promulgated penal laws which,
in response to [the needs of] the time, consisted of five [kinds]".
The Five Punishments
constitute the whip for the Five Constant [Virtues].
Why are there five punishments?
They model themselves on the Five Elements.
The 'capital punishment' dà-pì
models itself on water, which extinguishes fire.
The 'punishment of castration' gōng
models itself on earth, which blocks up water.
The 'punishment of cutting off the knee-cap' bìn
models itself on metal, which cuts wood.
The 'punishment of cutting off the nose' yì
models itself on wood, which pierces through earth.
The 'punishment of branding' mò
models itself on fire, which smelts metal.
The 'punishments by effigy' [employed] by the Five Emperors
consisted in the representation of the Five Punishments by means of clothing.
Those who had committed a crime [which should be punished by] branding [had their heads] covered with a cloth.
Those who had committed a crime [which should be punished by] cutting of nose had their upper-garments dyed red.
Those who had committed a crime [which should be punished by] cutting off the knee-cap had a black spot painted on the place of the knee-cap.
Those who had committed a crime [which should be punished by] castration had to walk in variegated straw sandals.
Those who had committed a capital crime had to wear clothes without a collar.
[The criminal code comprised] three thousand articles,
so as to correspond with the [number of] emotions in Heaven, Earth, and Man.
There were three thousand [offences] which fell under the jurisdication of the Five Punishments.
Two hundred belonged to cases of capital punishment,
three hundred to those of castration,
five hundred to those of cutting off the knee-cap,
one thousand either to those of cutting off the nose or to those of branding.
The nets set out [to suppress crimes were] numerous,
but without the Five Punishments they would be invisible.
What do the punishments of cutting off the nose and branding stand for?
They are [considered as] minor punishments.
The mò [punishment]
consists in branding the forehead.
The yì [punishment]
consists in cutting off the nose.
The féi [punishment]
consists in taking away the knee-cap.
The gōng [punishment]
when applied to women who have committed adultery,
consists in their being cloistered in 'building' gōng
which they are not allowed to leave;
when applied to men who have committed adultery
it consists in cutting off their testicles.
The dà-pì [punishment]
means death.
Why are punishments not applied to the great officers?
It is to honour them.
The rites are not extended to the common man,
and [the task of] actuating the people is left to the common officer.
Therefore the rites have been instituted for those who know [their import],
while the punishments have been established for those who know it not.
A common man, though he may have a treasure of a thousand gold-pieces,
is not allowed [to show it in] his apparel.
That the punishments do not apply to the great officers
is based on the fact that the rites make no provisions with respect to them.
Another opinion is:
"[It is only] the punishment of flogging[, which is not applied to the great officers].
By the rites which are not extended to the common man
are meant the rites of pledging each other.
(For the translation of the text here, please see the footnote of no. ?)
Why did Confucius fix the Five Canons?
Confucius lived in the late period of the Zhōu;
the Kingly Way had deteriorated
and the ritual rules had been neglected;
the strong oppressed the weak
and the many behaved cruelly towards the few;
the Son of Heaven dared not inflict punishments
and the Regional Chiefs dared not begin punitive expeditions.
[Confucius,] deploring that the spiritual power [which proceeds from the possession] of the Way was not being practised,
began to travel about and to accept invitations [to enter the service of one Feudal Lord after the other],
hoping that [in that way] the spiritual power [proceeding from the possession] of the Way might be put into practise.
[But when at last he had to] return from [the state of] Wèi to [his home-state] Lǔ
he knew that it was of no avail.
Therefore he recalled [antiquity] and fixed the Five Canons, [hoping therewith to be able] to apply the Way.
Thus Confucius said:
"The Shū says:
Be filial, only be filial,
and friendly to your brothers;
to impress this upon those who are in government,
also means to hold a government's office".
Before Confucius had fixed the Five Canons, how [was the condition of the country]?
The [House of] Zhōu had declined, the Way was lost,
the Major Relationshs were dispersed, the Minor Relationships were in confusion,
and the Five Instructions were neglected.
So the canons for the Five Constant [Virtues] completely lost [the meaning of] their representations,
the Yì lost its regulating norms,
the yin and the yang and the ten thousand things, abandoning their nature, went wrong.
[Confucius] established the words of strict admonition,
and, collecting them, he composed the Shū in three thousand piān,
and out of the songs of resentment
the Shī in three hundred piān.
Since the Chūn qīu had already been composed,
why was again the Xiào jīng produced?
[Confucius] wished especially [by the book] to establish the correct [norms].
Why [should he wish to do so] by means of the Xiào jīng?
Filial piety
is shared by superior and inferior alike,
from the Son of Heaven down to the common man.
The Xiào jīng....
The fashioning of rites and the creation of music
are the basis of consideration for others;
the Sage's spiritual power [proceeding from his possession] of the Way is completed thereby.
Why did his disciples not down again his 'selected conversations'?
To show how the precepts issued by the Master
when he met with difficulties and extraordinary events rose to the correct standards.
Why did King Wén extend [the meaning of] the Yì?
King Shòu of the Shāng [Dynasty] did not follow the Way of consideration for others and sense of the right principles,
and had lost all norms in his treatment of men.
When he came to an end there was only little left of the harmony between the yin and the yang.
Therefore [King Wén] extended [the meaning of] the Yì,
and caused our [Zhōu Dynasty] to obtain the supremacy, finally reaching general peace and the brilliance of the sun and the moon.
It means that [under the Zhōu] for the rules Yì was followed.
Why did Fú-xī make the Eight Trigrams?
When Fú-xī began his kingship over all under Heaven
there were not yet laws and measures made by the former Sages.
Therefore, "looking up, he contemplated the forms in the sky,
and looking down, he examined the patterns on the earth.
He contemplated the ornaments on birds and beasts
and the suitabilities of the soil.
Near at hand, he found [things for consideration] in his own person;
at a distance, he found [the same] in things [in general].
On this he divised the Eight Trigrams
to be in communication with the power of the spiritual and intelligent [beings],
and to give form to the natures of the ten thousand things". [SYMBOLISE THE REAL NATURE]
Why are there five Canons?
Jīng 'canon' means
cháng 'constant'.
As there is the way of the Five Constant [Virtues],
so we speak of the Five Canons.
The Yuè '[Canon of] Music' [represents] consideration for others;
the Shū '[Canon of] History' [represents] sense of the correct principles;
the Lǐ '[Canon of] Rites' [represents] ceremonial behaviour;
the Yì '[Canon of] Changes' [represents] wisdom;
the Shī '[Canon of] Poetry' [represents] trustworthiness.
Man has five instincts
comprising the Five Constant [Virtues,
which however, he] cannot develop by himself.
Therefore the Sage, in imitation of the Way of the Five Constant [Virtues instituted] by Heaven, clarified them
in order to teach man to perfect his spiritual power.
What are the Five Canons?
They are the Yì,
the Shàng shū,
the Shī,
the Lǐ,
and the Chūn qīu.
The Lǐ jīng jiě says:
"Affability and liberality
are what the Shī teaches;
wide knowledge and penetrating wisdom
are what the Shū teaches;
extensiveness and spontaneity
are what the Yuè teaches;
What constant [value] does the Chūn qīu represent?
It has provided the rules from [the times of] Huáng-dì onwards.
What do we mean by saying this?
The Yì says:
"In the highest antiquity government was carried on by means of knotted cords;
the Sages of later generations substituted for these written characters and documents;
therewith the hundred officials were regulated,
and the myriads of people examined".
By the Sages of later generations the Five Emperors are meant.
The Zhuàn says:
"The Three August Ones during a hundred generations observed the spiritual and primeval documents [of nature];
in the period of the Five Emperors the books and charts were received;
[later,] historial records on government [affairs] were inscribed.
Since Dì-kuí
the documents on rites and music in three thousand two hundred and forty piān had been set aside".
Why is it that marriage belongs to the ways of man?
It is because of the emotions and instincts
there are none so important as [those between] man and woman.
In the intercourse between man and woman,
as the beginnings of human relationships,
there is nothing [so important] as the relation between husband and wife.
The Yì says:
"When the generating forces of Heaven and Earth intermingle
the ten thousand things get their transformation and fertility;
when the seeds of male and female are united
the ten thousand things are transformed and produced".
Man is to assist Heaven and Earth
in the keeping in motion of the yin and the yang,
therefore the institution of marriage is set up
to emphasize human relationships
and enlarge his progeny.
The Lǐ bǎo fù jì says:
"When one is cautious in arranging a marriage for one's son or daughter
one always chooses [a mate in whose family] for generations consideration for others and sense of the right principles have been observed".
Why is it that according to the rites the man takes his wife, whereas the woman leaves her house?
It is because the yin [to which a woman belongs] is lowly,
and should not have the intiative;
it proceeds to the yang in order to be completed.
Therefore the Zhuàn says:
"The yang leads, the yin conforms;
the man goes [ahead], the woman follows".
Why is it that a man does not marry on his own initiative,
and neither does a woman on hers,
[but for both] the marriage must proceed from the parents,
and be arranged through a go-between?
It is to keep shame at a distance and to avoid debauchery.
The Shī says:
"How should we take a wife?
We must first announce it to our parents".
Again it says:
"How should we take a wife?
Without go-between it cannot be done".
Why does the man take a wife at thirty,
while the woman marries at twenty?
The number of yang is odd,
the number of yin is even.
Why [does] the man [marry at] an older age than the woman?
The Way of yang is slow,
the way of yin is fast.
At thirty a man's sinews and bones have become hard and strong,
and he is ready to become the father of his children;
at twenty a woman's flesh and muscles are fully developed,
and she is ready to become the mother of her chidren.
Combined together they make [the age of] fifty,
corresponding to the number of the Great Expansion,
which begets the ten thousand things.
Therefore the Lǐ nèi zé says:
"At thirty a man is adult and begins a household;
at twenty a woman is adult and is given in marriage".
Seven
is the yang of the year [cycle],
eight
is the yin of the year [cycle].
Seven and eight make fifteen;
the number of the yin and the yang [added together] is then complete,
and there is the mutual wish to mate.
Therefore the Lǐ jì says:
"A girl is promised in marriage at fifteen,
when she receives a hair-pin and her style".
The rites speak of hair-pin,
[indicating by it that] the yin is bound to the yang,
by which [she has reached] the period that she is exclusively [destined for] one [man].
The yang, being higher,
need not be bound.
Yang does slow, yin goes fast.
With thirty
the numbering of three terminates, odd
is yang's measure;
with twenty the numbering of two terminates, even
is yin's measure.
Yang reaches the Small Perfection in yin,
the Great Perfection in yang,
therefore [the man is] capped at twenty
and marries at thirty.
Yin reaches the Small Perfection in yang,
the Great Perfection in yin,
therefore [the woman] receives a hair-pin at fifteen
and is married at twenty.
Another opinion says:
"At twenty-five the man is bound with his heart to a woman,
because that is the point at which the yang approaches the yin".
The Chūn qīu gǔ liáng zhuàn says:
"At twenty-five the man is bound with his heart [to a woman],
at fifteen the woman is promised in marriage.
[This is] under the influence of [the alternation of] the yin and the yang".
The number of yang is seven,
the number of yin is eight.
At the age of eight the boy sheds his teeth,
at the age of seven the girl sheds her teeth.
[But] the number of yang is odd,
therefore it is three.
Three times eight make twenty-four
plus one make twenty-five,
[so at twenty-five the man] ties his heart.
The number of yin is even, therefore it is two.
The woman matures at [the age of] fourteen [twice seven]
plus one making fifteen;
therefore at fifteen she is promised in marriage.
In either case one is added,
meaning that both have tied their hearts exclusively one [to the other].
Why is there this tying of the heart?
It is to avoid debauchery.
[According to] the rites
when a girl is fifteen she is promised in marriage.
[When the bridegroom's father] sends [the first present to confirm his] choice,
when he asks for the [girl's] name,
when news is sent of the favourable result of the divination,
when he asks for the time [of the wedding-ceremony],
and at the meeting [of the bride by the bridegroom] in person,
[on these five occasions] a goose is used as the present.
As the present for the completion [of the preliminaries] black and red [silk] is used
and not a goose.
The use of a goose as a present is because
it symbolizes [the migration to] the south and [return to] the north, the following of the seasons,
and the never missing the right moment;
it indicates that the girl is not robbed of her [right] time.
The goose is also a bird which follows the yang [sun],
as the wife's duty is to follow her husband.
Then [the goose is used] because they form rows in flying
and queues in resting,
as the marriage ritual [institution requires that]
old and young have their proper places
and do not trespass upon each other['s positions].
Since the marriage-rites [demand that] a dead pheasant shall not be used as a present,
a [live] goose is offered.
As the present for the completion [of the preliminaries] a bundle of black and red silk and the lí-pí [are sent];
black silk, three [rolls of two pieces], as a symbol of Heaven,
red silk, two [rolls of two pieces], as a symbol of Earth,
[for the number of] yang is odd [and the number of] yin is even:
it is to denote that the nature of yang is greater [than that of yin].
The lí-pí
are two [deer-]skins,
with which to cover the cout-hall.
The covering of the court-hall
is [done with an] even [number of skins].
The Lǐ hūn jīng says:
"At the sending of [the first present to confirm the] choice,
when asking for the [girl's] name,
when announcing the favourable result of the divination,
when asking for the time [of the wedding-ceremony],
and at the meeting in person [of the bride, on all these five occasions] a goose is used.
At the present for the completion [of the preliminaries] a bundle of [black
and red] silk
and two [deer-]skins [are used]".
The words [used by the messenger] when offering the present for the completion [of the preliminaries] are:
"His honour [your master] has expressed his distinguished desire
to present a wife to [my master's son] So-and-so.
[My master] So-and-so, in accordance with the custom of the ancients,
[sends] two [deer-]skins and a bundle of silk.
He has ordered [me,] So-and-so, to invite you to accept these gifts".
The first So-and-so
[indicates] the name of the bridegroom,
the second So-and-so
[indicates] the name of the bridegroom's father,
the third So-and-so
[indicates] the name of the messenger.
The father of the girl replies:
"His honour [your master], in compliance with the ancient rules,
has favoured [me,] So-and-so, with this valuable present,
[which I,] So-and-so, do not dare to refuse.
Would I dare not to confirm to his orders?"
The words [spoken by the messenger] when offering [the first present to confirm the] choice are:
"His honour [your master] is so gracious
as to present a wife to [master's son] So-and-so.
[My master,] So-and-so, according to the custom of the ancients,
has sent [me,] So-and-so, to invite you to accept these gifts".
The reply is:
"[My,] So-and-so's daughter is dull and stupit,
besides which she is unteachable.
[But since] his honour [your master] has ordered it,
[I,] So-and-so dare not refuse".
Why is it that from the Son of Heaven down to the common officer
[the bridegroom] must meet [his bride] in person and offer the end of the mounting-cord to her [to get into the carriage?
It is here the case of] the yang descending to the yin.
[The man] wishes to please the heart [of his bride],
it is the token of his affection for her.
The husband meets her in person,
[he drives the carriage for] three revolutions of the wheels,
descends, and looks askance at her;
this is to avoid [feelings of] uncontrolled passion.
The Shī says:
"[King] Wén fixed on a luchy day
and went in person to meet her on the [river] Wèi;
he arranged boats to form a bridge,
amply illustrious was the splendour".
The Lǐ hūn jīng says:
"The guest ascends [the steps],
facing north,
lays down his goose,
and salutes twice,
knocking his head against the ground. [Then] he descends [the steps] and does out.
The bride follows from out of her room, descending from the western steps.
The bridegroom mounts the bride's carriage,
and hands her the mounting-cord".
The giving away [in marriage] of the daughter [by the father] takes place before the shrine of his deceased father in the ancestral temple,
to honour the remains of the ancestors.
[The girl's father] does not dare to act of his own accord,
so he announces it [first] to the shrine of his deceased father.
Why do the parents in person exhort their daughter?
It is [the expression of] their extreme love for their child.
The father says:
"Be careful and reverent.
Day and night do not neglect the commands [of thy parents-in-law]".
The mother, giving her a sash and a handkerchief, says:
"Be diligent and reverent.
Day and night do not neglect the rules of the household".
The father exhorts her at [the head of] the eartern steps,
the mother exhorts her at [the head of] the western steps.
