The father's concubine accompanies her to the inner side of the gate and gives her a silk girdle-perse;
she impresses her with her parents' commands,
and instructs her, saying:
"Reverently and respectfully remember the words of thy father and mother.
Day and night be without blame.
Let thyself be remined of them by this sash and this girdle-purse".
[Thus] leaving [her parents' home] the girl does not bid farewell,
neither does she reply to the exhortations,
because she feels embarrassed and thinks it hard to do.
According to the rites
"in the family of the girl who has been given in marriage
the fire is not extinghuished for three days;
[they spend the time waking and] thinking of the [coming] separation.
In the family of the man who takes the wife
no music in made during three days;
they think [of the fact that the son is going to] succeed his father".
They feel sad at [the thought that] the father has grown feeble and old in the course of years and that [the time of his] being replaced [by the son] has arrived.
The Lǐ says:
"The wedding is not [a case] for congratulations;
it is [a case of] generations succeeding each other".
[When the bridegroom] hands the mounting-cord [to the bride],
the duenna declines [on her behalf] saying:
"She has not yet been taught,
[and has] not [the knowledge] sufficient to exchange ceremonies with three".
When [the bridegroom] first meets [his bride] in person,
the usher invites him [to state his business, upon which] he replies
"His honour [your master] has instructed [my father] So-and-so, that the wedding will begin this moment.
He has ordered [me,] So-and-so, to execute [the rites], and I request [to be allowed] to do as he has commanded".
The host says:
"[I,] So-and-so, with sincere respect have prepared all that is necessary".
When the father pledges his son and sends him to meet [his bride],
he admonishes his saying:
"Go and meet thy helpmeet,
that [with her] thou mayst succeed me in the sacrifices to the ancestral temple.
With diligence lead her, [but also] with respect, [for she is] the successor of thy mother after her death.
In thy [behaviour] there should be constancy".
The son says:
"Yes,
only I fear that I cannot undertake [the task].
I shall[, however,] not dare to neglect your command".
After the man has married his wife, he does not immediately present her to [his ancestors in] the ancestral temple;
this is to indicate that [her place is] not yet definitely fixed.
It is [also] the reason why, according to the marriage-rites, [when the bridegroom's father] asks for the time of the wedding,
[the bride's father] does not dare to be definite.
After the wife has been in [her husband's home] for three months she takes part in the sacrifices [to the ancestors of her husband].
If her parents-in-law are dead
the wife, after having been three months in [her husband's home], also offers vegetables [to their shrines] in the ancestral temple.
Three months [constitute] a season,
[in which] the things have their [seasonal] completion,
and the good and bad [qualities] of man can be known.
After this [period of trial] she may participate in the rites of sacrificing in the ancestral temple.
Zēng-zǐ says:
"If a woman dies before she has been presented to [the ancestors of her husband in] the ancestral temple....
the body is returned to be interred in [the cemetery of] her kindred,
which indicates that she has not yet become his wife in the full sense".
Why must the wedding take place in spring?
Spring
is the time when Heaven and Earth communicate,
when the ten thousand things begin to live,
and when the yin and the yang touch each other.
The Shī says:
"A knight who brings home his wife
must do so before the ice melts".
The reason that, [even] when the husband behaves badly,
his wife has no right to leave him
lies in the principle that Earth does not separate from Heaven.
Though the husband [behaves] badly
the wife is not allowed to leave him.
Therefore the Lǐ jiāo tě shēng says:
"Once having shared the ceremonial meal with [her husband
the wife] shall never change".
The violation of human relationships,
the killing of the wife's parents,
and the abolishment of the principles of social bonds
belong to the greater crimes.
[Only in the case of] these principles being transgressed
is it allowed [to the wife] to leave [her husband].
Why is it that the Son of Heaven and the Feudal Lords marry nine wives at a time?
It is to emphasize the importance of their states and to enlarge their progeny.
Why does it happen to be nine?
It is modelled on Earth with its nine provinces which,
responding to Heaven's creative force,
leaves nothing without life.
To take nine women in one marriage
should likewise be sufficient to meet the requirements of the Lord's creative force.
If with nine wife he does not beget children,
[then even] one hundred would not produce results.
The Wáng dù jì says:
"The Son of Heaven and the Feudal Lords marry nine women at a time".
The Chūn qīu gōng yáng zhuàn says:
"When a Feudal Lord marries a woman from one state,
then two other states send each a concubine to accompany her,
[in all three case] with her cousin and sister following".
What is meant by cousin?
[Her father's] elder brother's daughter.
And by sister?
The girl's younger sister.
Some says:
"The Son of Heaven marries twelve wives,
modelling himself on Heaven with its twelve months,
[during which period] the ten thousand things are bound to [complete their cycle of] life".
Why must he only marry once?
It is to avoid debauchery
and to prevent him casting away virtue and indulging in passion.
Therefore he only marries once;
the Lord of men has no right to marry twice.
[The marriage with the principal wife is] completed by a suite of her cousin and her younger sister
to ensure that there will be no mutual jealousy.
When one woman bears a child
three women will share [her joy],
as if they had borne it themselves.
Why does he not take two younger sisters?
It is in order to extend [his progeny by] foreign blood.
Why does he take women from three [different] states?
It is to widen [his progeny by] foreign stock;
[if he took all nine women from] one state it is feared that, their blood being much alike,
no children at all will be produced.
The cousin and the younger sister, even though still young,
follow the principal wife,
which indicates that the Lord has no right to marry twice.
They are[, however,] returned to await [the coming of] their years in the state of their parents,
[because] they are not yet prepared to respond to the Lord['s wants].
The Shī says:
"All the cousins and younger sisters followed her,
in great numbers like a cloud.
The Lord of Hán looked round at them,
resplendent, they filled the gate".
The Gōng yáng zhuàn says:
"Shū-jī went to Jì [as concubine]".
It is clear that she had been awaiting [the coming of] her years.
When two states send concubines to
which is [the precedence in] honour given?
The greater state takes precedence.
If both states are alike [in size] they are judged by their spiritual power;
if their spiritual power is alike they are judged by the beauty [of the girls].
The adherents of the Principle of Substance model themselves on Heaven, and reverence the left.
The adherents of the Principle of Form model themselves on Earth, and reverence the right.
Why [is a woman] not ceremoniously betrothed to become a concubine?
[All] men have the right to want an honourable [place]
for their children and grandchildren,
and one should not invite a man to [let his daughter] take a lowly [position].
The Chūn qīu zhuàn says:
"Two states came to offer concubines".
Why is it proper to invite a man to be a common officer,
but not to invite a man to [let his daughter] be a concubine?
A common officer is honoured at once [in his position],
and when gradually his capacities [reveal themselves] he will not remain a common officer.
But a concubine, however worthy,
will never become a principal wife.
Why is it that in taking a wife the tortoise-shell is consulted?
To divine the girl's spiritual power,
in order to know whether [the couple] will suit each other or not.
It is stated in the Hūn lǐ jīng:
"[The messenger of the bride-groom's parents says: 'I, So-and-so, have been instructed that my master] is about to consult the tortoise-shell;
may I venture to ask to which family the girl belongs'?"
When a Sovereign or the head of the major lineage has no parents,
he arranges his marriage himself.
The lower does not conduct [a ceremony] for the higher,
nor the lowly for the honourable,
therefore he arranges it himself.
The Hūn lǐ jīng says:
"When both parents [of the head of the major lineage] are dead
he himself gives the orders [for the arrangements of his marriage]".
The Shī says:
"[King] Wén fixed on a lucky day,
and went in person to meet [her, his bride,] on the [river] Wèi".
A great officer who, having acquired merit, receives a fief,
obtains the right to make up [the number] of his concubines to eight,
in order to emphasize the importance of his [newly acquired] state and to extend his progeny.
He is not[, however, allowed] to enter into a new marriage-alliance with a large state,
in order that he may not forget his original principal wife.
The Lǐ says:
"In sending presents to a daughter [who has been definitely taken as the wife] of a great officer
it is said: [That she may now be] prepared for [her task of] sweeping and sprinking".
The eldest son of the Son of Heaven
and the Heir of a Feudal Lord
both take their wives according to the rites [prescribed] for a Feudal Lord.
[They are considered] the same as the Lord,
which means that they [also] have no right to marry twice.
When the King takes a wife
he must first choose from among the daughters of a large state.
The ritual regulations provide many places
from which this appears.
The Shī says:
"In a large state there was a young lady,
she looked as if she were a younger sister of Heaven.
[King] Wén fixed on a lucky day,
and went in person to meet [her, his bride,] on the [river] Wèi",
which proves that the King must take his wife from [among the daughers of] a large state.
The Chūn qiū says:
"The Marquis of Jì came to court".
The Viscount of Jì had married his daughter to the Son of Heaven,
therefore his rank raised and he was called Marquis.
In the course of the following decades
the Marquis of Jì acquired no other meirt
than that his daughter had become Queen [by the grace] of Heaven.
When, therefore, his rank is mentioned as being that of Marquis,
we know that although [the Viscount of Jì had only] a small state,
[his rank] must [be that of one] enfeoffed with a large state.
It means that he had reached [a position of] honour which prevented him being treated as a [mere] subject [by the Son of Heaven].
Why does the King extend his [choice of] marriage-alliances [even] to minor states?
It is to open the way for the worthy in all under Heaven;
it indicates that the capable will not be neglected.
Therefore the Chūn qiū says:
"The Marquis of Jì came to court".
In [this] statement [the word] Marquis is added,
indicating that he had been enfeoffed.
He had first to be enfeoffed,
to indicate that [marriage] ceremonies were concluded with a minor state.
What is to be done with
the country of a woman [who is the wife of the Son of Heaven], when her conduct proves to be deficient and she is removed?
[It is dealt with] on the analogy of [the country of] one who is enfeoffed [with the rank of] a Feudal Lord.
Why is not a Feudal Lord allowed to take his wife from [among the women] within his [own] state?
A Feudal Lord has no right to enfeoff on his own initiative,
while it would not do to treat the parents [of his wife] as subjects.
The Chūn qiū zhuàn says:
"Sòng had no great officers for three generations.
[The Chūn qiū] condemns [the Lords of Sòng for their] taking their wives from [among the great officer's daughters] within [the state]".
The reason why a girl of the same clan-name is not taken as a wife
is out of respect to the human relationships,
to prevent debauchery,
and to avoid being [on] the same [level] as the beasts.
The Lūn yǔ says:
"The Lord [of Lǔ] married a daughter of [the state of] Wú,
of the same clan-name as himself,
and called her the Elder daughter of Wú".
The Qǔ lǐ says:
"In buying a concubine whose clan-name is not known divination is employed".
Neither does one take a wife a girl
from among one's mother's relatives [who is related to the degree that for her] the five months' mourning or more [is worn].
As it is said in the Chūn qiū zhuàn: "He was blamed for taking as a wife a girl of his mother's clan".
Why is it that when the King marries his daughter [to a Feudal Lord],
he must employ a Feudal Lord of the same clan-name [as the King's] to conduct [the ceremonies]?
In the marriage-rites it is [the preservation of] harmony that is the precious thing.
It would not do [for the King and the Feudal Lord] to converser with one another [on the same level],
because that would harm the correct relation between Lord and subject.
Moreover [the King], in employing [an intermediary for] his daughter, does not want his majesty as Son of Heaven to overawe the Feudal Lord.
The Chūn qiū zhuàn says:
"When the Son of Heaven marries his daughter to a Feudal Lord,
he must employ another Feudal Lord of the same clan-name to conduct [the ceremonies].
When a Feudal Lord marries his daughter to a great officer,
he must employ a great officer of the same clan-name to conduct [the ceremonies]".
That [a Feudal Lord or a great officer of] the same clan
and having a common ancestor,
he is fit to conduct [the nuptials of] his cognates,
so that he is employed to substitute in the affairs [appertaining to] a father.
Why does [the Son of Heaven] not employ a Minister of the same clan-name to conduct [the nuptials of his daughter to a Feudal Lord]?
It is because the majesty attached to the exalted position of the Feudal Lord
would not [make the Minister] feel at ease.
Why does [the Son of Heaven] not employ a Feudal Lord of the same clan-name to conduct [the nuptials of his daughter] in the capital?
It is because the Feudal Lord [who is to be married] will have to meet his bride in person;
to enter the capital would [for him] mean to go to the Son of Heaven for an audience,
and the rites [required for this audience and for the wedding] do not go together.
The Chūn qiū zhuàn says:
"A reception-house was built for the King's daughter outside [the city-wall Lǔ]".
It means that [the Feudal Lord, going to meet his bride, the King's daughter,] did not [have to] enter the [King's] capital.
Why must a special reception-house be built?
It is to honour [the King's daughter].
She is not lodged in the lù-qǐn,
it being the place for the administration of the government,
and not fit for a woman to dwell in.
The xiǎo-qǐn would be too depreciatory,while the room for the Duke's daughters
would constitute a slight to her.
Therefore a special building within the city-walls is erected.
The Zhuàn says:
"To build [a reception-house]
is according to the rites.
[To built it] outside [the city-wall]
is not according to the rites".
Why [is] a Minister or a great officer [entitled to take] one wife and two concubines?
It is to honour his worthiness, and to emphasize the importance of his progeny.
Why does he not complete [his marriage] by taking [his wife's father's] elder brother's daughter and [his wife's] younger sister?
It is because he is a subject who faces north,
and his authority is too small and insufficient [to entitle him] to take all the relatives of another house.
The Lǐ fú jīng says: "[The three months' mourning is worn by a Minister or a great officer for] his senior servant or his senior concubine".
It means that there is also a lower concubine.
Why [is] a common officer [only entitled to] one wife and one concubine?
[It is because his rank is] below a Minister or a great officer.
The Lǐ sàng fú xiǎo jì says:
"A common officer wears the three month's mourning
for his concubine when she was a child".
When a woman has been betrothed to be the principal wife, and she dies before she [can] proceed [to her husband],
why must [one of] the accompanying concubines go [in her stead]?
It is because the Sovereign has no right to marry twice,
but as Heaven's [favourable] destiny cannot be secured,
he marries nine women at one time.
In the Chūn qiū [it is related] that when Bó-jī [of Lǔ] died,
her youngest sister[, who should have gone to Chu-lou to take her sister's place as principal wife,] married Zēng instead.
The Chūn qiū condemns her.
When the principal wife dies,
[another] principal wife is installed,
because it would not do for a [concubine whose position is] lowly to partake [in the sacrifices] in the ancestral temple.
The younger sister [of the deceased] is installed [as principal wife] as a matter of course,
to honour the great state [from which she has come].
The Chūn qiū zhuàn says:
"Shū-jī was married to Jì".
Shū-jī
was the younger sister of Bó-jī.
When Bó-jī died,
Shū-jī was raised to [the position of] principal wife,
[which fact was] not condemned by the Classic.
Another opinion is:
"When the principal wife dies, another is not installed,
meaning that there may not be two principal wives
in order to prevent usurpation and murder.
[One of the concubines may] substitute for [the deceased principal wife] in the sacrifices in the ancestral temple,
but no more.
The rites forbid the betrothal of a woman as concubine.
This means that she cannot be raised [to the position of principal wife]".
Zēng-zǐ asked, saying:
"If according to the marriage-rites
the wedding-presents have been received
and a propitious day has been fixed,
and the parents of the girl die,
what should be done?"
Confucius said:
"The son-in-low will send someone to condole with her,
and if it is the parents of the son-in-law who die,
the girl will likewise send someone to condole with him.
If it is the father who dies [the messenger] mentions the [other] father [as having sent him];
if it is the mother who dies [the messenger] mentions the [other] mother [as having sent him];
if both parents are dead
then [the messenger] mentions the father's elder brother and his wife [as having sent him].
When the son-in-law has buried [his dead],
his father's elder brother or his father's younger brother will send someone to offer a release from the engagement to the girl's family, saying:
'It is the duty of the son of So-and-so to mourn for his parents,
and he has no right to continue his relations with your daughter.
He has sent men, So-and-so, to offer the release from the engagement'.
It is according to the rites that
the girl's family, [though] consenting [to the offer],
does not dare to engage her [to another man].
When the son-in-law has ended his mourning,
the girl's parents send someone to request [the renewal of the engagement].
It is according to the rites that
if the son-in-law does not [wish to] take her as his wife, thereafter she is married [to someone else].
If it is the parents of the girl who die,
the son-in-law will act in the same way".
Why is it that a woman [about to be married] has a teacher?
It is in order that she may learn the way of serving others.
The Shī says:
"I saw my teacher that I might be instructed;
he instructed me in the duties of a wife".
The Lǐ hūn jīng says:
"[When a girl of a Feudal Lord's family has been promised in marriage....] she is instructed in [one of the rooms of] the Lord's palace for three months".
The woman [about to be married] is instructed for one season,
which is sufficient to make her accomplished.
When a girl is related to the Lord in the degree whereby she must submit to a three month's mourning [or nearer],
she receives instruction in [one of the rooms of] the Lord's palace for three months;
when she is not related to the Lord,
she receives instruction in the rooms of the wife of the head of the major lineage.
The Lord of the state, in taking one of the concubines of his great officer,
or the wife of his common officer, who is aged and has no childred, but possesses good knowledge of the duties of a wife,
related to him [nearer than] in the fifth degree in the rooms of the head of the major lineage.
It is only natural that the great officer or the common officer, in his own group of lineage,
[has his female relatives taught also] in the rooms of the head of the major lineage [that they may] learn how to serve others.
Why should a woman have a teacher and a duenna?
It is to honour her.
The Chūn qiū says:
"The teacher has come,
but not yet the duenna".
The wife learns to serve her parents-in-law,
and not to serve her husband,
because wife and husband constitute one body.
The Lǐ nèi zé says:
"The secondary wife serves the principal wife
as [the latter] serves her parents-in-law.
It originates from [the wish] to honour the first wife and to avoid jealousy".
The Lǐ fú zhuàn says:
"The secondary wife serves the principal wife in the same way as [the latter] serves her parents-in-law".
The wife serves her husband
according to four principles.
[Firstly,] on the first crowing of the cock
she washes her hands and rinses her mouth,
she combs her hair, draws over it a scarf of silk, fixes it with a pin, and fastens it, then she meets [her husband]:
this is the principle of [the relation of] Lord and subject.
[Secondly,] she feels affection [for him to such a degree that his loss results in] deep sorrow:
that is the principle of [the relation of] father and son.
[Thirdly,] she keeps account of what there is and of what there is not:
this is the principle of [the relation of] elder and younger brother.
[Fourthly,] within the doors [of the women's apartments]
she sits with him on the mat:
that is the principle of [the relation of] friends.
[On each occasion she] hears [him or] sees [him, she uses] different words.
Therefore these [rules] have been established.
There are five [cases] in which [a man] does not take a girl as his wife.
He does not marry a girl of an unruly family,
nor one of a licentious family.
He does not marry a girl of a family which has convicts in it,
or a girl suffering from an incurable disease,
or a grown-up girl who is in mourning for the wife [of her father].
In these cases he does not take a girl as his wife.
When a wife is divorced the proper attitude is to accompany her [or have her accompanied by a messenger to her original home],
where she is received with the rites [appropriate] for a guest.
A Noble Man divorcing [his wife observes rites which are] more than the [blunt] handing over by a common man [of his divorced wife to her parents].
The Shī says:
"[Not far, only a little way] did he accompany me to the threshold".
Why is the spouse of the Son of Heaven called hòu?
Hòu means
Lord jūn.
The spouse of the Son of Heaven is the most honourable [of the women],
so that she is called hòu 'Lord',
meaning that as mate to the most honourable [King] she is the Little Lord within the seas.
What
do [the words] qī 'principal wife', and qiè 'concubine' mean?
Qī means
'whole' qí.
[The wife forms] one whole body with her husband.
From the Son of Heaven down to the common man
[the word qī is used with] the same meaning.
Qiè means
'to connect' jiē.
[The concubine] at regular times meets the man for connection.
What
do [the words] jià-qǔ 'marriage' mean?
Jià means
home jiā.
The wife comes from outside to another house
to make it her home.
Qǔ means
to take qǔ.
What
do [the words] nán-nǚ 'man and woman' mean?
Nán means
to be charged with rèn.
He is charged with the task of completing an undertaking.
Nǚ means
to conform to rú.
She follows and conforms to another.
In her home she follows her parents,
who married she follows her husband,
when her husband is dead she follows her son.
The Zhuàn says:
"A woman's duty is to follow [others in] three [cases]".
What
do [the words] fū-fù 'husband and wife' means?
[The first] fū means
to support fú.
To support with the principles [required] of man.
[The second] fù means
to submit fú.
To submit to the duties of home,
and to serve others.
Fēi means
mate pǐ.
What do [the words] fēi-pǐ mean?
That they are each other's mates.
What
do [the words] hūn-yīn mean?
Hūn meanst hat
the rites [of meeting the bride] are performed at dusk hūn.
Therefore it is spoken of as hūn.
Yīn means that
the woman becomes his wife by following her husband.
Therefore it is spoken of as yīn.
The Shī says: "Thou hast no regard for the old alliance".
This was said with respect [to the alliance of the woman]to the husband.
[The Shī says] again: "Thou feastest thy newly-wedded [wife]".
This was said with respect [to the alliance of the man] to the wife.
Why are the rites performed at dusk?
In order to indicate that the yang descends to the yin.
Dusk is also the time that the yin and the yang intermingle.
Why is it that a man at sixty closes the [door of his] bed-chamber?
It is that he may take care of his feebleness.
He thus pays attention to his life['s strength].
The Lǐ nèi zé says:
"A concubine though she is old,
if she has not yet reached the age of fifth,
must cohabit with [her master] every five days".
[When she has reached the] age of fifty she does not visit [her master any more,
the abstinence] for both being helpful to [their mutually growing] feebleness.
When a man is seventy he has reached the stage of dotage:
he cannot relish food without meat,
he cannot get warm in bed without a bed-mate.
Therfore at seventy he opens the [door of his] bed-chamber again [for his bed-mate to enter].
What
does fú 'knee-cover' mean?
Fú means
bì 'to cover';
to cover the front [part of the legs] when walking.
It is used on [special] occasions to distinguish between the higH and the lowly,
and to signal out those who have spiritual power.
The Son of Heaven wears vermillion knee-covers,
the Feudal Lords red ones.
The Shī says:
"His vermillion knee-covers [will be] brilliant,
[he will be] the ruler of a Hereditary House".
Further it says:
"There are red knee-covers and gold-adorned slippers;
the meeting [of the Lords] is grand".
Again:
"There are red knee-covers over their upper-legs".
This was all said of the Feudal Lords.
The Shū speaks of
'Embroidered clothes and light vermillion knee-covers",'
which was also said of the Feudal Lords.
Although they made visible the design of their garments,
so that they could be distinguished from a distance. What is called 'light vermillion' is the same as 'red'.
Great officers wear green stone-pendants [with their knee-covers],
so that they can be distinguished from the Lords. ((to distinguish them from??...CH)
[Thus] a great officer of the Son of Heaven wears red knee-covers with gree stone-pendants.
Common officers wear leather knee-covers dyed [red].
Vermillion and red
are the fullest colours.
Therefore the Sages, patterning themselves on them, used them for the knee-covers in their dress,
which was not to be changed in a hundred Dynasties.
The knee-cover is made of hide
because [the meaning is] to revert to antiquity, so as not to forget the origin.
Above it has a width of one foot,
below of two feet,
modelling itself on Heaven['s number, which is] one, and on Earth['s number, which is] two.
Its length is three feet,
modelling itself on Heaven, Earth, and Man.
Why [does a man] wear a 'cap' guān?
Guān means
juan 'to gather'.
[With the cap] the hair is gathered and secured.
Man harbours the Five Constant [virtues],
and there is none who does not esteem spiritual power.
It means that for the perfection of his rites there should be ornaments and embellishments.
Therefore the cap is instituted to adorn the head,
so as to distinguish [the former youth] as an adult man.
The Shì guān jīng says:
"He receives his cap and style
that his personal name [may from now on] be respected".
The Lún yǔ says:
"Five or six capped young men,
and six or seven youths".
Why is it that according to the rites [a boy may be] capped when he is nineteen, and when there happens to be an 'auspicious moment' jiàn-zhèng?
He is a man who is nearing his twentieth year.
A male belongs to the yang[,
but] completes [his manhood] in [the number of] the yin.
Therefore he is capped at twenty.
The Qǔ lǐ says:
"At twenty [a man is called] ruò 'young';
he is then capped".
Since the expression jiàn-zhèng is used,
how do we know that zhēng-yuè 'the first month of the year' is not meant?
Because the Lǐ shì guāng jīng says:
"[When the capping ceremony takes place in summer] the boy wears hempen shoes,
when in winter [he wears] shoes of leather".
It means [that the capping does] not always [take place] in the first month of the seasonal year.
What
does pí-biàn 'cap of deer-skin' mean?
It is the name of the plainest cap,
by means of which one models oneself on antiquity.
Biàn means pān 'to secure'.
With [the deer-skin cap] the hair is secured.
The time of the highest antiquity was primitive,
and the skin [of beasts] was as first used as clothes.
[For the cap of skin] the deer-skin was used because of its ornamentation.
The Lǐ says:
"All the Three Dynasties [Xià, Yīn, and Zhōu] used the cap of deer-skin and the 'white silk nether-garments gathered at the waist' sù-jī".
Sù-jī means that
the silk is 'gathered' jī to serve as nether-garments,
that is, it is gathered at the waist.
[It represents] the plainest dress which should never be changed:
a reverting to antiquity, so as not to forget the origin.
It is worn both
at war and during the hunt.
What is the má-miǎn 'hempen cap'?
It is the cap [worn] in the ancestral temple under the Zhōu.
The Lǐ says:
"The Zhōu used the miǎn [cap] at the sacrifice [in the ancestral temple]".
It further says:
"The Yīn used the xǔ [cap],
the Xià the shōu [cap] at the sacrifice".
These were the caps [worn] in the ancestral temple during [each of] the Three Dynasties.
In the eleventh month
the yang-fluid inclines and titles up its head, under the Yellow Sources
the ten thousand things are being urged [to unfold, and they are titled up] like a miǎn [cap],
up in front and down at the back.
Therefore [the cap is] called miǎn.
The name xǔ means that
in the twelfth month
the yang-fluid takes its turn; it 'expands' xǔ-zhāng
in order afterwards to attain [its strength to make the ten thousand things] sprout out.
Therefore [the cap is] called xǔ.
The name shōu means that
in the thirteenth month
the yang-fluid 'gathers' shōu its original [strength],
and revivifies the ten thousand things, pushing them out.
Therefore [the cap is] called shōu.
The inclining and the title-up [of the yang] are not the same;
therefore the front and the back [of the miǎn cap] form an irregularity;
in the period [of the eleventh month] the things also [show irregularities; the yang] expands; therefore [the xǔ cap] greatly 'sprouts out' méng;
in the period [of the twelfth month] the things also obtain large 'sprouts' méng-yá.
[The yang] gathers and drivers out;
therefore [the shōu cap] gathers together at the front
and is large at the back;
in the period [of the thirteenth month] the things also first gather together [in order to produce their later fruits].
The miǎn [cap] is made of hemp
because [hemp] represents the first of woman's handicrafts.
It indicates that one should not forget the origin.
If this be so,
why is not skin used?
Skin is the apperal used in the highest antiquity when rites and refinement were still lacking.
Therefore the Lún yǔ says:
"[The wearing of] the hempen cap
is according to the rites".
The Shàng shū says:
"The King put on his hempen cap".
Why is it that with the miǎn [cap] from the front and from the back long pendants are suspended from the rectangular level on top?
It indicates the promotion of the worthy and the rejection of the unable.
The hanging beads means that
[the wearer] closes his eyes to perversities
and shuts his ears [to calumnies];
it indicates that he does not listen to vilifications.
Therefore: if water is [too] clear it will have no fish,
if man is [too] critical, he will have no company.
It means that [the superior] should not value an over-exact knowledge of the inferior.
Therefore the Lǐ says:
"The Son of Heaven wears twelve long pendants of beads of jade
hanging down from the rectangular level on top before and behind".
The Lǐ qì says:
"The Son of Heaven wears a hempen cap
with twelve pendants of vermillion and green beads of jade,
modelling himself on the four seasons and the twelve months;
the Feudal Lords have nine,
the great officers seven pendants;
the common officers wear a jué-bià4n without pendants".
What is the wěi-mào?
It is the name of the cap worn in the Zhōu court when regulating the affairs of state
and putting in practise the spiritual power [which proceeds] from the Way.
The Shī guān jīng says:
"The wěi-mào was in use with the Zhōu,
the zhāng-fǔ with the Yīn,
the wù-zuī with the Xià".
Why [is the cap of the Zhōu] called wěi-mào?
The Zhōu took for the regulation [of the year] the eleventh month as the beginning.
The ten thousand things [then] begin to form small buds.
Therefore for the cap-ornament the smallest [sharp is taken],
which is for that reason called wěi-mào.
Wěi-mào means
having the shape of something 'small and petty' wěi-qǔ.
The Yīn took for the regulation [of the year] the twelfth month as the beginning.
The ornament [of the Yīn cap] is a little larger;
therefore it is called zhāng-fǔ.
Zhāng-fǔ means
not yet having fully reached the standard of the origin.
The Xià took for the regulation [of the year] the thirteenth month as the beginning.
The ornament [of the Xià cap] is the largest,
therefore it is called wú-zuī.
Wú-zuī means
that its size is large.
What does jué-biàn mean?
[It means that] the colour [of the cap] is like that of the head of the [bird] jué.
It is the cap worn in the Zhōu by the common officer [when he assisted] in the ancestral temple.
The Lǐ jiān tè shēng says: "Under the Zhōu [the cap was called] biàn".
The Shì guān jīng says: "Under the Zhōu [the cap was called] biàn;
under the Yīn xǔ;
under the Xià shōu".
How do we know that jué denotes the colour?
Because sometimes [the cap is] called jué-biàn,
sometimes only biàn.
Why is the colour of the cap under the Zhōu [the colour of the bird] jué?
Because the Zhōu honoured [the colour] red.
Why is it not plain red,
but [the colour of] the head of the jué [bird]?
Because originally the design of the caps modelled itself on Heaven,
whose colour is black; [it was desirable that] its substantial nature should not be neglected.
Therefore the Zhōu added red [to the black colour of Heaven],
the Yīn added white [to it],
whereas the colour of the cap under the Xià was plain black.
How do we know that the Yīn added white?
As the Zhōu[, honouring the colour red,] had added red
so we know that the Yīn[, honouring the colour white,] added white.
Why is it that before the Xià and the Yīn the [cotton] caps of the common officer were indifferently [used for all occassions]?
It is because [the custom in the highest] antiquity was primitive.
We know it from the Shì guān lǐ.
Why is it that the Feudal Lords wear the three years' mourning in unhemmed sackcloth for the Son of Heaven?
"Under the wide Heaven
there is no land which is not the King's,
of all the guests on the earth
there is none who is not the King's subject".
The subject is towards his Lord
as the son is towards his father,
that is: [there is between them] the relation of the most exalted
and the subject and son.
The Sàng fú jīng says:
"The Feudal Lords wear the three years' mourning in unhemmed sackcloth for the Son of Heaven".
The Son of Heaven for the Feudal Lords....
Why do the Son of Heaven and the Feudal Lords cut off the one year's mourning?
It means that they love the Hundred Clans equally,
and that they do not limit themselves to loving their relatives.
Therefore the Lǐ zhōng yōng says:
"The one year's mourning extends up to the great officers,
the three year's mourning extends to the Son of Heaven".
The Minister and the great officer [obtain the right of] reducing the mourning period [for some of their relatives] to three months
in order to honour their public position.
Why is it that according to the rites
the 'common man who is officially employed' wears the three months' mourning in 'hemmed sackcloth' for the Lord of the state,
and at the death of the King
the common people in the capital mourn for three months?
The people are lowly, whereas the King is exalted;
therefore the favours [he bestows on them] are small,
so that they can suffice with no more than three months [of mourning].
Since the Son of Heaven is buried seven months,
and a Feudal Lord five months [after their deaths],
the people [after the news of death] begin to weep and wear plain clothes.
Three months before the funeral they put on the hemmed sackcloth,
and after the prescribed months [of mourning], following the funeral of the Lord, they have accomplished their ritual [duties].
Since the rites do not affect the common man,
why are mourning clothes devised for the people?
The [meaning of the] rites not affecting the common man
is that there are [different] standards and regulations.
[But] mourning garments
are the outward expressions of the inner feelings,
therefore they are devised for them [also].
Why is it that at the death of the King
the subjects put on their mourning garments according to [a prescribed] order?
The favours [of the King] have been great or small, extensive or limited;
therefore the regulation [varies] from days to months.
The Tán gōng jì says:
"The third day after the death of the Son of Heaven
the 'officers of prayer' as the first put on their mourning garments,
on the fifth day the heads of the departments follow,
on the seventh day the men and women in the King's domain follow,
and in the course of three months all under Heaven have assumed their mourning garments".
Why does the three years' mourning last twenty-five months?
Because the people of antiquity were primitive,
and, fearing the dead,
"did not raise mounds neither planted trees [on their graves];
they had no fixed period for mourning",
and, when they forgot, they [simply] discarded [their mourning clothes].
The Sages of later ages, in conformity with [the fact that] the ten thousand things [created] by Heaven and Earth [in one year] have their beginning and end,
established for them institutions
according to which [the mourning] expired after a term of one round year.xxx???
[But] the father is the most exalted
while the mother is the most beloved,
therefore an 'extension' [of the mourning period] is made, so that the filial son may exhaust his feelings of affection.
As his affection and love are most profound
the extension amounts to a redoubing.
Therefore [his mourning period] lasts two terms of one year, that is twenty-five months.
The rites take [their norm] from [the number of] three.
Therefore [this mourning is] called three years[' mourning]
because [the period of twenty-five months] approaches the fluid of the third year.
Therefore the Chūn qiū zhuàn says:
"The mourning term of three calendrical years
is in reality twenty-months".
Why is it that in the three years' mourning period the intercalary month is not counted?
Because of the use of the term qī 'round year'.
Qī means
covering the [full] time.
The mourning periods of nine months and less is counted by months,
therefore the intercalary month is substracted.
The Lǐ shì yú jīng says:
"After one round year theSmall Auspicious Sacrifice is performed,
after two round years the Great Auspicious Sacrifice".
Why is it that for the mourning rites the wearing of sackcloth is prescribed?
It is to bring it into accordance with one's fellings.
Clothes are the adornments of one's emotions.
Emotions and appearance should match each other,
the interior and the exterior should correspond with each other.
Therefore the clothes are not alike for joy and for grief,
the voice is not alike in singing and in wailing.
[Each is] the expression of one's inner sincerity.
The coat and shirt of sackcloth,
the hempen fillets,
the bamboo hairpin,
the hatstrings of cord,
and the coarse staff
are [all] indications of a reverting to the origin.
The fillets
indicate that there has been a disaster,
and used together [with the other things]
they indicate that it is a case of death.
The waist-fillet
replaces the large girdle with sashes.
Why is it tied in a knot?
[The son] thinks with reverential [affection of the deceased], and his feelings are such that they seem to be tied in a knot.
Why must there be two knots?
It means that the affection is never-ending.
Why must [the chief-mourner] carry a staff?
The filial son, having lost his parent,
was so afflicted with grief that during three days he could not eat
but only weep;
his body [consequently] became emaciated and ill.
Therefore he carries a staff to support himself,
meaning that he should not on behalf of the dead endanger his life.
According to the rites
neither a young boy nor a wife are required to carry a staff
because they cannot [bear the hardships of extreme] suffering.
The Lǐ says:
"He who wears the three years' mourning in unhemmed sackcloth does not take food for three days;
he who wears the three years' mourning in hemmned sackcloth does not take food for two days;
he who wears the nine months' mourning does not take food for one day;
he who wears the five months' mourning or the three months' mourning
does not take two meals in one day, such being a sufficient [abstinence]".
Why is the staff made of bamboo or of the [wood of the] tóng [tree]?
The names [of these plants] are taken [as symbols].
'Bamboo' zhú means
cù 'to stamp the feet'.
Tóng means
tòng 'grieved'.
Why is a staff of bamboo used for [the death of] the father,
and a staff of the tóng wood for [that of] the mother?
Bamboo
is yang,
the tóng [wood]
is yin.
Why is bamboo yang?
A bamboo[-stem] is [simply] cut to be used [as a staff];
it is primitive
and so represents the yang.
[A branch of] the tóng [tree] has its bark removed before it is used [as a staff];
it undergoes
dressing by human skill,
and so it is yin.
Therefore the Lǐ says:
"The coarse staff is of bamboo,
the staff without bark is of tóng [wood]".
Why must [the mourner] occupy a mourning shed?
The filial son is so grieved
that he does not wish to hear the voices of the people,
neither does he wish to live in the dwellin where the disaster has taken place;
[therefore] he takes up his abode outside the middle gare,
building a hut by propping beams [against the wall.
The structure should be] promitive, and [means] a reverting to antiquity.
Why [is the hut] not placed outside the [outer] gate?
To avoid unforeseen dangers.
Therefore the Lǐ xián zhuàn says:
"During the mourning for his father or his mother
[the son] dwells lin the mourning shed".
This shed is situated outside the middle gate, below the eastern wall,
with an opening facing north.
[After one year when he has adopted the cap of] bleached silk he dwells in the unplastered chamber,
which is a room without any adornments.
It is further said:
"The wife does not dwell in the mourning shed".
Again:
"For the Son of Heaven the mourning garments are fully assumed seven days [after his death],
for a Ducal Minister or a Feudal Lord five days,
for a Minister or a great officer three days [after the death]".
[The mourner] dwells [in the mourning shed] inside the outer gate, having built the hut below the eastern wall.
He sleeps on rough straw with a clod for his pillow,
wailing unceasingly,
and not taking off his head-fillet or girdle.
After the yú [sacrifice]
he sleeps on a mat,
eats coarse food
and drinks water,
wailing only once in the morning
and once in the evening.
After he has assumed the cap of bleached silk
he takes up his abode in the outer chamber,
living in the unplastered room;
he begins to enjoy [again] vegetables and fruit,
and eats his ordinary dishes,
while he wails unceasingly [whenever he thinks of the deceased].
In the twenty-fifth month [after the death] the Great Auspicious Sacrifice is performed,
he then drinks unfermented wine
and eats dried meat.
In the twenty-seventh month the tán [sacrifice] is performed,
which may take place at the same time as the [seasonal] sacrifices in the ancestral temple;
[then he] puts off the last vestiges of his mourning.
Why is it that according to the rites [the mourner does] not speak during his period of mourning?
He thinks with reverential [affection of the deceased], and cherishes the deepest feelings of sorrow.
[This, however, means that during the time of mourning the mourner does] not use cultivated language in his speech,
which applies to the common officers and the people.
[He who can afford] not to speak [at all] while his affairs are completely attended to [by others] is the Lord of a state.
The Ministers and great officers carrying their [mourning] staff [have to speak with and] see off their guests.
Those whose possessions are few depend on their own strength;
wearing a livid countenance they manage everything personally.
For those who [can afford] not to speak [at all] their affairs are managed [by others];
so that they can wail and give the fullest expression to their feelings [of grief].
Why is it that when the mourner is afflicted with sickness
he is allowed to drink wine and eat meat?
It is that he may support his life's strength,
and so honour the body his ancestors have left to him.
Therefore the Qǔ lǐ says:
"During the observance of the mourning rites,
if [the mourner have] a scab on his head he should wash it;
if he have a sore on his body he should bathe it;
if he be ill he should drink wine and eat meat;
if he be fifty he should not allow himself to be reduced [by his abstinence] very much;
if he be sixty not at all.
At seventy he will only wear the unhemmed dress of sackcloth,
and will drink wine and eat meat".
It further says:
"When his father or mother is ill [a young man who has been capped]
should not eat so much meat that his taste is changed,
neither should he drink so much wine that his countenance is changed;
he should not laugh so as to show his teeth
nor be angry till he breaks forth in revilling;
he should not touch his qín or sè [lutes]".
The Zēng zǐ wèn says:
"When [a son is] wearing the three years' mourning,
[even after one year when he has put on his cap of] bleached silk,
he should not be standing in a company [of friends],
neither should he go along in a crowd.
The rites are the adornments of the sentiments;
would it not be an empty form
to condole and wail [with others] while wearing the three year's mourning?"
The LI3 tán gōng says:
"Zēng-zǐ, while wearing mourning for his mother,
paid a visit of condolence at the death of Zǐ-zhāng".
Zǐ-zhāng was his friend,
and for a mourner,
though wearing deep mourning,
it is right to pay a visit of condolence [at the death of a friend].
The Zhēng zǐ wèn says:
"[Zēng-zǐ asked:] If one wears the five months' mourning is he allowed to participate in sacrifices [for a deceased person]?
Confucius said:
It is according to the rites that
those wearing mourning for three years in unhemmed sackcloth and less do so".
This refers to the mourning sacrifices for the Lord.
Zǐ-xià asked:
"It is according to the rites
if one does not seek to escape military service,
after the wailing
in the three years' mourning has come to an end?"
Confucius said:
I heard Lǎo Dān say that
Bó-qín,
the Duke of Lǔ,
once engaged [in such a service] when there was occasion for it.
[But] if now during a three years' mourning one follows one's advantage [by entering military service],
I do not know [if I should allow it]".
The wife does not cross the boundaries [of the state of her husband] to pay a visit of condolence
because she has no business outise [her home].
It is to avoid [the danger of] debauchery.
The Lǐ zá jì says:
"It is not according to the rites that
the wife cross the boundaries [of the state of her husband] for a visit of condolence".
If she has to wear the three years' mourning [for one of her parents]
the Lord goes together with her.
According to the rites,
if a wife wears mourning for her parents
her husband also assumes mourning.
Why are there three cases in which condolence is not required?
As a subject and the son of a man
one should constantly observe prudence, care,
and forethought,
and [always] attend to the preservation of one's life.
If now a person shoule meet his death 'through being killed in a roit' wèi, 'through being crushed' yā, or 'through being drowned' nì
it is considered to be a naglect of his duty;
therefore no condolence is required.
Wèi means
meeting one's death from weapons.
The Lǐ zēng zǐ jì says:
"A man who has brought great shame upon himself
and cause his body to be maimed [in a punishment]
is not considered to be the servant [of his Lord] anymore,
neither are the common officers willing to have intercouse with him.
In the sacrifices to the ancestors he is no longer employable as an impersonator,
he is not allowed to partake of the sacrificial vistims in the ancestral temple,
and when he dies he is not buried in the precincts of the ancestral temple".
A disciple wears mourning for his teacher
because his relation to him is that of Lord to subject,
of father to son,
of friend to friend.
Therefore during [the teacher's] life he honours and reveres him with affection,
when he is dead he grieves and sorrows for him.
His affection is deep, his feeling of duty profound.
Therefore he wears deep mourning for him.
At home he wears the [head-and-waist] fillets,
outside he leaves them off.
The Tán gōng says:
"[Zǐ-gòng says:] Formerly, when our Master was mourning for Yán Huí
he acted as if he was mourning for a son, [only] he did not wear mourning dress.
He did the same in the case of Zǐ-lù.
Let us mourn for our Master as we should mourn for our fathers, but wear no mourning dress".
The Zēng zǐ wèn says:
"[Zēng-z93 asked:] If, when the ruler has died and is lying in his coffin,
an officer is informed of the death of his father or mother
what should be done?
Confucius said:
He should go home and remain there;
for the great services [to the deceased ruler] he should go to his Lord's place,
but not for those of every morning and evening.
[Zēng-zǐ] asked:
If, when they have begun to move the ruler['s coffin],
an officer is informed of the death of his father or mother
what should be done?
Confucius said:
He should go home and wail,
and then return and accompany [the funeral of] his Lord.
[Zēng-zǐ] asked:
If, before the ruler has been encoffined, an officer is informed of the death of his father or mother
what should be done?
Confucius said:
He should go home and have the deceased put int the coffin,
and then return to the ruler's place;
for the great services [to the deceased parent] he should go home,
but not for those of every morning and evening.
If [the officer] is a great officer
the chief servant of his household will attend to [his private] affairs;
if he is a common officer
his son or grandson.
The wife of a great officer,
on the occasion of the great services [to the deceased ruler],
will also go to the ruler's place,
but not for those of every morning and evening".
Why is it that if a Feudal Lord who is wearing mourning for his parents
is informed of the death of the Son of Heaven
he hastens to take part in the funeral rites [for the latter]?
It expresses the idea that he subordinates
[his grief for the loss of] his own parents to his fidelity to the Exalted One.
The Chūn qiū zhuàn says:
"The reason that the death of the Son of Heaven is recorded,
but not his funeral, is that the time for his burial is determined.
The funeral of a Feudal Lord is recorded
because the time for it is not necessarily determined".
As a Feudal Lord at the death of the Son of Heaven
is in duty bound to hasten [and take part in the funeral rites even if he is in mourning for his parent],
the time of the burial [of his deceased parent] cannot always be determined.
When a great officer, charged with a mission [by his Lord], has started [his journey],
and is informed of the death of his father or mother,
he only returns upon the order of his Lord:
that is his [expression of] esteem for his ruler.
The Chūn qiū zhuàn says:
"When a great officer, having started his journey on a mission from his Lord,
is informed of the death [of his parent]
he proceeds without haste and does not return".
Why is it that a Feudal Lord who is on his way to a court-visit
is allowed to return when he is informed of the death of his own [parent]?
It expresses the idea that one is not to enter the palace-gates in mourning dress,
neither should the Lord summon [his subject when he is in mourning].
Not to dare to enter the palace-gates in mourning dress
indicates reverence for the court;
luck and disaster do not go together.
Therefore the Zhōu guān says:
"When one is in mourning dress one should not enter the palace-gates".
The Qǔ lǐ says:
"When one is in mourning one does not speak of music;
when one is directing a sacrifice one does not speak of unlucky things;
when one is at court one does not speak of wife or daughters".
The Lún yǔ says:
"The Master did not sing on the same day
in which he had been weeping".
When a subject is wearing deep mourning
[his Lord should] not knock at his door [to summon him]
because he allows him to terminate his duties as a filial son
and to consummate his great [mourning] rites.
The Chūn qiū zhuàn says:
"Anciently, when a Minister was wearing deep mourning
his ruler did not knock at his door for three years".
Why is it that when [a Lord is] informed of the death [of his parent]
he wails before beginning the journey [home]?
It is to exhaust his grief; he only starts after his first sorrow has somewhat abated.
Seeing the boundaries of his state he weeps again,
but passing the market and the palace he does not:
for the Noble Man restrains himself
that the small man may [also] make an effort to come up to the [required] decorum.
[On his way] he stops when he sees the stars;
each day he covers one hundred lǐ.
His anguished heart
only thinks of seeing the corpse in the coffin as soon as possible.
Therefore the Lǐ bèn sāng jì says:
"With lamentations he responds t the notifier,
thus giving full vent to his grief;
he inquires of the cause [of the death],
and then sets out on his way".
Zēng-zǐ says:
"An army moves thirty lǐ [a day,
the bringer of] lucky news moves fifty lǐ,
[the son] hurrying home to attend the funeral [of his parent] moves one hundred lǐ [a day]".
Why is it that when the mourning proves to have already ended
[by the time the son] returns he goes to the grave to weep?
It means that he feels the deepest sorrow
because he cannot see the deceased again.
As mourning cannot be assumed after [the period after it has expired]
he only weeps and leaves it at that.
Therefore the Lǐ bèn jì says:
"He goes to the grave,
faces west, and weeps, and [there the mourning] ends".
This means that having returned from afar [he finds that] the burial has already taken place,
and the wearing of mourning has been ended according to the rites.
Zēng-zǐ was standing by the door [of his house] with a visitor
when [one of the latter's] companions went out in a hurry.
Zēng-zǐ asked:
"Where art thou going?"
[The disciple] replied:
"My father has died,
and I am going to wail for him in the lane".
Zēng-zǐ said:
"Return and wail in thy apartment [in my house]".
Zēng-zǐ [then] paid him a visit of condolence, [standing with] his face to the north.
The Tán gōng jì says:
"Confucius said:
Where shall I wail for him?
For brethren
I wail outside the gate of the ancestral temple,
for a teacher
in my chamber,
for a friend
outside the door of the chamber,
for an acquaintance
in the open country".
Since upbringing follows [the statues in which] one was born,
and burial follows [the status in which] one has died,
why was the Duke of Zhōu buried with the royal rites?
Because the Duke of Zhōu had [acted as the Son of Heaven, and had] ascended the eastern steps.
In his direction of the government [of the state] he was in accordance with the intentions of Heaven.
He expended and brought to prosperity the way of the Zhōu [Dynasty].
He made manifest the measures and numbers of Heaven,
[as a consequence of which] the ten thousand things all obtained [their proper attendance],
and the magnificent fluid penetrated
[everything, all in accordance with] the intent of primordial Heaven.
The [people's] filial love for the Duke of Zhōu
was not different from that for [King] Wén and [King] Wǔ;
therefore he was buried with the royal rites,
and was accorded the sacrifice in the suburb.
The Shàng shū says:
"Now Heaven has moved its terrors to display the spiritual power of the Duke of Zhōu".
Hereafter [the Shàng shū continues] saying: "The [royal] rites [with which he was treated] therefore befitted him".
The Shàng shū says:
"King Chéng 'died'".
Why is the term bēng used to denote [the death of] the Son of Heaven [whereas different terms are used for all other persons]?
It is to distinguishe between the high and the lowly,
to differentiate [their status in] life [as well as after] death.
Bēng used for the Son of Heaven
is the expression of something great and exalted.
Bēng means that
the Son of Heaven like a collapsing mountain lies prostrate,
so that all under Heaven are struck and lose their wits,
which means that the people weep in distress,
and grief and sadness prevail throughout all within the seas.
The term for [the death of] a Feudal Lord is hōng,
[which means that] the state has lost its yang.
Hōng (die) means yǎn 'suddenly', (basically refers to the suddenness CH??)
[that is] suddenly to pass away.
The term for [the death of] a great officer is zú;
the essential and sparkling [stuff] has come to an end.
Zú indicates that he is finished for the state.
The term for [the death of] a common officer is bú-lù;
he does not continue to the end the service to his Lord.
Lù means xiāo 'to consume';
while he consumes his body [in the service of his Lord] his name attains glory.
The term for [the death of] the comman man is sǐ;
his spirit and soul escape and disappear.
Sǐ means sī 'exhausted';
the essential [stuff and the] breath have exhausted themselves.
Why is it that the death of the Son of Heaven and that of a Feudal Lord are recorded in [the annals of] the states?
Because there are rites for the high and the lowly,
and regulations for post-humous names and appellations; therefore there are [records of them].
The [institution of] rites began with Huáng-dì,
and was completed under Yáo and Shùn.
In the Yì [death is] denoted as mò
because [the statement was] based on [the tradition of] distant antiquity.
The Shū speaks of zǔ-lào [for the death of Yáo], and sǐ [for the death of Shùn];
for both the meaning is self-evident.
With Yáo [the meaning is to be] seen from [the point of view of] his ending [his life],
but both [convey the] same [sense].
What does sàng mean?
Sàng means
wáng 'to disappear'.
Why is sàng used to denote the death of a man?
It expresses the idea that he has disappeared,
and is not seen again.
Why is it not just said that he was 'died' sǐ,
but is the term sàng used [instead]?
The feelings [of love] of the filial son prevent him from using the word [sǐ 'die'].
The Shàng shū says:
"When King Wǔ has 'passed away' sàng....".
The Shàng lǐ jīng says:
"The dead lies in an apartment of the principal hall".
We know [by this] that the dead is spoken of as 'to have passed away' sàng.
Grief and mourning of the living are also denoted by the term sàng.
The Lǐ speaks [in the chapter]
'Mourning Garments' Sàng fú of 'the unhemmed sackcloth'.
The Yì says:
"They did not raise mounds neither did they plant trees [on their graves]
nor had they any fixed period of mourning".
The Xiào jīng says:
"The mourning of a filial son for his parent".
These [are all instances where the term sàng] applies to the living.
Why is the term sàng used [indiscriminately]
for the Son of Heaven down to the common man?
It expresses the idea that all men have received their bodies, their hair, and their skin from their parents,
and that their suffering is the same.
Why is it that the death of the Son of Heaven
is announced to the Feudal Lords?
Because when the subjects and sons have lost their Lord
their grief and mourning are so overwhelming
that they cannot but communicate them to others.
It is desirable that the Feudal Lords be informed of [the death],
so that they can use the produce of their lands to contribute to the mourning sacrifices.
Therefore the Lǐ says:
"When the Son of Heaven dies
an envoy is sent
to announce [the death] to the Feudal Lords".
Why is it that at the death of the King
the Feudal Lords hasten to the [place of] mourning?
Being [the King's] subjects and sons they are so much afflicted by grief and sorrow
that none of them does not wish to see their Lord-and-father's coffin
[at the side of which] they may exhaust their [feelings of] woe.
[However,] the frontiers they have to guard for the Son of Heaven
cannot be left undefended.
Therefore they divide themselves into three groups:
there are those who immediately after the death hasten [to the palace of the Son of Heaven];
there are those who delay their coming until the middle [of the period at which time they can] exhaust their [feelings of] grief;
there are those who wait until the gathering of the mourners who are to escort the Lord [to his grave].
Within the period of seven months
[in this way] there have been among the Feudal Lords those who in the capital personally assisted in the [first] sacrifices [incumbent] on a subject and son;
there have been those who gave vent to their [feelings of] sorrow by wailing along the roads while they hastened [to the capital],
and there have been those who stayed in their states wailing and mourning,
and reverently exerted themselves to devise means by which to contribute to the funeral sacrifices.
Within the four seas all are immersed in grief:
it means that [all] the subjects are mourning [for the Son of Heaven] as they would have done for their fathers and mothers.
At the funeral there is a gathering [of Feudal Lords,
that is:] near and distant relatives, and [those whose abodes are] far and near have come in their entirety;
it is the expression of the principle of loving the relative.
Why is it that a Feudal Lord who, being a youth, is not required to go to court is in duty bound to hasten to the funeral?
It means that the relation between the subject and son and the Lord and father is not [altered] by old age or youth.
Also [it is allowed to such a Feudal Lord to] follow the substance of the mourning [ceremony]
without observing the elaborate rites;
he is only required to exhaust his [feelings of] sorrow.
Why is it that the death of a subject
is announced to his Lord?
Because that Lord should feel sorrow and grief for his subject and son [who has died].
He wishes to be informed of it that he may fulfill the rites of giving presents for the funeral.
Therefore the Chūn qiū says: "Kǎo-fù, Marquis of Cài, dies".
The Zhuàn says:
"The death [of a Feudal Lord] is announced [to the Son of Heaven], but not the funeral".
Why is it that the death of a Feudal Lord
is announced to the neighbour states?
Because these states may wish to take part in the [funeral] rites.
The Chūn qiū zhuàn says:
"The death of the mother of Duke Huán
was announced to the [other] Feudal Lords".
Duke Huán's mother was of a lowly position,
still [her death was] announced to the [other] Feudal Lords;
it is clear that the death of a Feudal Lord
is [certainly] announced to the neighbour states.
The death of the Spouse of a Feudal Lord
is announced to the Son of Heaven
because [the Feudal Lord] dares not of his own accord abstain himself from his ruler's duties.
Moreover, the Son of Heaven may wish to be informed of it
that he may contribute to the [funeral] rites.
The Chūn qiū says:
The King [mandated] by Heaven sent the administrator Xuān to come and present a carriage and horses for the funeral of Duke Huì['s wife] Zhòng-zǐ".
[The Chūn qiū] blames [the fact that the presents were sent] too late.
As Zhòng-zǐ
was [only] the favourite concubine of the Lord of Lǔ,
how much more would it be so with [a Feudal Lord's] Spouse.
When a Feudal Lord dies,
why is his Minister sent to return his Auspicious Jade Tablet to the Son of Heaven?
The Feudal Lord was given the Jade Tablet as [a symbol of his] good faith.
Now he has died,
and his successor will have to spend three years in the mourning shed
before he can again be invested with [his father's] dignites.
Therefore the returning [of the Jade Tablet rests
upon] the principle of relinquishment and cession.
The Lǐ says:
"When a Feudal Lord dies
his Minister is sent to return his Auspicious Jade Tablet to the Son of Heaven".
Why is it that when the Son of Heaven is informed of the death of a Feudal Lord
he wails for him?
It is the manifestation of his [feelings of] sadness,
for he suffers the deepest sorrow.
He then charges a great officer to pay a visit of condolence,
so as to keep the remembrance of the distance [Lord], and to attach importance to the [fact of] death.
Therefore the Lǐ tán gōng says:
"When the Son of Heaven wails for a [deceased] Feudal Lord
he puts on the [cap] jué-biàn and silk garments".
It also says:
"The Son of Heaven sends a great officer to pay a visit of condolence;
his words are:
August Heaven has sent down this calamity,
into which you[, my Lord,]
have by destiny been thrown,
alas!
The King [mandated] by Heaven has sent his servant, So-and-So, to condole with you".
Why is it that at the death of his officer
the Lord goes to pay a visit of condolence?
He was in close relation [with the deceased] in the governing together of the people;
his affection is deep and the relationship weighs heavey,
so that he wishes to see him personally.
Therefore the Lǐ zá ji says:
"When the Lord pays a visit of condolence to his officer
the host waits outside the gate.
When he sees the heads of the horses [of the carriage of the Lord] he stops his weeping.
When the Lord arrives
the host first enters [the house];
the Lord asceds by the eastern steps, faces west, and weeps.
The host, standing in the middle of the hall,
joins in the weeping.
It also says:
'When a great officer is ill
his Lord inquires about him continually;
when a common officer is ill
he only inquires about him once".
At the death of a great officer
"When the time has come for the burial [the Lord does] not taste meat;
when the time has come for the wailing to be stopped he does not have music performed [at his meals].
In the case of [the death of] a common officer, when the time has come to put him into the coffin, [the Lord] abstains from having music performed".
One must not wear a black cap when paying a visit of condolence
because one should not approach people in distress in one's auspicious dress;
it means that one should aid [in the assuaging of] grief.
The Lún yǔ says:
"[The Noble Man does] not wear lamb's fur or a black cap on a visit of condolence".
Why is it that [not until] three days after the death of the Son of Heaven or a Feudal Lord [is the corpse subjected to] the Smaller Dressing?
It is in order that the grief of the filial son may be diminished by degrees.
On the first day of death
a piece of floss-silk is put upon the mouth to watch for the cessation of the breath;
on the second day
it is still hoped that [the deceased] may return to life;
on the third day
[it is certain that] the vital fluid will not come back,
and death is irrevocable.
Therefore the Lǐ shì shàng jīng says:
"Four attendants sit [by the deceased],
prop up his body, and put a piece of floss-silk [on his mouth]
to watch for the cessation of his breath".
The Lǐ says:
"For the Son of Heaven or a Feudal Lord the Smaller Dressing takes place three days [after the death],
for a great officer or a common officer two days.
A piece of floss-silk is put upon the mouth
because the filial son wishes [to see] his parent come to life [again]".
Why is it that the corpse must be washed under the impluvium?
It indicates that the purification takes places according to the original rites.
The Lǐ tán gōng says:
"The dying person lies below the window,
the washing [of the corpse] takes place under the impluvium,
the filling of the mouth blow the window,
the Smaller Dressing inside the door,
the Greater Dressing at the eastern steps,
the encoffining on the guest's seat,
the sacrifice of departure in the courtyard,
the interment in the grave;
in this way the corpse is moved farther and farther away,
and the filial son's grief is diminished by degrees".
Why is the mouth 'filled'?
As a living being he has eaten,
and now that he is dead
his mouth should not be left empty;
therefore it is 'filled'.
Why are pearls and [other] precious things [to put into the mouth of the deceased]?
To add to [the adornment of] the bodily form of the deceased.
Therefore for the Son of Heaven jade is used to put into the mouth,
for a Feudal Lord pearls,
for a great officer a bì,
for a common officer a shell.
What does zèng suì 'to present funeral clothes' mean?
Zèng means chēng 'to complete';
[the presentation of] what is beautiful and loveable is called zèng.
Suì means yí 'to endow';
clothes and covers are called suì.
When one had friendly relations with the deceased one presents funeral clothes
in order to aid the living [son] when he supplies them to the dead.
It is a reminder of affection, [a token of] recognition of the death,
and a correlate of one's deepest feelings.
What does fù-fèng mean?
Fù means
zhù 'to aid';
therewith one aids and gives to him who has not enough.
Fèng means
fù 'to hasten';
therewith one hastens to aid the other.
Therefore we say with respect to [the presents at] the condolence:
when one has friendly relations with the living [son the presentation is called] fù.
[The presentation of] goods and money is called fù,
[the presentation of] a carriage and horses is called fèng.
The Son of Heaven is encoffined seven days [after his death],
a Feudal Lord five days;
the [two] events are different as to their import,
and the sacrifices are not of the same class.
Therefore the Wáng zhì says:
"The Son of Heaven is encoffined seven days,
a Feudal Lord five days,
a Minister or great officer three days [after their deaths]".
Why is it that under the Xià Dynasty the encoffining took place at [the top of] the eastern steps,
under the Yīn between the two pillars [of the steps],
and under the Zhōu at the top of the western steps?
The Xià instructed by 'loyalty'.
Loyalty zhōng means
hòu 'gratitude';
[this was what] they said:
"In life
our father,
in death still our father";
the host [such as he still was] should be at [the top of] the eastern steps.
The Yīn instructed by reverence;
[this was what] they said:
"The deceased is about to depart,
still we dare not treat him as a guest";
therefore they placed him [in the coffin] between the two pillars [of the steps],
where he was honoured as combining the positions of host and guest.
The Zhōu instructed by culture;
[this was what] they said:
"The deceased is about to depart,
and we cannot detain him";
therefore they treated him as a guest[, whose place was the western steps].
The Tán gōng jì says:
"Under the Xià the encoffining took place at [the top of] the eastern steps,
under the Yīn between the two pillars [of the steps],
under the Zhōu at the top of the western steps".
The Qǐ mìng zhēng says:
"Why is the corpse of the Son of Heaven placed in a boat-carriage catafalque?
To guard it against flood or five.
Therefore the coffin is placed upon a carriage,
and the carriage is placed in a boat.
Servants, to the number of twelve hundred men, constantly taking turns, hold the ropes
during the day and night.
These ropes
are to keep the coffin in its place and to pull it".
Therefore the Lǐ says:
"The Son of Heaven has a boat-carriage catafalque,
a Feudal Lord a carriage catafalque,
and a great officer a pallissaded and plastered [coffin];
a common officer is simply buried [in an ordinary coffin]".
This is to distinguish between the high and the lowly.
Why does the 'sacrifice of departure' zǔ take place in the courtyard?
[This is the opportunity for] the filial son to exhaust his feelings of affection.
Zǔ means
shǐ 'to begin';
the beginning is made of the placing [of the coffin] in the carriage in the courtyard.
[Another opinion is:] With the coffin placed on a bier
leave is taken from the 'first ancestor and the deceased father' zǔ-nǐ;
therefore [the sacrifice is] named zǔ-zǎi.
Therefore the Lǐ says:
"The sacrifice of departure takes place in the courtyard,
the interment in the grave".
It also says:
"When they proceed to the ancestors [with the coffin] they ascend by the western steps".
Why are an inner coffin and an outer coffin used?
To conceal the hideous [sight of the dead] body.
It is not desirable that the filial son should witness the [process of] decay.
Guān 'inner coffin' means
wán 'to conserve'.
It confines the corpse and conserves it.
Guǒ 'outer coffin' means kuò 'to enlarge'.
It enlarges [the inner coffin], and prevents the earth
from penetrating into the inner coffin.
The Lǐ wáng zhì says:
"The coffin of the Son of Heaven has nine layers
and his funeral garments consist of one hundred and twenty chēng;
[the coffin of] a Feudal Lord has five layers
and his funeral garments consist of ninety chēng;
a great officer has a large inner coffin with three layers
and his funeral garments consist of fifty chēng;
[the coffin of] a common officer has two layers, but there is no large inner coffin
while his funeral garments consist of thirty chēng.
The inner and outer garments together constitute a chēng".
The LI3 tán gōng[, however,] says:
"The inner coffin of the Son of Heaven has four layers;
the hides of a water-buffaloo and a rhinoceros, overlapping each other
and each being three inches thick,
serve as [the first layer of the] coffin;
[then] there is one coffin [of the wood] of the white poplar[, forming the second layer,]
and two coffins of the catalpa [wood, forming the third and fourth layers]; the outer coffin is made of boards of cypress wood, [in pieces of] six feet long".
Why is it that whereas [in the time of Shùn of] Yú earthenware coffins were used
wood is now employed?
Yú adhered to the Principle of Substance,
and therefore earthenware was used.
The Xià[, adherents of the Principle of Form,] added [some] refinements;
therefore they effected a change by surrounding it with an enclosure of brick,
that is to say: brick and wood enclosed [the coffin]
without the use of glue or varnish.
The Yīn had inner and outer coffins,
and made use of glue and varnish.
The Zhōu, advancing in refinement,
added surrounding curtains and feathery ornaments
by applying their skill in adornment.
The rites for mourning and burial are:
to serve the dead in accordance with [his state when] alive.
What he had not in his lifetime
should not be created after his death.
In the time of the highest antiquity
[the people] lived in caves or dwelt on the plains;
they were clothed in skins and wore girdles of hide.
So, when they died
they were covered with faggots,
under which they were stowed away without any adornments.
In the times of middle antiquity
there came buildings and garments.
Therefore [the corpses were] clad in silk,
and buried in coffins.
A tumulus was raised and trees were planted [on the grave] to make it recognizable [as such].
They treated the [dead] body as if it were alive.
The Xià and the Yīn were more advanced in refinement,
and completed [the funeral rites] by [providing] vessels and implements.
When it came to the Zhōu refinement became great,
[they introduced the principle that] since husband and wife during their life had the same habitation
after death they should be buried together.
What do [the words for 'corpse'] shī and jìu mean?
Shī means
chén 'to stretch out';
when the breath has stopped and the spirit has left
it is only the bodily form that lies stretched out.
Jìu means jīu 'final',
jǐu 'forever';
the dead body will never be removed.
The Qǔ lǐ says:
"[The corpse lying] in the bed is called shī;
in the coffin it is called jìu".
Since a distinction is made in the denotation [of the death of the high and the lowly, such as] by the use of [the words] bēng and hōng,
why is it the same [for all] when it comes to [the burial in] the grave?
In all times the subject and son has the duty of laying his Lord and father
to rest,
and [this duty] apllies to the high as well as to the lowly.
Zàng 'to bury' means xià-zàng 'to put out of sight'.
Why [are the dead buried] in the earth?
Man is born of the yin,
though he contains a charge of the yang.
When he dies he is buried in the earth
that he may return to her who has given him [life].
Why is it that the Son of Heaven is buried seven months,
and Feudal Lord five months [after their deaths]?
To distinguish between the high and the lowly.
"The Son of Heaven is buried seven months [after his death]
by which time all his subjects were expected to be present;
a Feudal Lord is buried five months [after his death]
by which time all his allies were expected to be present".
Thus do they express their [feelings of] solicitude for the deceased and the mourner.
The Lǐ says:
"The officer for the graves is charged with the plans for the burial-grounds.
The grave of the first King
occupies the middle position
with the graves of his son and grandson to his left and right".
All his subjects for the burial follow this order
of [distinguishing between] the high and the lowly.
Why are [husband and wife] buried together?
To complete the union of husband and wife.
Therefore the Shī says:
"Living they occupy different apartments,
dead they share the same hole".
And the Lǐ tán gōng says:
"[Confucius said:] The burying together [of husband and wife]
is not an ancient custom;
it dates from [the time of] the Duke of Zhōu,
and has not been changed since".
Why [is it that man is] buried outside the city walls?
The dead and the living should have different dwellings,
the end and the beginning should occupy different places.
The Yì says: "[In ancient times the dead were] buried in the open country".
In this way an end was made to the reverential thoughts [which had constantly been cherished] by the filial son.
The Zhuàn says:
"Music is performed in the ancestral temple,
but it should not be heard at the grave.
The wailing takes place at the grave,
but it should not be heard in the ancestral temple".
Why [are the dead buried] to the north [of the city]?
They go to the yin[-region].
The Táng gōng says:
"To bury to the north [of the city] and with the head [of the dead] turned to the north was the common practise of the Three Dynasties".
When Confucius died he was buried,
[together] with the huáng jade he had received from the ruler of Lǔ, to the north of the capital of Lǔ.
A tumulus is made and trees are planted [on the grave]
that it may be recognized [as such].
Therefore the Tán gōng says:
"[Confucius said:] In antiquity no mounds were raised over the graves;
now [I,] Qīu,
am a man [who is always travelling] east, west, south, and north,
and it would not do if I could not recognize [my parents' grave].
Thereupon he raised a tumulus over it
four feet high".
The Hán wén jiā says:
"The grave-mound of the Son of Heaven is thirty feet high
with a pine-tree planted on it;
that of a Feudal Lord is half that height
with a cypress planted on it;
that of a great officer is eight feet high
with a luán-tree planted on it;
that of a common officer four feet
with an accacia planted on it;
the common man has no grave-mound,
but a willow is planted [on the grave]".
The King sacrifices to Heaven
according to the same principle as he serves his father.
At the sacrifice the first ancestor must be associated with Heaven.
The Five Emperors and the Three Kings
all used the first month of the Xià calendar for the sacrifice to Heaven (Qián zuò dù).
The sacrifice to Heaven must take place in the 'suburb' jiāo.
