The day for the sacrifice is either a ting-day or a hsin-day (Chūn qiū zhuàn; Shàng shū).
The sacrifice takes place once a year
--so as not to be too intimate with Heaven
--at a time when the yang-fluid begins to reassert itself.
At the sacrifice music is performed.
The Queen is not allowed to take part in the sacrifice (Zhōu guān).
The King erects an 'Ancestral Temple' zōng-miào
where he can serve the dead according to the same principle
as he served the living;
thus his filial piety is expressed and continued.
The zōng-miào
represents the 'venerable appearance' zūn-mào of the ancestors.
The temple has 'apartments' shì.
The sacrifice in the Ancestral Temple consists of the dì and the qiā sacrifices.
The dì sacrifice emphasizes the 'ranging' dì
of the shrines of fathers and sons;
the qiā sacrifice
emphasizes the 'collective' hé
offering to the ancestral tablets in the general shrine.
Every three years there is a dì sacrifice.
The Zhōu had a temple with seven shrines,
in which Hòu-jì was sacrificed to as the 'First Ancestor' shǐ-zǔ,
King Wén as the 'Great Ancestor' tài-zǔ,
King Wǔ as the 'Great Exemplar' tài-zōng.
In the dì and qiā sacrifices the general shrine is included.
In one year there are four sacrifices to the ancestors:
in spring the sacrifice is called cí,
in summer yuè,
in autumn cháng,
in winter zhēng.
In spring scallions and eggs are offered,
in summer wheat and fish,
in autumn millet and pork,
in winter rice and goose (Wáng zhì).
The Feudal Lords announce the first day of the month in the Ancestral Temple.
At the sacrifice there is a tablet
to which the filial son can attach his feelings of affection for the deceased.
The Xià used a tablet of the wood of the 'pine' sōng,
so as to 'stimulate themselves' sǒng-dòng;
the Yīn used a tablet of the wood of the 'cypress' bǎi,
so as to 'urge themselves' pò-cù;
the Zhōu used a tablet of the wood of the 'chestnut' lì,
so as to 'inspire themselves with awe' zhàn-lì (Lún yǔ).
a tablet of the wood of the mulberry-tree is constructed.
A liàn sacrifice a tablet of the wood of the chestnut is used.
The tablet is of wood,
which resembles man
in its growing and decaying, and it is inscribed.
The tablet is one foot square;
another opinion says it is one foot two inches long.
At the yú sacrifice, which takes place after the return from the grave at noon,
a tablet of the wood of the mulberry-tree is constructed.
A liàn sacrifice a tablet of the wood of the chestnut is used.
The tablet with its case is deposited at the western wall.
At the sacrifice there is an 'impersonator' shī,
who is served with food and drink as if he were the living father (Shī).
The institution of 'audiences' cháo-pìng
is to honour the Lord and father
and emphasize the filial way.
Pìng means
wèn 'to inquire';
the subject wishes to assure himself that his Lord is in good health.
Cháo means
xiàn 'to appear';
in five years there is one cháo audience,
on which occasion one's spiritual power and ritual behaviour may appear in their fullness.
The cháo audience takes place in the first month of summer, the fourth month of the year.
When a Feudal Lord on his cháo audience is about to reach the capital
he sends an envoy to communicate his mission to the Son of Heaven;
the Son of Heaven sends a great officer to welcome him in the suburb, one hundred lǐ from the capital,
and the Heir to welcome him in the suburb, fifty lǐ from the capital (Jìn lǐ jīng; Shàng shū dà zhuàn).
At the cháo audience
the Son of Heaven personally gives to the Feudal Lords the tally of the Auspicious Token of Good Faith (Jìn lǐ jīng; Shàng shū).
The Feudal Lords pay 'court-visits' cháo-pìng to each other
as an expression of mutual esteem.
A Duke gives presents of jade,
A Minister a lamb (Shū).
It is on the first day of the first month
that they go with their presents to congratulate their Lords.
The ritual at a cháo audience
is that the Lord goes out and installs himself outside the inner gate;
the Son of Heaven bows to the Feudal Lords
and the Ducal Ministers one by one,
to the Ministers collectively,
to the great officers and common officers cursorilly; the common officers are not saluted with the hands.
Once in three years the Feudal Lords present officers to the Son of Heaven,
while the Son of Heaven solicits them(Yuè lìng).
Besides the presenting of officers by the Feudal Lords
there is the solicitation by the Son of Heaven
in order that those who were overlooked by the Feudal Lords may be brought forward.
Lù means
dà 'great',
dào 'the Way',
zhèng 'correct'.
Lù also means
the Lord's vehicle.
The carriage of the Son of Heaven is called dà-lù,
that of a Feudal Lord lù-chē,
that of a great officer xuān-chē,
that of a common officer shì-chē.
The yù-lù
is the dà-lù.
A vehicle is called lù because with it one treads the 'road' lù.
One drives in a carriage standing.
In a carriage one does not turn one's head round (Lún yǔ).
The carriage has the hé and luán bells;
the luán bells are on the cross-bar,
the hé bells on the front-bar.
The bells only sound harmoniously when one drives correctly (Shī; Lǔ xùn).
In spring the hunt is called tián,
in summer miáo,
in autumn sōu,
in winter shòu.
The general name for hunting is tián (Chūn qiū gǔ liáng zhuàn).
For the offering to the Ancestral Temple
the King personally hunts the 'game' qín.
Qín is the general name for birds and quadrupeds.
The King does not in person catch fish.
Huáng-dì created palaces and houses to escape from cold and heat.
Gōng 'palace' means zhōng 'within'.
The hall of the Son of Heaven is nine feet high.
Táng 'hall' means míng 'bright'(Lǐ jì).
There are four gates opening to the outside (Lǐ sān cháo jì).
There are 'lobbies' shú
by the gate,
where the subjects, visiting their Lord,
may 'ripely' shú reflect on their tasks.
There are 'towers' jué on the gates,
as an adornment
and to distinguish between the high and the lowly.
Jué means
yí 'to be on the alert'.
Why place the 'screen-wall' píng in front of the gate?
The píng
is to shelter oneself.
The Son of Heaven
has a screen-wall for the outer gate;
a Feudal Lord
one for the inner gate.
The walls of the palace of the Son of Heaven are called chóng-chéng;
chóng means gāo 'high';
those of the Feudal Lords are called gàn-chéng
because they do not 'dare' gàn to act of their own accord.
The son of Gòng-gōng was called Xīu;
he was fond of roaming about,
and went wherever boat or carriage might carry him
or his legs lead him;
he is worshipped as the 'Spirit of the Roads' zǔ-shén.
When the Son of Heaven is ill
one speaks of bú-yù,
when a Feudal Lord is ill one speaks of fù-zǐ.
When a Great officer is ill one speaks of fù-xīn,
when a common officer is ill one speaks of quǎn-mǎ.
Towards the winter-solstice the Noble Man rests his body, the officials stop their work, and no governmental affairs are attended to.
The Xià counted the days
by tens,
and the foot measured ten inches.
The Yīn had twelve months in a year,
and the foot measured twelve inches.
The Zhōu flourished by applying the principle of Earth.
Earth
which is yin,
and modelled themselves on woman,
whose hands cover a surface of eight inches;
the foot measured eight inches.
A man's 'half-pace' jiàn is three feet.
The Xià is denoted by the term hòu 'lords',
the Yīn and the Zhōu are denoted by the term rén 'people'.
